PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support ``The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill'' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of widespread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill:
1. offer nothing more than is already available under law,
2. deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
That the Senate should completely reject the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATUTORY AUTHORITIES AND GOVERNMENT BUSINESS ENTERPRISES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a document relating to Proposed Policy Guidelines for Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises, and I seek leave, Mr President, to make a statement relating thereto and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I present for the information of the Parliament a Document entitled Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises-Proposed Policy Guidelines. In doing so I make a statement regarding the Government's view of the role of its statutory authorities and business enterprises and the principles underlying the proposed guidelines.
Introduction

The Hawke Government was elected in 1983 on a platform which placed high priority on reforming Government administration. The Government's Policy Discussion Paper on Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises is the fourth in a series which began with Reforming the Australian Public Service and was continued with Budget Reform and Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities.

The Policy Discussion Paper outlines the proposed policy guidelines for the future management, performance and public accountability of Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises. As with the three previous papers, the Government wishes to encourage wide consultation with the community on the proposals. Owing to the very great diversity in the functions and responsibilities of statutory authorities, the general policy guidelines inevitably will need to be tailored to the circumstances of individual authorities. The purpose of the policy review process of which this Discussion Paper forms a part is to develop a coherent set of principles and mechanisms for application in the review of individual authorities.

When work first started on the Policy Discussion Paper, it was not envisaged that its release would coincide with a political debate on privatisation. Unfortunately, the politicisation of the issue has detracted from sensible, balanced discussion. It also has had the damaging effect of polarising opinions. Those at the conservative end have wanted to privatise just about every profitable enterprise, though conspicuously, they are not so enthusiastic about privatising the unprofitable ones. Some at the progressive end seem to favour public ownership at all cost-simply because the conservatives want privatisation.

The previous Government displayed antipathy towards statutory authorities and government business enterprises. Through their neglect they starved these organisations of capital, stifled managerial incentive and demoralised the workforce. Now the response of the present Opposition is to privatise-indicating the same lack of concern about efficiency as was evident during their seven years in Government.

The intrusion of ideology into the debate has promoted the myth that private ownership equates with competition and the absence of regulation. Too often this has been used simply as a smokescreen behind which proposals have been developed for the liquidation of public assets to fund promised tax cuts or expanding government activity. Many of these proposals have drawn from overseas models, especially from the experiment in privatisation in the United Kingdom.

It is therefore most illuminating to look at the United Kingdom Government's record on privatisation. The United Kingdom record shows that privatisation has not led to deregulation; it has not led to deregulation; it has not led to increased competition. Instead, regulation has been maintained with privatisation or even increased. Unwilling to relinquish control, the United Kingdom Government has retained substantial equity or special voting rights in companies it has privatised. For the same reason it has prevented concentration of private ownership, going so far in the case of privatising British Telecom to offer discounts on telephone bills to customers who agreed to hold their shares rather than re-sell them. And quite blatantly the United Kingdom Government has barred competition in markets served by privatised companies and has established watchdog bodies equipped with a whole raft of regulations to control markets in which privatised companies are operating.

A long list of academics has observed that the United Kingdom Government has sacrificed de- regulation in favour of privatisation. They have been led to conclude that conflicts will arise between achieving efficiency and obtaining a high price for a government firm, that privatisation, as it turns out in practice, in fact inhibits liberalisation, that when the test comes, it is far from clear that the government's free enterprise instincts are anything like as committed to competition as they are to private ownership and finally, that the conflict between privatisation and liberalisation is no longer a conflict: it is a rout. The titles of these papers are available from the Office of the Minister of Finance.

The conflict to which these academics and others have referred stems from the dilemma facing governments wishing to privatise for short-term gain: sale proceeds are maximised by insulating the privatised business from competition through government regulation, so that de-regulation would reduce the price the Government could expect to obtain from privatising the company.

The Hawke Labor Government has demonstrated its resolve to remove unnecessary regulation so as to encourage efficiency and with it, sustainable economic growth. Efficiency is the real issue, not private or public ownership. The privatisation dogma has diverted attention from the question of efficiency. The Policy Discussion Paper on Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises attempts to return public discussion to the question of efficiency in government authorities.

What are statutory authorities and government business enterprises? A statutory authority is an organisation established by an Act of Parliament to provide services to the community. There are more than 250 Commonwealth statutory authorities. These authorities collectively deliver an enormous range of services, from scientific research to television broadcasting and from compiling national accounts to displaying works of art.

Most statutory authorities derive little or no revenue from the services they deliver, relying heavily on the Commonwealth Budget for funding. But there are exceptions in the form of two special types of statutory authorities: statutory marketing authorities (SMAs) and government business enterprises. SMAs are financed through levies paid by growers or from the sale of produce. Government business enterprises sell their services and derive a substantial proportion of their revenue from those sales. Although the absolute amounts of Budget funding for government business enterprises may be large, Budget funding usually represents a much smaller proportion of total funding of government business enterprises than is the case with ordinary statutory authorities. Some government business enterprises, of course, are completely independent of the Budget.

Ordinary statutory authorities include many familiar names-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Australian National Gallery, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the National Parks and Wildlife Service-and some not so well known-the Office of Australian War Graves, the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board and the Oilseeds Research Council.

Ten SMAs have been established within the Commonwealth Primary Industry portfolio at the request of primary producers. They co-ordinate the marketing of primary produce. About 80 per cent of rural exports are derived from industries covered by SMAs.

There are eighteen major Commonwealth government business enterprises. The biggest and possibly best-known are Telecom, OTC, Australia Post, the Commonwealth Bank, the Australian National Line (ANL), the Australian National Railways Commission (AN), TAA and Qantas. These eight account for well over 90 per cent of all employees in Commonwealth government business enterprises. Some government business enterprises are established as public companies fully owned by the Commonwealth (eg Qantas).
Statutory authorities and government business enterprises in our mixed economy

A threshold question in reviewing Government policy on statutory authorities and government business enterprises is why we have these organisations. Government departments are the primary mechanism for the implementation of government policy. They are subject to direct ministerial direction. But there are reasons for looking beyond the departmental system for the delivery of some publicly-provided services. In order for commercial and some other services to be delivered effectively and efficiently they must be free of the day-to-day control of Ministers and indeed, of government departments. Yet there is no doubt that governments should have the power to ensure that authorities and government business enterprises comply with Government Policy. In other instances, statutory authorities have grown up through a series of ad hoc government decisions, without prior consideration in detail of the national benefits and costs of their establishment.

Ours is a mixed economy, though it is worth pointing out that among the twenty-three Western industrialised countries (the OECD countries) Australia ranks about sixth lowest in terms of the share of the public sector in the national economy. There has been a rather unproductive political debate in Australia and overseas over the optimal size of government. It is asserted in some quarters that Australia has Big Government and that this ought to be reduced to make room for the private sector. Not only is this assertion in conflict with the facts, it is founded on ideological prejudice rather than on any rigorous comparison of the performance of public and private enterprises. Extensive empirical research has been unable to establish any systematic difference in the efficiency of public and private enterprises: excellent performers can be found in both sectors, as can abject failures.

Government business enterprises provide infrastructure and services upon which private industry and commerce depend. In addition to providing services on which an economic rate of return on investment legitimately could be expected, government business enterprises often have been assigned by the Commonwealth the responsibility of extending services to remote areas and to disadvantaged groups who otherwise would not have access to them. The fulfilment of these ``community service obligations'' (CSOs) most commonly has been required in the case of natural monopolies. Among the most striking examples of natural monopolies are many of the services provided by Telecom and Australia Post. Where it is Commonwealth Government policy for these services to be extended at reasonable cost to remote areas and disadvantaged groups, the case for a private unregulated company completely disintegrates. Profit maximising private firms would provide virtually no postal or telephone services outside of the cities and major towns. Charges needed to fully recover costs would be so high in country areas as to choke off virtually all demand. Few Australians would accept a system which denied telephones or mail to a significant proportion of the population and about 95 per cent of the country. The privatisers' response to that difficulty has been that the private firm could be subsidised from the Budget in providing unprofitable ser-vices. While that is true, it destroys the purported rationale of privatisation-that the profit motive will induce a lower cost, more efficient service. A privately-owned firm with costs underwritten by government has no profit-related interest in efficiency or cost control.

Many of the Commonwealth statutory autho-rities have established a high reputation in the community for the delivery of services. And the return on assets achieved in recent years by government business enterprises such as OTC and Telecom would make many private business managers envious. Australia Post, the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas, TAA, the Australian National Line (ANL) and the Australian National Railways Commission (AN) all have made steady improvements in efficiency under the present Government following years of neglect under the previous Government. To illustrate, new guidelines were issued in May 1984 to the directors of Qantas, giving the company greater freedom and flexibility in managing its commercial activities. The new guidelines complemented other measures taken by the Government to place the operations of Qantas on a surer commercial footing. The company is now trading profitably again after a number of years of losses. TAA also has been given far greater flexibility in management and greater responsibility in its commercial operations. Following an injection of capital in 1983, TAA has returned to profitability, with a net profit of $3.9m in 1983-84 and of $30.0m in 1984-85. The Government has initiated policies that are revitalising ANL. In 1983 ANL was virtually bankrupt. It is now becoming a successful public enterprise as a result of a new commercially oriented legislative charter, restructured top management, a generally responsible approach by employees and their unions, and a strengthening of its capital base. ANL achieved a record operating profit of $41.5m in 1984-85, contrasted with its record operating loss in 1982-83 of $18.8m (though ANL is not out of the woods yet, having accumulated losses of $110m). AN too has been given an updated commercially oriented charter. Over the past three years AN has reduced its call on the taxpayer by 42 per cent in real terms because of improved efficiency.

But there is no room for complacency. The development of general policy approach to statutory authorities and government business enterprises not only will help in recognising and acknowledging the fine performance of many of these organisations, it will help identify areas for further improvement and will provide a framework for addressing the problems of those organisations which have not performed well. The alternative-of selling off the good performers and further subsidising the poor performers-is nothing but a formula for running down the stock of public assets. It is an alternative which rewards inefficiently by subsidising it and penalises efficiency by privatising it.
General principles underlying the proposed guidelines

Statutory authorities and government business enterprises tend to attract attention when they perform badly; good performances usually go unnoticed. This has encouraged conservative, risk-averse management and the imposition of extra controls by government. Shackled with these controls, management often has become demo-ralised and performance has worsened, not improved. In other instances, public organisations, sheltered from market discipline, have grown inefficient and unresponsive to public demands. This sheltering from the market can create opportunities for the dissipation or diversion of government business enterprise surpluses away from consumers and taxpayers. This could allow powerful employee groups to benefit-and allow politically expedient governments to porkbarrel in assisting sensitive electorates and powerful supporters. These organisations also can be milked for revenue, starved of capital or put too far into debt by governments with short time horizons and immediate budgetary problems.

A new generally-applicable approach is needed, an approach designed to provide incentive, to enhance efficiency and to improve public accountability. The Government wishes to establish a degree of deregulation and a pattern of public enterprise which will best enhance the productive and distributive performance of the economy as a whole. As part of its general policy of removing unnecessary regulation, the Government proposes to reduce existing direct controls over statutory authorities and government business enterprises where it is satisfied with progress on the performance and public accountability of those organisations. As reflected in its policy measures applied already to a number of key authorities, the Government believes that these organisations should have responsible and enterprising management. Its proposed approach aims to encourage flair and managerial excellence, rather than conservative, unimaginative mediocrity. Consistent with this, the Government wishes to ensure that these organisations are efficient and publicly accountable, and that they comply with government policy.

In view of the diversity in assigned responsibilities, structure and funding of statutory authorities, it is appropriate that there be some differences in the policy guidelines for the various types of authorities. Accordingly, proposed guidelines have been developed to apply to ordinary statutory authorities, and special guidelines have been developed for SMAs and government business enterprises.
Proposed guidelines for ordinary statutory authorities

The Government proposes to make sparing use of statutory authorities when new or upgraded functions relating to the normal business of government are to be performed. It believes that for many purposes Government departments have the decided advantage of making the relevant Minister directly responsible to the community for the effectiveness and efficiency of administration. It also has the cost-saving advantage of making use of long established administrative machinery and procedures, rather than necessitating the establishment of new machinery and procedures each time a new function is to be performed.
When establishing or reviewing a statutory authority the Government intends that:
The authority's relationship with the responsible Minister, its governing board and other government agencies will be specified clearly in legislation.
The authority's charter, its reporting obligations and its procedures for funding and financial management also will be specified clearly in legislation.
Ministerial powers of direction, when used, will be in writing, and will be reported in the authority's annual report to Parliament.
Financial and reporting arrangements will be standardised.
Revised arrangements governing the creation and control of subsidiaries of statutory authorities will be adopted, including requirements for ministerial approval and notification to Parliament.
As appropriate to the circumstances of individual bodies, `sunset' provisions will be included in the authorities' enabling legislation.
Proposed guidelines for statutory marketing authorities
When establishing or reviewing SMAs the Government intends that:
Boards will be of workable size (at most nine to eleven members), with all members being selected on merit, and with members serving in the corporate interests of the organisation.
Boards generally will comprise a Chairperson and Government Member selected by the Minister, and other members with special expertise selected by a statutory selection committee.

Management will be required to adopt corporate planning techniques in order to chart the performance of SMAs, thereby placing the Minister for Primary Industry in a better position to monitor and evaluate their performance.
SMAs will be given greater autonomy, with their Boards being authorised to direct their business along commercial lines, free from day-to-day government oversight.
Accountability of SMAs to the industries they serve will be strengthened either through Annual General Meetings or formal reporting arrangements to representative industry bodies.

Further details of the Government's policy framework for statutory marketing authorities are provided in Chapter IV and in the paper released in January 1986 by the Minister for Primary Industry entitled `Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities: A Government Policy Statement'.
Proposed guidelines for government business enterprises

The proposed approach to government business enterprises has three specific components: the preparation of strategic plans including financial performance objectives; a reduction in direct controls over the day-to-day operations of enterprises; and improved quality of information for the assessment of enterprise performance.
In the application of this program of efficiency, decontrol and accountability the Government intends that:
Existing direct controls will be reduced on the basis of a case-by-case assessment in the context of strategic planning.
Controls for possible consideration including contract approval ceilings, purchasing and offsets, and borrowings, including the subjection of enterprises' loan raisings to Loan Council procedures.

Enterprises will be expected to provide to the responsible Minister a strategic corporate plan covering fixed periods of three to five years ahead for consideration and approval, in consultation with the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance as necessary of those aspects requiring formal Government approval.
The plans will be prepared and revised at intervals not exceeding three years.
They will incorporate economic and broad financial objectives, and technical operational targets.
Enterprises will work towards a financial target established in advance by the responsible Minister in consultation with the enterprise.
The financial target will supplement any other performance monitoring measures considered appropriate for the particular enterprise.

In setting financial targets for achieving economic efficiency the Government will have regard for the trading conditions in the industry within which the enterprise operates, for its relative commercial and market strengths and for the extent to which, on the basis of Government policy, it is required to meet any community service obligations and to pursue other non-commercial objectives.

Before allowance for the cost of meeting community service obligations the financial performance of enterprises should be sufficient to justify the long-term retention of assets in the enterprise rather than in some alternative use.

The Government will be calling for further work by officials (chaired by the Department of the responsible Minister) with a view to translating this guideline into specific targets for individual enterprises.
Where an enterprise, consistent with its statutory obligations, is able to generate a financial surplus after meeting all costs and interest charges then dividends should be paid to the Commonwealth.

The extent of dividend payments from individual enterprise will depend, among other things, on the requirement of those enterprises to retain earnings to finance capital expansion, reduce borrowings or improve their cash flow position.
In most cases it will be appropriate to provide for an enterprise to recommend a dividend payment to the Commonwealth and for the responsible Minister to accept or vary that recommendation.
Some enterprises have no Commonwealth equity but instead make a return to the Commonwealth through fixed interest payments: This would need to be taken into account.
Annual reports of enterprises will give account of performance against previously established goals, together with assessments of the cost of meeting community service obligations.
The Government's guidelines for the form and standard of financial statements of Commonwealth undertakings will continue to be updated, refined and applied.
Consultation with the community

The Government invites comment on this discussion paper over the next three months. In the light of those comments the Government intends developing a White Paper on the subject, where its more detailed policies for reform will be articulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion. I have had only limited time to examine the ministerial statement which has been put down by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and I have not had a chance properly to scan the proposed policy guidelines which he has tabled.
—Frittering away your time at the outset.

—That is quite true. I have had the statement for two hours, but because of party meetings and other matters, I have not had a chance to examine it in detail. This statement continues the record of the Hawke Government's thoroughly dishonest contribution to debate on important economic issues. I do not suppose we should be surprised at that because the dishonesty started with the National Economic Summit Conference, at which a first class economic debate took place in the parliamentary chamber, and was reduced to a communique which in no way reflected the views expressed by many of the participants in the economic summit.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent months we have seen a whole series of attempts to debate issues that are of importance to Australia and to our economic future. We have seen tentative admissions by Ministers, including Senator Button, that we need to do something about labour market flexibility, but as soon as the issue is raised by the Opposition it is treated in a total political fashion by the Government, instead of the Government trying to come to grips with the very real problem that Australia faces in its present economic circumstances.

What we have today from Senator Walsh is just a rehash of a speech that he gave last February. We were told at that time there was to be a release of these papers in March. We have waited three months and nothing new has been produced in this statement. The supreme irony of the statement is to be found on page 2 where the Minister says:
Unfortunately, the politicisation of the issue-
he is referring to the issue of privatisation-
has detracted from sensible, balanced discussion.

If ever there were a case of crocodile tears, it would be in that sentence of the Minister's where he is expressing the idea that it is unfortunate that the issue of privatisation has been politicised, when clearly the issue has been politicised by the Government. One only has to go back to last December to find that the Australian Labor Party is reported as having decided to organise among Public Service unions a campaign of opposition to privatisation policies and a report that the ALP National Secretary, Mr Bob McMullan, had approached one of the largest Federal public service unions and sought the service of a full time official to organise the campaign.

It is true that the issue of privatisation has been politicised-against the national interest and the interests of consumers-and those who have politicised it have been the ALP, and not least the leading members of this Government. The debate should be about the benefits that can be provided for Australian consumers and taxpayers. The real issues are as to the extent to which we can promote efficiency in the public sector. But, instead, the ALP has been intruding ideology into the debate and seeking to score cheap political points. That has occurred at both State and Federal levels. In my State of Western Australia in the last State election campaign great use was made of the issue of privatisation by the State Labor Party. Letters were written to every employee of every statutory authority warning people that they would lose their jobs and so on. Within a month of returning to government at the State level in Western Australia, the Labor Party proceeded to allow private interests to be taken up in the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia.

This Government has taken some steps to reduce the impact of the public sector which have had the support of the Opposition-for example, the sale of the Belconnen Mall. We had the intrusion of the private sector into the war service homes area. On occasions, the Government itself has made motions towards greater use of the private sector and trying to get greater efficiency, but at the political level it has done nothing except try to score points in this debate, which ought to be about how we can best benefit the people of Australia who pay for the greater statutory corporations which are part of the life of this country.

What is said in the statement on page 3 is that we have had the intrusion of ideology into the debate and that this has promoted the myth that private ownership equates with competition and the absence of regulation. There is a very heavy burden in this statement which suggests that the Opposition is trying to assert that private ownership of itself is what the privatisation debate is about. The fact of the matter is that the Liberal and National parties consistently in this debate have stressed competition as the essential prerequisite for improvements in efficiency and service. Ownership is an important but, in fact, a second-order condition in the privatisation debate. The principles which have been adopted by the Opposition in this matter make it clear and state:

The fundamental principle underlying a policy that returns functions from the public to the private sector is that competition ensures better and more efficient delivery of goals and services to consumers than centralised decision-making.
Only last week on behalf of the Opposition I took part in a program on this issue broadcast on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I said:
I think it is very important to note that the Opposition takes the view that it is really not ownership that determines efficiency, it is whether or not there is competition.

That has been central to the statements made by Mr Carlton, who has spoken often on behalf of the Opposition on this subject, and by Mr Howard, who also has spoken often on this subject. We find the Minister saying on page 4 of his statement:
A long list of academics has observed that the UK Government has sacrificed deregulation in favour of privatisation.

Whatever the truth or falsity of that comment, it bears no relationship to the approach that has been adopted by the Opposition here in Australia. We must be looking at Australia's conditions and Australia's needs. If I may quote John Howard, he said:
Privatisation is not an exercise in selling off the family silver in order to reduce expenditure.
It is not an exercise in raising money to finance tax cuts.

Those statements were made by the Leader of the Opposition in 1985. Those statements are utterly consistent with what has been said over and over again by Opposition spokesmen. It would not be any part of the policy of the Opposition to be selling assets which are owned by the Government of Australia to finance current expenditure.

It has been made quite clear that we think that, if there is any transfer of ownership, the proceeds should be used to reduce the excessive and enormous public indebtedness which has so substantially increased under the present Government. Again, on page 4 of the statement the Minister said that efficiency is the real issue, not private or public ownership. As far as the Opposition is concerned this is part of a statement setting up a straw man. Efficiency is the real issue. Competition and the fostering of competition is the real issue if we are to benefit the consumers of Australia. I think that the preliminary concern that I would express about these guidelines which the Minister has tabled here today, and which will be available for public discussion and comment, is that there is nothing in the guidelines for government business enterprises which will ensure real economic efficiency. The major elements of the guidelines are that there will be a reduction in existing direct controls and the provision of strategic corporate plans for periods of three to five years which will incorporate economic and broad financial objectives and that enterprises will work towards a financial target.

There is nothing in the guidelines which ensures cost efficiency and better consumer services. The imposition of a financial target by the Government does not improve incentives to be efficient. It could well be that the financial targets are simply met by raising charges or by providing fewer and poorer quality services. In the statement we find the Minister saying that private industry might well envy the return on assets that has been achieved by government business enterprises. On page 9 of the statement the Minister said:
. . . the return on assets achieved in recent years by Government business enterprises such as OTC and Telecom would make many private business managers envious.

Consumers of the products, the people who use the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and Telecom Australia, might well take the view that the return on assets achieved reflects a very significant increase in the charges that they have had to pay to get those returns for those statutory corporations. My response to the Minister is that the return on assets achieved by bodies such as OTC and Telecom is something that I am sure could be achieved by many private enterprise businesses if they had the monopolies which are enjoyed by Telecom and the OTC and the capacity to impose charges which will give those returns without having to be concerned about competition from some other sector which might cause them to lose customers because of those prices.

We say that nothing in the guidelines which have been put down will do anything to ensure cost efficiency and to ensure that, by competition, consumers will get a choice between varied products which meet their requirements. The guidelines which have been put down by the Government could simply permit gross overcharging of consumers to the benefit of the balance sheets of the bodies that are being run by government. It is said at page 8 of the statement:
It is asserted in some quarters that Australia has big Government and that this ought to be reduced to make room for the private sector.
A little later it is stated:
. . . not only is this assertion in conflict with the facts, it is founded on ideological prejudice rather than on any rigorous comparison of the performance of public and private enterprises.
It is also stated:
Excellent performers can be found in both sectors, as can abject failures.

Recently a paper was produced by this Government-not the Opposition-which puts the cost of the burden of regulations on private enterprise in Australia at between $40 billion and $80 billion. The paper sets out the direct cost of government regulation but goes on to give an assessment-this paper was tabled in this place by the Government, not the Opposition-of the cost to the private sector of between $40 billion and $80 billion because of government regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not suggesting that that has happened in just three years of a Labor government?

—I am suggesting that it is totally inconsistent with what is being said in the statement put down by Minister Walsh today that we do not have big government in Australia when the Government itself has put down an estimate of such an enormous cost being imposed by government on the private sector. If one looks at the Hawke Government in terms of whether it is a government that has promoted big government or small government one sees that personal income tax revenue has risen by 5.2 per cent a year in real terms since 1982-83, a much faster rise than the rise which occurred during the Fraser years. We find the selective use of international comparisons by the Hawke Government in terms of what the impact of government is. I simply make the point in this preliminary part of the debate on this statement that this Government, which in this statement is denying the proposition that there is big government in Australia, is a government which has presided over Budgets which have taken the largest share of our gross domestic product for the public sector in the history of Australia. The complaints which are heard about the size of government in Australia are about the excessive degree of regulation which occurs in the Australian economy, regulation which is estimated by this Government in a paper put down in this place to cost in excess of $40 billion per annum, a quite extraordinary figure. That means big government to most people who are complaining. The level of taxation, which has increased very substantially under this Government, is another area of complaint about big government in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also expresses concern in this statement-again, I think the concern is based on its attempts to politicise this issue rather than to deal with its merits-about remote area services. The Opposition has said over and over again that it will not consider changes to the arrangements which will prejudice the communications and other services which are provided for remote parts of Australia. The record of the Liberal and National parties in government has been one of showing very great concern for those Australians who live outside our great metropolitan centres. They are a minority of our population, they produce a great proportion of our national wealth in our exports and they are entitled, as Australians, to fair dealing in the provision of services. We have made it clear that we will not consider changes in the administration of these statutory authorities, for example, which will prejudice people who live in remote areas of Australia.

What we have from this Minister is a statement which, as I have said, is just an attempt to politicise this issue. It also tries to suggest that no benefit will be gained in remote areas by applying the principle of competition.

I say, in preliminary response to what has been put down in the statement by the Minister this morning, that in the existing arrangements which are used, for example, by the Australian Postal Commission for the provision of services in remote areas, there is already use of the private sector, use of the tender process and use of the principle of competition to try to reduce the cost of services which are provided, often at very great difficulty, in remote parts of Australia. Again, it is just a crude attempt to politicise what ought to be regarded as an important economic debate in the statements which are made about the possible impact on the remoter parts of Australia of any process of regulation reform, privatisation or better control of statutory authorities.

In summary, the Opposition, whilst welcoming the preparedness of the Government to see public discussion on those proposed policy guidelines, is really disgusted by the attempt which has been made by the Minister in this statement to obscure the real issues which arise in this area by making political points rather than dealing with the issues of substance. I would like to make it quite clear that the Opposition approaches the issue of privatisation, which has been given such prominence in the Minister's statement, from the point of view of a number of fundamental points which I would like to make now. We believe that we can reduce the cost of the production of goods and the delivery of services if there is competition. We think that consumers benefit where there is competition in providing services for them. We see the provisions of competitive services as being central to improving what is done for consumers in Australia. We are not about creating private monopolies where public monopolies at present exist. We do not see any point in having a mere transfer of ownership; we think it is important that any chance of ownership should be something which facilitates the more competitive provision of services in Australia.

If I could take one of the more obvious areas where we have sought to introduce greater competition, it would be in the area of airlines. We believe that the present arrangements reduce the services which are available to Australians and increase the costs of the services available. In our approach to this issue, we undertake to put the interests of consumers and taxpayers first and to ensure, as the Minister himself acknowledges in his statement, that the great statutory corporations which have been created by both Labor and coalition governments are administered not just for the benefit of those who work for them, but for the benefit of the people of Australia. I hope that there will be an opportunity later in this session to have a further look at the statement which has been put down by the Minister this morning and to have a further look at the proposed guidelines. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a very brief statement on the Government's policy guidelines for statutory authorities. The Australian Democrats support in principle the efficient management of statutory authorities, statutory marketing authorities and government business enterprise generally. In referring to government businesses, we believe that great steps forward could be made if many of these businesses adopted the principles of participatory democracy, tried to decentralise their control and tried to cellularise their organisational structure so that small groups of people had clearly defined objectives, and the outputs of these groups were measures on a regular basis so that the groups themselves could be self-regulating and self-directing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats tend not to support privatisation as a major policy initiative. So often the policy of privatisation means that everything the Government runs which is unprofitable should be retained by the Government and be a burden on the taxpayer and that profitable enterprises should be sold off to private enterprise. The deregulation of statutory authorities is a much more complex area than most people are prepared to admit, particularly those who want to deregulate everything. Often a lot of red tape is associated with the regulation of statutory authorities. Without doubt, this red tape should be cut. However, a case can often be made for new regulations for statutory authorities. Telecommunications is a prime example of this. We have in this country made many very effective technological advances in telecommunications which have particular application to South East Asia, China and India. Those advances have not been commercialised by Telecom Australia simply because, under its guidelines, Telecom is concerned with services and not with exporting technology. If Telecom's guidelines were changed, we could develop a very effective export industry by selling this country's telecommunications technology.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 follows debate in the Senate last October when the Opposition, together with the Australian Democrats, defeated Government legislation to change the management of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust for public servants. The Senate will recall that the main debate at that time centred on whether or not the management of the Investment Trust should be vested in what was substantially a trade union organised and elected body. Certainly, the Opposition had very little doubt that most of the measures in the Bill, apart from that section, had some merit. Indeed, it is time to improve and reform the circumstances under which the management of such vast amounts of money in the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust are handled.

SPEECH.PARA: We have no real concern about the measures that are incorporated in the Bill now before the Senate, as this Bill excludes the original proposi- tion that management of the Investment Trust itself should be vested substantially in the hands of nominees of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Just turning to that point, we should remind ourselves that clause 7 of the Bill that was defeated last year required that the Investment Trust be established with five members, one of whom would be a full time principal member nominated in accordance with sub-section (3) by the Minister. We had no particular complaint about that. Clause 7 also provided for a full time member to be nominated in accordance with sub-section (4) by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It also provided for two part time members to be nominated in accordance with sub-section (4) by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The last member was to be a part time member nominated by the Minister. So the outcome of all of this was that, of a total of five members of the board, the majority were to be direct nominees of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The debate on that Bill occurred last October at a time when there was much discussion in the community about the trend towards union controlled superannuation in the community.

While the Opposition clearly has no objection to the expansion of superannuation in the community generally, we do object to the way in which superannuation schemes are controlled. That was the core of our opposition to the clause establishing control of the Trust in the way proposed last year.

Let me expand a little on the question of superannuation generally. The Liberal and National parties have in their platform at present a clear commitment to the expansion of superannuation to all workers. It is our view that that ought to occur, although not in a way which is imposed by the trade union movement through union action, or indeed by Government fiat following some kind of cosy deal between the trade union movement and the Hawke Labor Government. Rather, the Liberal and National parties see a commitment to personal involvement in superannuation schemes on the part of employees, in conjunction with employers, and of course with the Government assisting by way of allowing taxation deductions for contributions made to schemes and providing tax exemption for income derived from superannuation schemes. We hold that that kind of system is practical, and in fact it has achieved a great deal. Statistics on the expansion of superannuation in the work force speak for themselves. From 1972 until the present time the proportion of the work force actually covered by superannuation schemes has expanded-from around a quarter of the total work force 14 or 15 years ago to around half at this time. That has occurred not through pressure from the trade union movement, not through some kind of cosy deal between the unions and the Government, but through the enhancement of taxation incentives for people to become involved in their own superannuation schemes.

I instance as a very real example the so-called section 23 F (2) (b) schemes, introduced by the Fraser Government back in 1980, which provided that people who were not members of employer-sponsored schemes could initiate their own schemes and contribute to them from their own funds if they so wished. They also covered people who were self-employed and who otherwise would have had no access to superannuation schemes. I am informed that the number of people in those kinds of schemes has risen dramatically, to around half a million at this time. They have been an outstanding success in encouraging more and more people in the work force to contribute towards their own long range retirement income fund. That kind of partnership is obviously successful and ought to be encouraged by any government.

What we are observing now, though, is a rather radical change in the way in which superannuation in this country is to be set up. The Opposition has raised many times the sorts of pressures being imposed upon the economy by the union push for the use of the so-called productivity case decision for compulsory superannuation contributions to be made for all employees in the work force. We understand the Government is having problems working out how that might apply to public sector employees and to those it puts in what it calls a safety net area, but I will return to that in a moment. To pick up the point about the public sector, which is really the essence of this Bill, the Government has not explained to us in any way how it is that the new superannuation push to which it is party, in conjunction with the trade union movement and through the accord mark 2, will lead to a scheme which will cover people currently covered under Public Service superannuation arrangements. For that reason alone we have very great concern about what it is that the Government intends for public sector employees.

I turn to the point in connection with this Bill, having made the point that there are significant pushes at present in the private sector for union-controlled superannuation. The Bill that was defeated last November sought to establish the same kind of union control over public sector superannuation arrangements. That is the reason why we objected to the legislation and the reason that we opposed it. We were joined in that opposition to the legislation by the Australian Democrats and, of course, that led to the defeat of the Bill.

This Bill does not provide for the establishment of the Trust to control the superannuation fund in the same way as was provided in that previous legislation. In fact, it seems that the Government has shied away altogether from the question of the membership of that Investment Trust and has not changed the position that obtained prior to the defeat of the legislation last year. What it has done is bring to account several other measures which are of concern to the Liberal and National parties. I shall move to those other measures in a moment, but, firstly, we make the point clear that our general support for this particular Bill is not based on the acceptance of any principle of union based superannuation as it is being pushed in the community at present. Our opposition remains to the concept of having union-based control over and above what we regard to be the most important factor of all-that is, professional and proper managerial control over superannuation funds so that appropriate and proper decisions are made about the investment of those funds.

There are several criteria that should be borne in mind in the management of superannuation funds. We know of the very substantial amount of money that is invested by superannuation schemes in the public sector-some $3 billion in this particular Investment Trust, as I understand it-and obviously those who control this fund have vast responsibilities, as well as duties and obligations to their members, to make the right decisions. Opposition senators have said consistently that the decisions ought to be made by people who are well trained and versed in the management techniques of such vast sums of money and that that ought to be the primary criterion in establishing the membership of the Investment Trust, rather than relying upon the kind of trust that would result from control by the trade union membership.

That professional approach is fundamental to the success of superannuation funds and brings with it, of course, the very substantial benefit for the taxpayers that if the return to the Trust is maximised, we would lower the impact upon taxpayers of their commitment to meet the requirements of payouts to superannuants when they retire. There are benefits to the taxpayer and to the Government from proper managerial control over the investments that are within this Trust.

I return to some of the other aspects of this Bill which give us concern. We note that the new Bill contains a feature that was not present in the previous legislation. This matter deals with the problem that has arisen for the Government in the light of an Administrative Appeals Tribunal case in the matter of a Mr Bewley, who is presently a member of the Fund and an employee of the Commonwealth. I shall go into the facts of his case in a few moments. In handling this matter the Government has sought to override the decision made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the Bewley case in such a way that that decision, which was favourable to Mr Bewley, will be overridden retrospectively to 1 July 1976 in all other cases which could have been subsequently appealed on the basis of the Bewley decision. In other words, the Government has imposed a retrospective provision here which goes back to the commencement of this superannuation fund on 1 July 1976 so as to override the rights of any members of that fund who may have experienced circumstances similar to those of Mr Bewley and who may subsequently have appealed successfully and had their cases treated in the same way as Mr Bewley's. Their rights have been affected retrospectively by this legislation. The Opposition's objection to that retrospectivity is the main issue in this matter and during the Committee stage of the debate we will move to oppose that part of the Bill-clause 2-which imposes retrospectivity in the way I have just outlined.

Let me just review the facts of Mr Bewley's case. The question at issue is that Mr Bewley was received into the Commonwealth superannuation scheme upon his joining the Commonwealth Public Service more or less on the basis of a contract, that contract being that he would become a full member of that scheme, notwithstanding any pre-existing illness that may have occurred. I understand from correspondence with Mr Bewley and others that that was his understanding of the original arrangements between the Government and himself when he moved from the Tasmanian Public Service to the Commonwealth Public Service. Subsequent to his taking up his position in the Commonwealth Public Service, Mr Bewley found that the Government, upon examination of his medical record, had discovered that at an earlier stage he had suffered from a melanoma which had been cleared up well before he joined the Commonwealth Public Service. Notwithstanding that, the Commonwealth then issued what is known as a benefit classification certificate against Mr Bewley. This meant that, in the event of his eventually retiring on the grounds of invalidity related to that pre-existing illness of the melanoma, he would not be able to obtain the full invalidity benefits of the superannuation scheme. That benefit classification certificate was subsequently taken up by Mr Bewley in representations to the Minister and then to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Eventually the Tribunal upheld Mr Bewley's case and overrode the benefit classification certificate. In other words, Mr Bewley won his case so that, in the event of the melanoma subsequently affecting his ability to continue in his job, his benefits would not be affected when he retired.

Perhaps Mr Bewley's case is different from many others in that it appears that he was guaranteed membership of the superannuation scheme by virtue of an arrangement with the Commonwealth when he joined the Commonwealth. It had been proven that the pre-existing illness-the melanoma-was not evident at the time of his joining the scheme because it had been cured. Apparently, it was the technical question of that melanoma subsequently coming to the knowledge of the administrators of the Superannuation Fund which led to the issuing of that certificate.

Much has been said in the general community about the question of abuse or otherwise of those so-called benefit classification certificates and about people retiring on grounds of invalidity when that invalidity was not necessarily the basis for their leaving the Public Service. Indeed, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) made statements in this place about the so-called rip-off of the superannuation scheme by people indulging in that kind of activity. That is the rationale for the introduction of the benefit classification certificate. However, the Opposition is convinced that in the case of Mr Bewley, which is the subject of this legislation, Mr Bewley suffered as a result of a breach of contract-the Government breached its arrangement. It does not matter whether the letter or the word of this arrangement was breached; the fact is that the spirit of it was certainly broken by the issuing of that certificate. Subsequently, the court upheld that the decision to issue that certificate should be overturned.

The Bill, while seeking to make retrospective its provisions to override the decision in Mr Bewley's case as they apply to all other members of the Superannuation Fund, does seek to protect Mr Bewley. The Bill sets out quite clearly in clause 6 (2) that Mr Bewley's case would not be affected by the retrospective provision. Mr Bewley therefore is protected. We are happy to see that. The problem that the Opposition now faces is that the rights of every other member of the Superannuation Fund will now be affected retrospectively by this legislation.

If the Opposition is successful in defeating the Government on clause 2 of the Bill, which we will oppose, Mr Bewley will lose the protection which is set down in the Bill. If the legislation is defeated on that point, one would expect the Government to follow an option that it has and seek a review of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision in the Federal Court. That, of course, would involve more expense. The issues involved are most difficult to resolve when one is trying to protect the rights of Mr Bewley who, I think, has been badly treated by this Government.

Because of the difficulties in this regard, I wrote to the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, some time in April raising the issues as I have just outlined them and making the point that, if an event unfavourable to Mr Bewley were to occur-that is, the passing of our amendment to this Bill, making it difficult for Mr Bewley to be protected-the Minister should seek to protect Mr Bewley separately by making an act of grace payment in the event of Mr Bewley ever being invalided out of the Public Service as a result of his pre-existing illness. The possibility of his being invalidated out is totally unknown, and no one can estimate whether or not that may occur. I suggest, though, that the likelihood is that it will never occur. Nevertheless, in order or protect Mr Bewley in these circumstances, we sought the Government's compassionate consideration of that point. Unfortunately, the Government wrote back via the Minister that it was not able to give me that assurance. I believe that the Government ought to consider this matter more deeply. I believe that there are issues at stake here which are to do not with the principle upon which the legislation is based but with justice in connection with Mr Bewley's case.

The facts that I have outlined to the Senate touch on the encouragement, if you like, for Mr Bewley to leave the Tasmanian Public Service, where he would have had no difficulties of the kind that we are now reviewing, and join the Commonwealth Public Service, where he finds himself subject to them, that factor becoming known after his having accepted a position in the Commonwealth Public Service. I think it is unjust to Mr Bewley and that the Government ought to be able to give a clear statement of protection for him in this case. I make the point again that I do not believe that that matter has anything to do with the general principle of the point that we have been making. The legislation which the Government is seeking to push through now will override Mr Bewley's decision at the AAT. Consequently, we are justified in taking our stand in principle on the retrospectivity question and Mr Bewley's case should be considered separately.

I hope that that guarantee will be forthcoming from the Minister. During the later stages of the debate on this matter we will be inquiring as to the Minister's intentions. In the meantime, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a copy of the letter dated 5 May 1986 which I have received from the Minister for Finance on the matter of Mr Bewley and which sets out the Government's position at that time.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator the Hon A. J. Messner
Senator for South Australia
Parliament House
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Messner,
I refer to your representations of 24 April 1986 on behalf of Mr P. J. Bewley of 313 Bugden Avenue, Fadden, A.C.T.

At the outset, I should point out that there is no benefit classification certificate presently in force in relation to Mr Bewley. Thus, there is no basis for consideration of an act-of-grace payment to Mr Bewley in the event that he should retire on invalidity grounds. The decision of 18 October 1985 by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal set aside the decision of the Commissioner for Superannuation to issue, pursuant to sub-section 16 (4) of the Superannuation Act 1976, a benefit classification certificate in respect of Mr Bewley specifying the condition ``History of superficial spreading melanoma''.

Sub-section 16 (6), (7) and (8) of the Act provide for the Commissioner for Superannuation to revoke a benefit classification certificate at the contributor's request following further medical examination and where the Commissioner is of the opinion that the contributor is not likely, by reason of or for a reason connected with the condition specified in the certificate, to cease to continue to be a contributor until his or her maximum retiring age. As there is no benefit classification certificate presently in force in relation to Mr Bewley it is not possible for consideration to be given to the application of these provisions to him in the light of the medical standards to which you refer.

The Tribunal's decision of 18 October 1985 is contrary to the purpose of the medical classification provisions of the Act which is to protect the Commonwealth against the risk of premature retirement or death caused by a physical or mental condition suffered at the time the person became a contributor to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. It is also at odds with the 1979 decision of the Tribunal in Re Linden which supported the manner in which the Commissioner for Superannuation has applied the provisions. Not only does the decision have serious cost implications but important questions of principle are involved.

The amendments to section 16 of the Act contained in sub-clause 6 (1) of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 which is presently before the Parliament would ensure that the ``real risk'' approach adopted by the Commissioner in the past, and which accords with the purpose of the provisions, is used in the future. The retrospective application of the provisions to 1 July 1976 (sub-clause 2 (1) of the Bill) would clarify that the ``real risk'' approach was also the appropriate and intended approach for past cases.

The two sub-clauses would ensure that past and future cases are treated on a common basis. Clearly it would be quite wrong in principle if those in relation to whom benefit classification certificates have been issued in the past were now able to take advantage of the alternative and unintended interpretation of the word ``likely'' and have their benefit classification certificates cancelled.

Sub-clause 6 (2) of the Bill would, however, protect Mr Bewley against the effects of the retrospective application of the amendments and ensure that a benefit classification certificate specifying the particular condition cannot be reinstated.

Because of the extremely serious general implications of the Tribunal's decision, there was no alternative but for the Commissioner to appeal it to the Federal Court. If the amendments to section 16 with retrospective effect to 1 July 1976 become law, the Commissioner's appeal will be withdrawn. If passage of the amendments with retrospective effect is not achieved, however, there will be no alternative but for the Commissioner to proceed with the appeal. The possible adverse consequences for Mr Bewley of the outcome of the appeal was an important consideration in the Commissioner seeking adjournment of the hearing of the appeal pending the outcome of Parliament's consideration of the Bill.

While it must be appreciated that the matter is one of great concern to Mr Bewley, resolution of the serious problems raised by the Tribunal's decision must be paramount. Mr Bewley's mind could, of course, be put at rest very quickly by a speedy passage of the Bill and the consequent statutory protection it will afford him.
Yours sincerely
PETER WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The final point that I make is that the Bill is unexceptionable except for the two or three matters that I have mentioned. We agree that improvements need to be made in the controls over the management of superannuation schemes and particularly the management of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust for public sector employees. We do not agree with any form of union control over the investment practices of those funds and, of course, we demonstrated our support for that principle in voting down the Government's legislation which sought to impose that last October. I understand that the Australian Democrats will be moving an amendment which seeks to put the control of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust in the hands of members insofar as each member of the Superannuation Fund would get to vote upon the membership of the Trust itself. That sounds fine in theory. It sounds like an admirable and very democratic solution. But I put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that it amounts to the same thing as the Government is proposing because it will mean that the most powerful bodies representing the members of the Fund-the trade unions-will have the most say in making sure that their nominees become the official nominees who are elected by the contributors. I believe that plays into the hands of the Government, which is seeking to do its cosy little deals with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Consequently, the Opposition does not support the Democrat amendment if it is in the form that I have just outlined, which is very similar to the amendment the Democrats proposed at the time of the defeat of the legislation last year. For those reasons, and subject to the reservations I have outlined, the Opposition will not be opposing the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. As Senator Messner pointed out, this legislation is identical to the legislation that was defeated in the Senate late last year with the exception that the appointment of the trustees of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust is now to be in the hands of the Government, as it always has been in the past. The Australian Democrats are unhappy about this method of appointment of trustees. We have repeatedly drawn attention to the critical problem surrounding superannuation, which is who should appoint the trustees. The amount of money involved in superannuation-which represents the savings of Australians-is enormous. Already 50 per cent of the money invested on the Australian stock exchanges is invested on behalf of superannuation funds. Once the 55 per cent of the work force that does not enjoy superannuation at the moment receives superannuation as a result of the Government's initiative, the amounts of money invested will at least double in a very short time. Therefore, the appointment of the trustees is vital. In effect, the trustees have the responsibility for investing these enormous amounts of money. It is not an exaggeration to say that whoever controls the superannuation funds of this country controls the Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: So far the Government has not really addressed the question of who should appoint the trustees. It has indicated that it wants this legislation passed before it has defined clearly how the trustees of all superannuation funds-not just the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund-should be appointed. The Australian Democrats' position on this matter is very clear. We believe that there should be equal representation by the two contributors-the employees and the employers. We believe that they should have equal representation on the board of trustees. I stress `equal'. We mean 50 : 50, not with the chairman having a controlling vote. That, in effect, would put enormous power in the hands of one person. Irrespective of a person's credentials one cannot put one person in charge of this enormous flow of the savings of Australians, the enormous flow of money that is involved. We must consider the havoc that wrong investment of superannuation funds could play with our industry and our stock exchanges.

Since the Government has not yet issued its guidelines on how the trustees are to be appointed-although the Democrats' position is very clear, as I have just outlined-we are in somewhat of a dilemma. In the Committee stage we will be moving amendments which will give the contributors the right to appoint trustees to the Superannuation Fund by virtue of an election at large. We say as it is very largely the money of the contributors that is being invested they should have a direct say in who the trustees are to be. If the contributors have faith in their union representative and want to appoint him as a trustee, so be it. It is indisputable to us that the contributors should have the final authority about appointing at least half of the trustees to any superannuation fund in this country. There has to be a balance between the two contributors-the employers and the employees. If the trustees representing those two sides cannot agree, there has to be a stalemate and no action should be taken until they can agree. That seems to be the only fair and safe way to go ahead in this area.

If the Government does not accept our amendment at the Committee stage, the Democrats will accept the legislation because the Government has given us an assurance that it will address the problem of how trustees are to be appointed. We await the Government's pronouncement on that matter. In the meantime, we have always agreed that there is an urgent need to reform the Commonwealth superannuation legislation. At present it is shackled, it is hide-bound, and the contributors, the Commonwealth public servants, are not receiving the return on their investments they should be receiving. We are prepared to accept pro tem an arrangement whereby the Government continues to appoint the trustees with the assurance that the Government will, in due course, come up with a clear definition of how trustees are to be appointed not only to the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund but to all superannuation funds. I hope that the Government will heed the Democrats' plea that these trustees should be appointed taking into account the wishes of the contributors as well as the employers, and that there is a balance on the Board of Trustees in all cases.

Senator Messner spent some time outlining the Bewley case. He claimed that the legislation now applied retrospectively and that, as such, the Opposition would be opposing those parts of the legislation. The Democrats have also received representations from those interested in the Bewley case and from Mr Bewley himself and we have considered the matter very carefully. I believe the Democrats' attitude on any retrospective legislation is well known: We oppose it. We have opposed it; we have stood our ground and have been very consistent in this area. However, on a careful assessment of the Bewley case we believe that, as to the claims that this legislation as it applies to the Bewley case is retrospective, it is retrospective purely on a technical ground. It is really not retrospective because the Government has tightened up the guidelines in the issuing of benefit classification certificates. In fact, these tighter guidelines have applied since the ruling in the Bewley case and before, back in 1976. So neither Mr Bewley nor anybody since or before that case was heard will be disadvantaged, because in fact the Government has been doing what this legislation now says it must do. It has been issuing benefit classification certificates in line with the tighter guidelines so that nobody will be disadvantaged with the passage of this legislation. For this reason we say it is not retrospective. It may be retrospective technically, but it will not disadvantage anybody, and for that reason we believe that the Democrats can allow the passage of the legislation.

Senator Messner indicated that the reason the legislation was blocked last year was that the Democrats supported the Opposition in blocking it. I am bound to point out that this legislation as it applied last year, with the majority of the trustees being appointed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, very nearly passed the Senate. The legislation passed the House of Representatives without members of the Opposition flagging in any way whatsoever the fact that a majority of the trustees were to be appointed by the ACTU. They let it pass through the House of Representatives, they did not move an amendment in that respect, and they did not raise the issue in the debate. The legislation came to the Democrats and it came specifically to my desk. I was told it was a routine piece of legislation. I read it through and found to my horror that the ACTU was to be given the authority to recommend three of the five trustees. That did not seem to me to be a routine piece of legislation, particularly as the trustees were to be in control of $7m a week.

We raised the matter with members of the Opposition. Their solution was to say: `No, we can't allow the ACTU to have control of these funds, but we will make the appointments of the trustees on the recommendation of bodies such as merchant bankers, financial institutions, et cetera'. In other words, they were prepared to go to the other extreme. They were prepared to say: `No, we can't let the ACTU recommend the appointment of the trustees, but we can rely on the merchant bankers, et cetera, to recommend the appointment of the trustees'. By and large these are competitors for funds who were to be given the right to recommend the appointment of trustees. So we went from the sublime to the ridiculous, from one extreme to the other, and got nowhere. The Opposition moved its amendments, which we were unable to support, and this Bill was defeated only at the third reading stage because the Opposition very belatedly realised that if it did not support a Democrat amendment in the third reading stage, the Bill would become law, the ACTU would get control of $7m a week, and the Government would have a resounding victory. It was an eleventh hour decision on behalf of the Opposition that this Bill was blocked last year. All I can say is: `Thank goodness'.

I do not want to delay the debate. A lot could be said about superannuation; a lot could be said about the Government's inaction so far in trying to tighten up its guidelines; and a lot could be said about the fact that no legislation has yet appeared on superannuation generally. We are waiting patiently for it. Presumably that will be forthcoming in the Budget session. In the meantime, this whole superannuation debate is one of the most critical the Australian Parliament will have to face for many years. I do not believe there is, as yet, full public awareness of the enormous amounts of money that will be involved in the superannuation initiative. Certainly there has not been an informed public debate as to how these funds should be controlled in the interests of contributors and in the interests of Australians generally in the long term. If these funds are imaginatively invested in this country they could contribute enormously to the development of Australia's export potential and the development of the wealth of this country. If they are squandered by investments overseas in places such as Saudi Arabia or wherever a fast buck can be made, the savings of Australians will be squandered and the long term development of this country will be put back many years.

We will support the legislation. We do so with reluctance because the Government has not yet faced up to how trustees are to be appointed and what is fair in the long term. However, we believe we cannot be a party to delaying or even amending the legislation because of the urgency of getting the guidelines reformed so that the very considerable funds invested on behalf of the Commonwealth Public Service can be invested in a much more efficient manner and the returns on those funds can be put to the benefit of Commonwealth public servants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Messner in his opposition to the retrospectivity element of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill, and to seek an act of grace payment to Mr Bewley, as Senator Messner outlined, but also to raise a couple of other points. One relates to delegation, the manner of which in this case appears to be inappropriate.
