The second point is on a matter of principle relating to the manner in which a Minister of the Crown, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has endeavoured to lean on independent, quasi- judicial tribunals by making insulting remarks about the merit of their decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to amend the Superannuation Act and, as Senator Siddons said, it does not contain those provisions concerning the composition of the Investment Trust which we opposed when the legislation came to the Senate previously. On the question of retrospectivity, which is dealt with in clause 6 of the Bill, the Australian Democrats, through Senator Siddons, once again have demonstrated a very flexible approach to matters of principle-`flexible' being a polite word--

TALK.START.PARA: —Well within the Standing Orders, too.

—As my cousin says, well within the Standing Orders. It is flexible enough that when they do deals with the Government they do not care about retrospectivity, but when they seek not to do a deal with the Government they do.
—Come on! I was explaining that it was a technicality.

—Senator Siddons may regard it as a technicality, but I presume that he has not read the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills on this matter. If he has not, I suggest that it is extraordinary of him to get up in this place and not mention the detailed report on this issue and make a debating point that is not based on fact. It may well be that he is too busy attending meetings of his company to take much notice of the business of the Senate, but it seems to me to be extraordinary that he should come into this debate and not even mention, when dealing with the question of retrospectivity, a report by a Senate Committee-I am glad to see another member of that Committee present, Senator Cooney-which dealt with this issue. If only to inform the Australian Democrats, apart from the people of Australia, I think that it is important to refer to elements of the report. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 16 of the Superannuation Act requires the Commissioner to issue a benefit classification certificate in respect of an eligible employee if, following a medical examination, the Commissioner is of the opinion that the employee `is not likely', by reason of a physical or mental condition, to continue to be an eligible employee until retiring age. Where a benefit classification certificate is in force in respect of a person the person may not be entitled to the full rate of invalidity benefit if the person retires on the grounds of invalidity and the Commissioner is of opinion that the incapacity which was the ground for retirement was caused, or was substantially contributed to, by a physical or mental condition specified in the benefit classification certificate. Clause 6 would alter the test in section 16 so that the Commissioner would be required to issue a benefit classification certificate if, in the opinion of the Commissioner, `there is a real risk' that the person in question will not continue to be an eligible employee until retiring age. By virtue of sub-clause 2 (1) this change will be deemed to have had effect from the commencement of the Act on 1 July 1976.
Senator Siddons cannot find that to be a retrospective element, which strikes me as extraordinary. The year 1976 is, for Senator Siddons's benefit, quite some years ago. The Committee further said:

Sub-clause 6 (2) will preserve the effect of decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal with respect to the issue of benefit classification certificates made before the day on which the amending bill receives the Royal Assent.
That is true. The report continues:

The reasons for this retrospectivity are fully set out in the Explanatory Memorandum. Briefly, the Commissioner has always interpreted the `is not likely' test in section 16 as meaning that `there is a real risk' that the person will not continue to be an eligible employee until retiring age. In 1985, however, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal held in Re Bewley that the correct test was whether it was not `more probable than not' that the person would not continue to be an eligible employee until retiring age. The Explanatory Memorandum indicates that the new test is considered much more severe than is appropriate for the issue of benefit classification certificates and that it would render section 16 `almost unworkable'. Nevertheless the effect of the amendments is to change the law as determined by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal with retrospective effect, thus disadvantaging contributors in respect of who a benefit classification certificate has been issued since the inception of the scheme.
Surely Senator Siddons cannot disagree with that. The report continues:
Accordingly the Committee draws the clause to the attention of Senators in that it may be considered by reason of its retrospective effect to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.
It is for that specific reason that we are opposing it, and we are also seeking an act of grace payment to Mr Bewley, if this goes through.

The other point I want to make about delegation is that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee also is uneasy about clause 19, which, by the way, is in the same form as clause 17 of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 to which the Committee drew attention in its fourth report of 1985. The Committee states:
The clause would insert a new section 39 empowering the principal member to delegate all or any of the principal member's powers under the Act (other than the power of delegation) to `a person'.
That can be any person, by the look of that legislation. It continues:
In its comment on clause 17 the Committee expressed concern that the new section 39 imposed no limitation, and gave no guidance, as to the attributes of the person to whom a delegation might be made.
This appears to be particularly bad law-making, in my view, and certainly in the view of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be Abe Saffron.
—It could be, as my cousin says, people of all sorts of repute. The Committee states:

SPEECH.PARA: In its seventh report in 1985 the Committee recorded a response from the Minister for Finance undertaking to consider the comments made by the Committee in the context of an examination of all of the delegation provisions in the Superannuation Act 1976 with any necessary amendments being made when the Act was next amended. The Committee assumes that this examination of delegation provisions has not yet been completed. However it reaffirms its concern in relation to clause 19. The Committee suggests that it may be appropriate in this case, for example, to restrict the scope of delegation to another member of the Trust or an officer or employee of the Trust as was done in the not dissimilar case of sub-section 90 (2) of the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985.

There are the two specific concerns raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. But I am also concerned about a matter of principle relating to the propriety of a Minister of the Crown heavying administrative appeals tribunals or any other quasi-judicial body by referring to their decisions as capricious, irresponsible or in other terms that he has used in some other cases. I wish to deal with both matters.

The Minister for Finance is following a procedure which appears to be normal in the State of New South Wales of giving instructions, either covertly or overtly, to courts of law or quasi-judicial bodies. Apparently, this principle is extending beyond the State of New South Wales, where I hope that it will be ending with the change of government there, but I suggest that it is not a course of action that should proceed. When commenting on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal's decision on Bewley, the Minister for Finance said, in response to the remarks of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, the following: That `it would be quite wrong in principle' if contributors currently subject to benefit classification certificates were now able to take advantage of the alternative and unintended interpretation of the relevant provision to have their benefit classification certificates cancelled, and he says that that is an unintended interpretation. The Minister said:
The application of the test as interpreted by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in Re Bewley would have serious cost implications.
At the end of his response the Minister added the following postscript:

As I have already stated in the Senate I believe it is essential that capricious and irresponsible decisions by quasi-judicial bodies be overturned by the Parliament. As a prime example of internally illogical and externally contradictory decisions by such bodies, I enclose summaries of two recent Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions.

The decisions that the Minister attached at that point were those in Kingston and Kennison. The Minister's handwritten note on the summary of the Kennison case indicates that he considered the decision to be `180 degrees' from that in Kingston, seemingly because in Kingston the Administrative Appeals Tribunal found that the lack of any sexual or romantic element in the relationship of the two persons living together meant that there was not a quasi-marriage relationship, whereas in Kennison, while there was no evidence of a sexual relationship between the two persons, the AAT found that the two persons were living together as man and wife. In Kingston the applicant was thus able to obtain the aged pension at the higher unmarried rate whereas in Kennison the applicant was held to be entitled to receive additional unemployment benefit in respect of his dependent spouse.

It seems to me-certainly, according to advice that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has received-that the first point that should be made is that both purport to be decisions on the relevant factors before the Tribunal rather than, as in Bewley, turning on the interpretation of the relevant statutory provision. In other words, it appears that the Minister seems to have strayed slightly from reality when pointing to these two cases. The fact that each case was decided on the relevant facts may go some way to explaining why the Department did not appeal against the decision in either case. Of course, the Minister did not mention that at the time. For the Department to have appealed it would have been necessary to allege an error of law, and not merely that the AAT drew the wrong inference from the facts.

The summary of Kingston which the Minister attached to his letter is accurate as far as it goes. It was common ground that the applicant and Mrs N had been living together on a bona fide domestic basis at all relevant times. The only question for the Tribunal was whether he was living with her as her husband. If not, he was entitled to obtain the aged pension at the unmarried rate. According to Mr Kingston, there had never been sexual relations between the two parties. The Department's social workers who had intervened in both cases accepted this evidence. That, of course, also was excluded from the Minister's statement, which simply referred to cohabiting. As set out in the summary the Department advanced three pieces of evidence in support of its view that the two persons were living together as man and wife. The Deputy President found that statements made by the applicant in 1970 to this effect did not have the same weight as the applicant's sworn evidence before the Tribunal. He found that no adverse inference could be drawn from the applicant's failure to comment on letters received from the Department in 1975 which referred to Mrs N as his spouse. With regard to the fact that in 1969 he had claimed the dependent spouse rebate in respect of Mrs N, Mr Kingston stated that in other years he had claimed the housekeeper rebate. It was conceded that the amounts involved were roughly the same and the Deputy President concluded that: `At worst it was an attempt to deceive the Taxation Department'. The Deputy President then concluded:

Whilst there may well be many `housekeeping' contracts or arrangements which develop into a man and wife relationship it certainly does not follow that all such arrangements acquire that quality merely by reason of their comparative permanence or the strength of the friendships developed. Before such a relationship is converted there must be, as the Tribunal recently observed, some kind of `spark to ignite the tinder of cohabitation into the fire of a quasi marriage relationship'.

That might sound a bit exotic, particularly in regard to people aged 80 years and 76 years. Perhaps the spark would be on very dry tinder. The question here was simply one of a determination of matters of fact. The Deputy President continued:

In the present case an arrangement which began as one of financial convenience has now developed into an arrangement for mutual support to the best of the physical and financial abilities of each party, but there is no evidence to justify a conclusion that there is a quasi marriage relationship.

The view, which the Minister said represented a 180-degree turn by the AAT in the case of Kennison, seems once again to depend simply on matters of fact. Once again, I repeat, there was no appeal by the Department. The summary of the Kennison case which the Minister attached to his letter is equally accurate, but only so far as it goes. Kennison had lived with Miss C from 25 December 1982 to 30 August 1983. He was paid additional benefit in respect of Miss C between 25 December 1982 and 22 May 1983 on the basis that she was a dependent female being a woman living with a man as his wife on a bona fide domestic basis although not legally married to him. The Department of Social Security cancelled the additional benefit on 1 June 1983 with effect from 23 May, having received legal advice that, as Miss C was under the age of consent under the South Australian law, Mr Kennison could not profit from what would be an illegal act. Miss C turned 17 years on 3 August 1983 and the additional benefit was restored from that date. However, the relationship broke up on 30 August 1983.

At issue was Mr Kennison's entitlement to receive additional benefit in respect of Miss C as his de facto spouse during the period when she was under the legal age of consent under the relevant State law. The Department argued that because she was under the age of consent Miss C should not be regarded as a `woman'-she was a non-woman-or, alternatively, that Mr Kennison should not be allowed to profit from his illegal acts. The Tribunal considered that no special meaning attached to the word `woman' as used in the Social Security Act 1947. Where the legislature had wished benefits to be restricted to persons of specified age it had said so in other cases, for example, by setting 16 years of age as the minimum for the receipt of unemployment benefits. The requirement, since changed, that a woman be living with a man as his wife was relevant at that time since under the Commonwealth Marriage Act 1961 a woman who has attained the age of 14 years may marry.

While the Secretary to the Department, in exercising his powers and discretions under the Act, should have due regard to public policy as set out in Commonwealth, State or Territory laws and should not be seen to authorise acts contrary to public policy, there was no evidence of any relevant public policy as to the payment of benefits to a person living in a bona fide domestic relationship with a person under the age of consent. There was no evidence before the Tribunal. The Tribunal had no jurisdiction to make a finding beyond reasonable doubt that an offence against State criminal law had been committed, nor could it circumvent the criminal standard of proof by reliance on the presumption that persons should not be allowed to profit from their illegal acts. If the Minister says that it was proper that they should not get this benefit because of an illegal act, surely it is essential to establish that the illegal act took place. As I said, there was no evidence-no criminal standard of proof-and as a result the Department did not appeal.

If, in a given case, a court of competent jurisdiction had found an offence proved, that would, of course, have been a relevant consideration. However, on the facts before the Tribunal in the instant case it was irrelevant that an offence of unlawful sexual intercourse might have been committed. The Tribunal endorsed the statement of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal which stated:

It is well to remember that the purpose of the Act is to relieve poverty and hardship amongst citizens of the Commonwealth. It is not intended as an instrument for enquiring into deviant social behaviour and assigning penalties and rewards.

Although the Tribunal had no direct evidence before it as to the existence of a sexual relationship between Mr Kennison and Miss C it concluded that there was sufficient evidence before it, in particular common experience of the behaviour of teenage people, the accommodation the couple had occupied during their relationship-a one-bedroom flat, a caravan, then another one-bedroom flat-and their mutually dependent financial and social arrangements, to be able to establish on the balance of probabilities that the applicant and Miss C had been living together as unmarried husband and wife as required under the Act.

The reason I have stated all that is to make quite clear that there does not appear to be any contradictory element in the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the matters of Kingston and Kennison. In Kingston the Tribunal found that two elderly people living together for financial and social reasons were not living in a quasi-marriage relationship. On the other hand, in Kennison the Tribunal found that two young people living together were indeed living in a de facto relationship. The possible commission of an offence against State law was a complicating factor in the latter case but the Tribunal had no evidence before it of any finding by any court of competent jurisdiction that such an offence had been committed, nor did it have the jurisdiction itself to make such a finding on the criminal standards of proof. In the absence of such a finding, the Tribunal clearly considered it inappropriate that the young people in question should be punished for the possible breach of law by withholding the additional benefit. To have done otherwise would have been to take into account an irrelevant consideration, a ground for judicial review in itself.

This is the point that I think should be made: An unfortunate tendency is prevalent at the moment for the courts to be criticised for having no sense of financial responsibility. However, it is a function of the courts to interpret the laws made by parliament. They are not required to have regard to the budgetary consequences of their interpretations of the law, nor could they do so without usurping the role of the Executive and the Parliament in this regard. It is always open to the Parliament to do so, as is proposed to be done by the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1986, and to rectify-in this case retrospectively-a defect in the law which has come to light as a result of a court decision. I repeat: It is a defect in the law which has come to light as a result of a court decision. Whether or not this is appropriate in a given case is, of course, a matter for judgment in all the circumstances. I note that Senator Walsh, in his letter to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, stated:

As an indication of the likely costs, it has been estimated that, if no benefit classification certificates had been in force in relation to contributors who retired on invalidity grounds in 1984-85, the capitalised cost of the benefits payable would have increased by $35 million.

This rests on the proposition that the change in interpretation would render the requirement useless, and I think that may be a matter of some disagreement. However, I should mention that in the case of Bewley the effect of which way one looks at questions of whether it is more probable or whether there is a real or remote possibility or a real risk should be pointed out as being most significant. Mr Bewley had a small melanoma or skin cancer removed from his shoulder. In August 1983 he joined the Commonwealth Public Service and was examined by the Commonwealth Medical Officer, who found that he did not meet the general medical standard because of a history of superficial spreading melanoma. It was agreed by specialists called by Mr Bewley and the Commissioner that there was a better than 90 per cent chance that the cancer would not recur. The Commissioner's experts said that of every 100 people who have a tumour such as Mr Bewley's some two to five could be expected to suffer a recurrence in some other part of the body. Therefore, if one took the view that the word `likely' meant more probably than not it was clearly likely that Mr Bewley would remain an eligible employee until retiring age. On the other hand, if one took the view that the word `likely' meant a real or not remote chance or possibility, it was likely that Mr Bewley would not continue to be an eligible employee until retirement age.

In conclusion, clause 6 seeks to change the interpretation by substituting for the `is not likely' test the `there is a real risk' test that the employee will not continue to be an eligible employee until retiring age. Whether or not the latter test is an appropriate one is a question of policy and the Government is quite entitled to do what it likes. However, while recognising-this is in the advice to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee-the Minister's perogative to describe as unintended the interpretation of section 16 adopted regarding Bewley, one may take issue with his description of the decision in that case, by implication, as capricious and irresponsible. I return to the point I made earlier. It is the function of the courts to determine the meaning of the law made in parliament. As Professor Pearce stated at page 185 of his standard work Statutory Interpretation:

It must be remembered that judges are men and not machines. One does not feed the legislation together with the rules of interpretation in at one end and have a `correct' reading of the Act come out the other.

Merely because judges and courts differ in their interpretation of words or because interpretations change over time does not mean that the courts or quasi-judicial tribunals such as the AAT are acting capriciously. I make a request of the Minister when he is dealing, as he quite properly does, with matters of concern to him and where savings might be made. I commend him in his pursuit of saving government money where it is being improperly spent. Certainly among his colleagues he has no peer in the pursuit of waste, and I congratulate him to that extent. However I am concerned that in his enthusiasm he has quite clearly behaved, I think, in an improper way in relation to quasi-judicial tribunals. He is clearly, by his statements, heavying them to make decisions that are favourable to the Government rather than to judge cases on their merits and to judge the facts as they see them. To that extent I suggest to him that in his quite proper pursuit of waste he should cease heavying the judiciary and semi-judicial bodies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Messner raised the matter of Mr Bewley and that he argued that Mr Bewley should be exempt from the scope of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. Mr Bewley is, in fact, exempt from the scope of this legislation. I made this quite clear in my letter to Senator Messner of 5 May, from which I now quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I should point out that there is no benefit classification certificate presently in force in relation to Mr Bewley. Thus, there is no basis for consideration of an act-of-grace payment to Mr Bewley in the event that he should retire on invalidity grounds.

Mr Bewley has been excluded from this legislation, and I thought that statement would have made that perfectly clear. I also stated in that letter that the decision made by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the Bewley case was clearly a reversal of an earlier decision of the AAT, made in 1979 in the Linden case, which had supported the manner in which the Commissioner for Superannuation had applied the provisions. That was also cited in my letter to Senator Messner of 5 May.

If the effect of the AAT decision in the Bewley case were allowed to stand without challenge the 66,000 benefit classification certificates already in existence would be effectively cancelled. Even if some people disagree at the margin with that judgment, they cannot guarantee that future absurd decisions by the AAT or some similar bodies might not extend the degree to which they have already been effectively cancelled by the AAT decision in the Bewley case. It is not a question, as Senator Michael Baume asserts, of my trying to heavy tribunals to make decisions which are favourable to governments. What I am trying to establish with this legislation-I have spelt this out publicly on numerous occasions-is the precedent that when courts and tribunals reverse longstanding applications and interpretations of the law in a way that has serious expenditure consequences for which the courts and tribunals have absolutely no responsibility, the Parliament will accept its responsibility to overturn the decisions of the courts and tribunals. That is precisely what this legislation seeks to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but retrospectively.

—Only in the highly technical sense, and I will come to that in a minute. Senator Baume asked why there was no appeal against two other AAT cases-Kennison and, although I have forgotten the name of the other one, I am familiar with the details. An appeal to the Federal Court of Australia is restricted, as Senator Baume said, to a question of law and not to the `facts' as found by the AAT. Since they are unlikely to have significant flow-on effects, there is also the question of an appeal, which is a very expensive operation for the Government to mount. It is good for the lawyers, of course; they never lose out of these sorts of cases-a few lawyers become even richer than they were. However, given the record of the courts, there is no guarantee that the courts will behave any more sensibly than the AAT did. I have argued publicly and I argue again that the proper response by the legislature to this sort of reversal of long term, long-standing application of the law is for the Parliament to legislate to overturn the decisions of the courts and tribunals, and the financial consequences that go with them.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is retrospective only in the most pedantic technical sense; that is, it has application from 1 July 1976, when the existing Commonwealth superannuation scheme came into operation, as a result of which some 66,000 benefit classification certificates have been issued. All that this legislation will do-I say `will do' because I understand that the Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's proposed amendment-is to continue, with the one-off exception of Bewley, to ensure that the law will continue to be applied in the way in which it has been ever since 1976 and in the way in which the AAT itself in the Linden case in 1979 said it should be. Nobody's expectations will be reduced because of this piece of legislation. It is retrospective only in the highly technical sense. In fact, it continues to apply the law in the way it was intended that the law should be applied and the way it has been applied.

I can understand the difficulty into which the Opposition has got itself over this. It is not really concerned about this proposed amendment becoming operative from 1 July 1976; it is concerned that it will be accused on the outside of having supported the principle of retrospectivity. There we get to the nitty-gritty because it could be argued, at least politically, against the Opposition that if it supports the principle of technical retrospectivity in regard to Government outlays, what is the rationale for its continued opposition to retrospectivity in regard to income tax avoided and evaded? That is the nub of the question. That is what the Opposition is really worried about. It is not worried about 66,000 benefit classification certificate holders; it is worried about establishing a precedent which would make it easier for Governments, either this Government or future governments, to get at income tax which has been evaded or avoided. Let us all recognise this spurious, specious argument for what it is. That is what it is all about.

Unfortunately, in pursuing what I would suggest is a less than laudable objective, the Opposition is lining itself up as an accessory to all those who want declarations of open season for raids on the Treasury by people who are in a position to harvest windfall gains because of some silly ruling by a court or tribunal. Senator Michael Baume said, if I understood him correctly, that for the AAT to have done other than it did in this case and in a couple of other cases to which it referred would be for the AAT to usurp from the Parliament the power to make laws. I do not accept that at all because, first, it is in conflict with previous AAT decisions and, secondly, precedents which have been established and until now accepted have given, I would argue, the courts and quasi-judicial tribunals the power to extend the interpretation of the law beyond what can legitimately be regarded as interpretation and into the province of law-making. I know very well-I will not embarrass members of the Opposition by naming them-that that view is shared entirely by a number of leading people in the Opposition in the Senate, and probably in the Opposition in the House of Representatives as well. If Senator Michael Baume is concerned about what he misconstrues my argument as being-that is, that the courts and tribunals usurp the power of the legislature-he has left his concern a bit late, because it was asserted in the most unequivocal terms by the Privy Council in its judgment in the banking case in 1949 that the Privy Council had the right to do precisely that. The judgment states:
Every case must be judged on its own facts and in its own setting of time and circumstance . . .
forget about the legalistic application of the letter of the law-

and it may be that in regard to some economic activity and at some stage of social development it might be maintained that prohibition with a view to State mono-poly was the only practical and reasonable manner of regulation, and that inter-State trade commerce and intercourse thus prohibited and thus monopolized remained absolutely free.

Leaving aside the piece of blatant doublespeak at the end of that paragraph-that that which is prohibited remains absolutely free-what the Privy Council was asserting was that it arrogates to itself the right to make political decisions about the time and circumstance in which particular pieces of legislation which prohibit certain forms of economic activity are constitutional and when they are not.

It has always amazed me that the Australian electorate at the time accepted without question the assertion by a foreign court that it had the right to usurp the political power of the Australian Parliament, which is what it was doing in that paragraph, and the right to make political decisions. But that is almost ancient history. The fact is that there is nothing new about the intrusion of courts and tribunals into the area of policy-making. That, I would argue, is what the AAT has done in this case and what the Federal Court of Australia and the High Court of Australia have done on a number of other occasions in recent times. This legislation is establishing a precedent that when the courts and tribunals act in that way and in a way which has severe financial consequences, the Parliament will accept its duty to overturn those decisions.

There is a notion that the courts and tribunals are the protectors of the little people. In matters of civil liberties and personal freedom, I certainly agree that the courts and tribunals have a very strong responsibility in that area. When it comes to questions of expenditure, the belief that courts and tribunals protect the personal liberties of people against the actions of a vin-dictive or nascent totalitarian state may have some validity but the reality is that the victims and the winners game is reversed because on matters of expenditure and insofar as these bodies have a propensity to lean towards the individual, they are not in fact protecting the individuals against victimisation by the state. In making awards which are favourable to individuals and in ways which contradict long-standing applications of the law, they are victimising all the other people in the state because the state is no more than the sum of the individuals who are contained within it. Courts and tribunals can blithely go out handing down decisions which have ultimately cost in some cases hundreds of millions of dollars per annum in outlays and for which they have no responsibility. To quantify it in this case-I think it has been mentioned by some of the Opposition speakers-if this legislation is not passed, over the next 10 years it is probable that around an additional $35m a year in current value terms or in capitalised terms will be paid out under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme.

The opposition to the Government's proposals to prevent that comes from the Opposition which incessantly complains about the cost of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme to the taxpayer. But, simultaneously, it proposes a course of action which would add $35m per annum, capitalised cost, to the cost of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme over each of the next 10 years. The reason for that contradiction-I am sure it is not that the Opposition is not capable of recognising that contradiction-is that in a very pedantic, legalistic sense, this legislation is retrospective. The Opposition would be quite happy to support retrospective legislation in this instance, but to do so would expose its unguarded flanks on retrospective legislation with respect to tax evaders and tax avoiders.

I understand that the Democrats are propo-sing to move an amendment to seek to change the method by which the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust is appointed. It is a similar amendment to that which the Democrats moved to a similar piece of legislation late last year. The Government, in the legislation which was rejected last year, proposed both to extend the number of people on the Trust and to change the way in which they were appointed.

Although there were some sort of strange circumstances, the legislation was effectively rejected by the Senate. In this Bill the Government has decided to leave the clause dealing with the composition of the Trust as it is. I will not go into the arguments against the Democrat amendment at this stage, but the Government will not be accepting it.

As I have already indicated, the Opposition has given notice of an amendment to be moved at the Committee stage, the effect of which would be to cancel the 66,000 BCCs already in existence and add a capital cost of about $35m a year for each of the next 10 years to the cost of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. Obviously the Government will not accept that amendment either because to do so would be to overturn-I do not know whether I should say the major purpose; there are a number of other significant amendments proposed in this legislation-from a financial aspect, the major purpose of this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Committee that the Bill be taken as a whole?

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Messner-The Liberal and National parties will be dividing in respect of an amendment to clause 2 and we will be discussing clause 9 in detail.

Senator Siddons-I would just like to mention that the amendments circulated in the name of the Australian Democrats substantially relate to clause 9. I suggest that the first amendment be debated and the consequential amendments left until we ascertain whether the substantive amendment is to be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, sub-clause 2 (1), leave out `Sub-section 4 (1), section 5 and sub-section 6 (1)', insert `Sub-section 4 (1) and section 5'.

The effect of this amendment is to wipe out the retrospective element of the Government's Bill. During the second reading stage we reiterated the points surrounding the case of one Mr Bewley and the action which the Government was taking in order to try to overcome the effects of Mr Bewley's case having been upheld by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. As the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) pointed out during the second reading stage, as a result of this legislation some 66,000 members of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust would lose their rights to have the circumstances that might pertain in their individual cases upheld in the same way as Mr Bewley was able to have the circumstances applied in his favour as a result of the AAT decision. It is, as the Minister has pointed out, a question of retrospectivity.

He does not deny that this is the case, although he seeks to argue that the principle can be watered down in some way. That, of course, is not the view of the Liberal and National parties and we oppose in principle this act of retrospectivity which is incorporated into the Bill.

I would like to mention a few points in regard to that. The Minister went on at some length to argue the correctness of his action in seeking retrospectivity in this case. He referred to the effects on the taxpayer of decisions of this kind which, being applied in one single case, flow over and incorporate principles that are applied in vast numbers of cases and therefore add significantly to the cost to the taxpayer. I can well understand his point. However, surely the point remains that a law can be tested in various ways through our legal system and can be found to be a good law or a bad law, depending upon the circumstances. Consequently, when a decision is made, it is made for the benefit of the people generally. Of course, the rather fine point that the Minister was arguing in relation to Parliament having a power to override any decision of a court is absolutely correct. However, in our view, that power certainly should not be applied retrospectively. Indeed, this legislation seeks to correct an understanding of the law which goes right back to the commencement of the superannuation fund on 1 July 1976. Be it a technical point or otherwise, we cannot see that that is a reasonable proposition. I would like to turn to one or two of the arguments the Minister made in that respect a little later.

Perhaps the point that ought to be made first is that the continual statement from the Minister that an extra cost to the taxpayer of $35m per annum might arise needs to be put to rest. The Minister continually misstates the figures and misrepresents their meaning by referring to what is the capitalised value of the effect of pensions over a considerable period-that is, the estimated life of the recipient or superannuitant while he draws that pension-as compared with the annual cost. So the capitalised cost might amount to $35m but the annual cost may be only a mere fraction of that-maybe $1m or $2m a year. The Minister, by the extension of some rather twisted arithmetic, then seeks to multiply that figure by 10 and conclude that the cost over 10 years will be $350m. Of course, that is plainly wrong. What we are talking about is the capitalised value of the pension over the life of the recipient. Of course, in annual terms the figure would be much less than the amount the Minister cites. Indeed, it is a total misrepresentation of the position to state, as he has done publicly, in Press releases and in this Parliament, that his point is somehow a legitimate one. It is not a valid point at all. The Government should recognise that and take into account the arguments of the Opposition.

I would like to turn to one other point that the Minister made. We also take exception to the line taken by the Minister about the decisions of various arbitral authorities being retrospectively overturned by Parliament and his justification for that. I wonder whether he would apply that logic to the decisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Would he apply it to decisions that are made in cases involving particular groups of workers on questions of anomalies or whatever which then flow on through other arbitral processes to the rest of the community? Would he therefore apply retrospectively the principles of wiping out the flow-on of those wage decisions to other members of the community to whom it was not intended the decisions should flow? Such a decision would introduce a new element into the Government's thinking in terms of industrial relations. I wonder whether it would be serious in applying a principle such as that.

Certainly the Liberal and National parties would like to see more flexibility in the wage system and we believe it is unfair that wage decisions of the various arbitral authorities are made in respect of particular industries in particular circumstances; but to see those decisions flow over into industries whose circumstances are totally different and which have difficulty meeting their obligations under those decisions is a totally different thing. I would be pleased to hear whether the Minister would be prepared to argue that the decisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should be overturned on the basis of the principles he outlined earlier.

The point at issue in this matter is simple. The Government, to its credit, has sought in this legislation to protect Mr Bewley, who is at the centre of the amendment the Government has brought forward. The problem is that it has also added retrospectivity to overcome the point of principle raised by the decision in Mr Bewley's case. That means that all those people who may or may not ever be affected by that decision, who may or may not ever seek in the future to have applied to their own cases that favourable decision in Bewley's case, are being prohibited now by virtue of the Government's amendment from receiving the benefits of that decision.

That is the simple fact, and that is what we oppose. It is purely and simply retrospective legislation, which all parliaments abhor, that takes away benefits that applied under the law to individual persons. That is a principle greater than the one the Minister seeks to argue. He merely seeks to denigrate the point made by the Opposition on the basis that somehow we are seeking to protect tax evaders. That is absolute nonsense. It is nothing to do with taxpayers or taxation legislation at all; this matter is about a benefit that by due process of law has been applied to certain beneficiaries who are members of the Public Service Superannuation Fund but is now to be denied to them by virtue of this legislation. That is the point of principle. We appeal to the Australian Democrats to join with the Liberal and National parties and vote against this legislation to destroy the retrospectivity incorporated in it.

I implore the Minister to consider again the circumstances of Mr Bewley. I do not blame the Minister for using Mr Bewley as a kind of pawn in the battle to seek the passage of this legislation with its retrospectivity provision. The Minister is trying to say to us that if we support this legislation, if we let it go through, Mr Bewley's position will be protected; he forgets about all those other members of the Superannuation Fund who will be affected detrimentally as a result of that decision. That is our concern. I believe that Mr Bewley is big enough to see that the principle is bigger than him personally. It is true that, if the legislation goes through, it will protect Mr Bewley. If, on the other hand, it fails, Mr Bewley will be exposed. There is no guarantee that the condition Mr Bewley suffers from, a melanoma, will ever emerge again as a reason for his early retirement on grounds of invalidity.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it doesn't, it is irrelevant.

—If it does not, it is an irrelevant matter and will not apply. If the Government, under this legislation, feels that it has to appeal to the Federal Court of Australia against the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, that is its own decision, but I believe that in the exact circumstances of Mr Bewley's case, which involve what do appear to be breaches of contract in terms of the conditions of Mr Bewley's employment when he changed over from the Tasmanian Public Service to the Commonwealth Public Service, the Government should give special consideration to his case. In the light of the correspondence the Minister and I have had about this, I note that it is not the Minister's intention to do so. I implore the Minister again to reconsider that so as to give some guarantee, some comfort, to Mr Bewley in a most difficult situation. The decision of the AAT can then be upheld in his case and he can be sure that in the event of his eventually leaving the Public Service he will be protected by act of grace. I see no reason why the Government should not be so magnanimous as to agree to that and to put down in this place a guarantee to that effect. His case is surely a matter for compassion, and such action would not be beyond the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly on matters of principle the Government has a perfect right to appeal to a higher court, but I ask it please to consider the circumstances of Mr Bewley because his is not a clear cut case. It is not the case that Mr Bewley has suddenly popped out of the ground with a claim on the Commonwealth which is not beyond doubt. The fact is that he has been asserting a claim in this matter on the basis of what he believed to have been a legitimate arrangement between the Commonwealth and himself, which was that he would have all the protection of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. In that event I believe the Government should acknowledge that there is a problem, at least half an error, on its side, and should guarantee Mr Bewley's circumstances. Having said that, we can only hope that the Minister does see the light and act compassionately in Mr Bewley's case. I reiterate: The Liberal and National parties will be opposing those references in sub-clause 2 (1) which have the effect of imposing retrospectivity on the beneficiaries of the Superannuation Fund.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition's amendments, for reasons I believe I made clear during the debate on the second reading. We believe that the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill is retrospective in a very technical sense only, and we stick to that belief. There is no doubt that Mr Bewley was wronged in his dealings with the Government regarding his superannuation rights. However, the situation has since been righted by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In addressing Mr Bewley's problem, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal changed the definition of likely future illnesses, used to issue benefit classification certificates. Under this new definition it is virtually impossible for a doctor to issue a benefit classification certificate. If this definition had not been changed back in 1976, many people would have been wronged; but it was changed. The fact of the matter is that nobody-neither Mr Bewley nor anybody else-will be disadvantaged by this legislation. It purely seeks to enshrine in legislation a practice that has existed since 1976.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Liberals' amendment were to pass, people with illnesses likely to recur would be able to join the Public Service and retire on full benefits when those illnesses recurred. I would have thought that, with the Liberals' great talk about cutting waste and trying to reduce Government expenditure, they would not be seeking to move an amendment which would undoubtedly cost the Government enormous revenue. The precise amount is perhaps open to debate but it is beyond debate that it would be an enormous additional cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a question of justice; you don't understand.
—I was accused by Senator Michael Baume of not reading the legislation. I can assure honourable senators that we have read the legislation.
—And the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report?

—We have also read the report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. We have read the correspondence on the Bewley case and we have considered it very carefully. The Democrats can stand here proudly and say that we have a very consistent point of view on retrospective legislation. Of course we considered this legislation very carefully when the accusation was made that it was retrospective. We considered it in great detail and we came to the conclusion, as I have outlined, that it is retrospective purely in a highly technical sense. We believe that the Opposition, which has not been consistent on the question of retrospectivity, is now making great play of this purely for its own political grandstanding. Nobody will be disadvantaged-certainly not Mr Bewley-and we will not support the Liberal amendment.

—I wish to make, very briefly, one little point, and that is that I am concerned that Senator Walsh has said that there is a $35m cost. That cost appears to be based on there being no certificates, if all the outstanding certi-ficates were cancelled, because, as Senator Siddons said, it is virtually impossible to come up with a cost. What concerns me is why we have to assume that a definition change to `more likely than not'-for example, in the case of Bewley, who, as I recall the evidence, was 90 per cent likely not to have a recurrence-would remove certificates for everybody. There is evidence that Bewley was 90 per cent likely not to have a recurrence; but what about those people who would be 40 per cent likely not to have a recurrence? Presumably they would not fall within the new definition. I would like to hear the Minister explain why that change would entirely wipe out all existing certificates and what evidence he has for alleging that when, on the face of it, it seems to me to wipe out only those clearly above 50 per cent likely to have a recurrence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last question, the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office estimate is that 90 per cent of existing benefit classification certificates would be null and void if the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision in the Bewley case were allowed to stand. That is based on the BCC being valid only in circumstances where it was more likely than not that the same infirmity which had been identified at the time people joined the Public Service led to their premature retirement. There is, of course, the other 10 per cent but the AGRBO view is that the cost of reviewing the whole 66,000 in order to identify those 10 per cent would be so great that it would not be worth it. Let us be quite clear: The Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office has spontaneously-that office has not been leaned on by me or by anybody else-estimated that if this legislation is not passed with clauses 2, 5 and 6 intact, the 66,000 existing BCCs will be cancelled. Even if AGRBO decided to try to cull out the 10 per cent which it believes would still be applicable in a Bewley AAT decision situation, that assumes that some future AAT decision will not wipe them out as well. Likewise, although the Opposition's amendment seeks to apply a particular standard of proof or of probability only to new entrants to the Commonwealth Public Service, what is the Opposition going to do if the AAT subsequently brings in another and new interpretation of law that cancels them as well? There is no workable option other than that of establishing the precedent that when courts and tribunals make those sorts of silly decisions, the Parliament will accept its responsibility and overturn them by legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just been advised that this morning the AAT handed down a decision on the Dakin case, which is another BCC case, in which the AAT, with different personnel, I presume, overruled the Bewley decision. So where are we now? We have different groupings of the AAT in different parts of the country making decisions which are contradictory with each other. The Government's Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1986-and with the one exception, I am grateful for the support of the Australian Democrats-puts some certainty back into the law, which is what the Opposition has always said it wants in the law. Instead of taking a punt on what one AAT as constituted may do at one time which is different from what another AAT might do at some other time-we have people making highly subjective judgments about alleged facts, but in a way that nobody can predict with any certainty-with this legislation we will put more certainty into the law as it is recorded, and having established the precedent, if the AAT, the Federal Court of Australia or anybody else undermines it again, one would expect that the Government and the Parliament at the time that that happens will do what it ought to do and legislate to overturn those decisions.

The Opposition amendment is, in fact, retrospective. The Bill is not retrospective in any real sense. The Opposition amendment is retrospective because, if it was accepted, the 66,000 people who already hold BCCs, or that minority proportion of them who might ultimately be affected by a BCC, would be given a retrospective gain-something to which they did not believe they were entitled and something to which they would have absolutely no reason to believe they were entitled. The Government Bill seeks to preserve the status quo.

Cutting through all the specious arguments the Opposition has put up, as I have already said, its real worry about this provision has nothing to do with the Commonwealth superannuation scheme or benefits classification certificates; it is that the Opposition would be voting for legislation which, in the pedantic lawyer's sense, was retrospective; and having done that, the Opposition exposes its flanks on the question of retrospective tax legislation. I note for the record that despite Senator Messner's professed and absolute objection in principle to retrospectivity, in 1982 he voted for retrospective tax legislation. I have not had time to look up what Senator Michael Baume did, but I know that Senator Messner did that, as, of course, a majority of the members of the then Liberal and National Party Government did. They voted for retrospective legislation in 1982, so for whatever the principle is worth-in my view it is a very dubious principle-it is one that is applied in a highly selective manner.

On the question of costing, Senator Messner said that if the Opposition amendment was accepted, the additional payout from the CSS in the 1986-87 Budget might only be $2m or $3m. That is probably true. I have not had an estimate on that. It may even be less than that, but he is arguing that that is all one should count. He is arguing that a contingent and accruing liability should be ignored. I must say that I find it extraordinary that somebody who I understand practised as an accountant should put an argument that a contingent and accruing liability ought to be ignored. If we want to follow Senator Messner's line of reasoning down the years, although it may be only $1m in the first year-I do not have an accurate figure for that-one thing on which we can be certain is that at some time in the future the annual cost will be greatly in excess of $35m in 1986 value dollars. I do not know what it would amount to, but my hunch is that it would amount to something more than $100m annual cost at some time down the track. I have not fiddled the figures or anything like that. In a way that is most comprehensible I have tried to present just what the cost of the Opposition amendment would be. It is the cost in the particular year, plus the accruing contingent liability, brought back to a capitalised basis. That cost is around $35m in each of the next 10 years, so it is something like $350m plus. That is what the Opposition amendment seeks to impose upon the taxpayers-something more than an additional $350m cost on the superannuation scheme.

Senator Messner tries to present this dispute as if it were only a question of benefits. Certainly, if his amendment prevails some people will get benefits for which they had no expectation prior to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision in the Bewley case and to which they have no entitlement. They will receive those benefits at the expense of everyone else. As Senator Siddons has pointed out, if the AAT-Bewley interpretation were allowed to stand in conflict with the AAT-Dakin and the AAT- Linden cases, anyone who had any sort of physical infirmity which was likely to or could induce a premature retirement would be crazy not to try to get into the Commonwealth Public Service. In that way, through the windfall provisions of the invalidity retirement rules, such a person would gain a pension which could be anything up to five or six times the normal social security invalid pension. I would have thought that the Opposition would not want that to happen, but that is one of the likely effects of the proposed amendment, if it were carred.
I referred to the Dakin case earlier and to back up what I said I quote from page 34 of the decision:

In the result and with due respect to those who have taken that view, we find ourselves unable to agree with the interpretation of sub-section 16 (4) adopted by the Tribunal in Re Bewley and the Commissioner for Superannuation.

The members of that Tribunal, a section of the report of which I have just quoted, were, for the record, Mr Justice Neaves, Mr E. Smith, senior member, and Dr D. B. Travers. Thus, we have different components of the AAT running around all over the place producing contradictory decisions. This legislation removes that uncertainty and I commend it to all honourable senators who are not so frightened of exposing themselves to charges of inconsistency with respect to tax legislation which was retrospective.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Messner's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 9 (Membership of Trust).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 6, paragraphs 9 (a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f) and (g), lines 23 to 40, leave out the paragraphs, insert the following paragraphs:
`(a) by omitting sub-section (1) and substituting the following sub-section:
`(1) The Trust shall consist of 5 members, as follows:
(a) a full-time principal member nominated by the Minister;
(b) a full-time member nominated, in accordance with sub-section (5), by the Australian Council of Trade Unions;
(c) 3 part-time members elected, in accordance with the regulations, by all eligible employees by secret ballot conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission.

`(1a) The regulations made for the purpose of paragraph (1) (c) shall prescribe for elections held under that paragraph a system of election which is, as nearly as practicable, the same as the Hare-Clark proportional representation system set out in Schedule 4 of the Electoral Act 1907 of Tasmania.';
(b) by omitting sub-sections (3), (4), (5) and (6) and substituting the following sub-sections:
`(3) The members nominated under paragraphs 1 (a) and (b) shall be persons with knowledge and expertise in finance, industrial relations, superannuation and investment.
`(4) The members elected under paragraph (1) (c)-
(a) shall be nominated by no less than 200 eligible employees; and
(b) shall provide, at the time of their nomination, a written statement of their knowledge and expertise in the matters referred to in sub-section (3).

`(5) The Australian Council of Trade Unions shall not nominate a person for appointment under sub-section (1) unless the Australian Council of Trade Unions has consulted the relevant industrial organizations in relation to the nomination.
`(6) Each member of the Trust shall hold office for 5 years.'';'.

There are some consequential amendments which I will not move until I find out what support we have for this substantive amendment. This amendment relates to the appointment of trustees to the Board of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. It is, in principle, the same as the amendment that we moved late last year. We maintain our position that there is an overwhelming argument for giving the contributors representation on the board of trustees. We believe that the arguments for doing so are overwhelming. The superannuation funds are totally made up of contributors' payments-the Government puts in no money at all-yet the contributors have no say as to who appoints the trustees, who in turn will have the responsibility for investing those enormous sums.

Last year, when we moved this amendment, we had agreement from three public servants' unions, but the Government refused to countenance our idea. It did so, presumably, on the grounds that it considers that employees cannot be responsible or are not responsible enough to make judgments as to who should be elected to control their funds. We believe that this is a fundamental denial of the rights of individuals and of the Government's declared policy of consensus and listening to other people's points of view. Individuals do have a point of view. They should be allowed to exercise a direct vote on this very important issue. The amendment simply proposes:
`(1) The Trust shall consist of 5 members, as follows:
(a) a full-time principal member nominated by the Minister;
(b) a full-time member nominated, in accordance with sub-section (5), by the Australian Council of Trade Unions;
(c) 3 part-time members elected, in accordance with the regulations, by all eligible employees by secret ballot conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission.
What could be more straightforward than that? Our amendment goes on to say:
`(1a) The regulations made for the purpose of paragraph (1) (c)-
That is the preceding paragraph-

shall prescribe for elections held under that paragraph a system of election which is, as nearly as practicable, the same as the Hare-Clark proportional representation system set out in Schedule 4 of the Electoral Act 1907 of Tasmania.';
The amendment continues:
``(3) The members nominated under paragraphs 1 (a) and (b) shall be persons with knowledge and expertise in finance, industrial relations, superannuation and investment.
That is a very necessary requirement. We further say:
``(4) The members elected under paragraph (1) (c)-
(a) shall be nominated by no less than 200 eligible employees . . .

That is a very important stipulation, because it is necessary that those nominating do have grass roots support. We do not want an election to be conducted wherein any individual can offer himself or herself for election. Our amendment continues:
(b) shall provide, at the time of their nomination, a written statement of their knowledge and expertise in the matters referred to in sub-section (3).

We believe that members should have knowledge of financial matters, investment procedures, et cetera. On the basis of whatever criteria one likes to apply to this amendment, it seems to the Democrats to be fair on every possible ground. We are unhappy with this legislation. As I said earlier, we are unhappy that the Government, which contributes nothing at all to the superannuation funds, should have the right under the legislation as it now stands to appoint the trustees. That is patently unfair. It is not as it should be. We are comforted nevertheless, because although the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has not referred to the matter in this debate-I hope that he will address it to some degree-we understand that the Government intends to introduce amending legislation when it has decided its overall attitude to the election of trustees to the superannuation funds and that it will apply its principles to the legislation. It is essentially on that understanding that we support the legislation in its entirety, but we do commend this amendment to the Opposition and to the Government as being fair in every way and as having the support of the trade union movement and the contributors. We can see no reason at all why the Government should not support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support the amendment to clause 9 moved by the Australian Democrats. We debated the point in some part during the second reading debate. I made it clear that we regarded the Democrats' amendment as being tantamount to handing over control to the trade unions in the same way that the Government has chosen under the legislation as it originally stood before it was defeated in November of last year. For that reason, we will not now support the amendment, which is similar to that proposed by the Democrats at that time.
—You do not trust people to exercise a vote responsibly.
—I do not want to take up the time of the Committee to reargue the case. I think the honourable senator understands the reason why we have taken our position.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to clause 9, I would like to hear the views of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) on the situation that will arise by virtue of the inclusion in the Bill of paragraph (e) of clause 9, which seeks to omit sub-section (5) of the principal Act. The principal Act speaks of the appointments of persons as members of a trust. There is a requirement that the Governor-General, who makes those appointments, shall ensure that, as far as is practicable, a person is not appointed unless he has had appropriate experience in matters relating to the investment of moneys or otherwise in matters relating to the management of moneys.

This Bill proposes that that provision be deleted. I find that extraordinary in light of the fact that the Government first of all sought to transfer the power of control of the funds into the hands of people who did not have those skills and, having been defeated on that matter, it has resumed its original position as regards appointments but it proposes to remove the requirement on the Governor-General to choose people for those positions on the board of trustees who have skills in management of money. I do not understand that proposal. I do not think the Minister has explained it elsewhere. Unless there are other references to it in the legislation, I fail to understand why the Government has moved in this way, since I am sure that it has views similar to our own, that people with skills in the management area ought to be chosen to serve as the overall trustees of the Superannuation Fund. Perhaps the Minister can demonstrate whether our understanding of the amendment is incorrect. As it reads to me, it seems that, incredibly, it is proposed to wipe out the reference to the need to have people appointed to the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust who have skills in the investment and management of huge sums of money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply to Senator Messner's remarks first. It is, I concede, a matter of judgment, but the Government's view was that section 30 (5) was a bit too restricted and limiting. Obviously, some expertise is an important consideration and I will certainly take it into account in any appointments that I make to the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. But the Government's view was that, particularly when there were only three members, as will continue to be the case if the Australian Democrats' amendment is not carried, it was too restrictive to have something as tight as that in the legislation. However, I accept the validity of the argument and it is something that I will take into consideration. I just note for the record that the qualifications for administrators of superannuation schemes are generally not expressed in trust deeds or anything like trust deeds. Although it is probably the custom to have people with some expertise in the trustee positions, it is by no means mandatory-indeed, it is rarely mandatory in the trust deeds for private sector schemes-for that to be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to Senator Siddons's amendment, Senator Messner says that this view has been argued before, but I would like to go through the points very briefly again. What he has proposed is superficially attractive-I concede that-but the less superficial one becomes in examining it, I suggest the less attractive it becomes. Conducting an election for the members or trustees of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust is very different from conducting a national election or a ballot of members in any geographically compact group. It would be a nation-wide election, for which the candidates would be unknown as individuals to a very large number of Fund contributors. I think this is the crucial difference between such an election and parliamentary elections, as almost everybody who is elected to the national parliament is aligned to a party. Even if the individual is not known, the electors know that candidates are aligned to a particular party and they have some knowledge of the general attitudes and policies of the parties anyway, whereas in this case it is unlikely that that sort of party political situation and the knowledge which goes with it, which is vital to a nation-wide election, would apply.

I concede that the Democrats' proposal modifies the conditions which applied when rank and file elections were held prior to 1974 in that it stipulates that it would require 200 members contributing to the Fund, instead of 20, the figure that prevailed before, to sign a nomination form. That certainly is likely to produce ballots in which there are fewer candidates, but it provides no guarantee that there will not be very large numbers of candidates. In the last ballot there were some 28 candidates, only about 40 per cent of the membership voted and, as is usual, the positions on the ballot papers were determined by draw. A former member of the Trust who had a good deal of financial expertise and so on received 15,000 primary votes, but he was at the bottom of the ballot paper and did not get elected, whereas the person whose name was at the top of the ballot paper and who lacked any financial expertise received 12,000 votes and ultimately was elected. Under those circumstances it became more of a lottery than an election. For that reason, the Government will not accept the amendment.

It is correct, as Senator Siddons said, that the Public Service and the Public Service unions-certainly the Public Service unions-agreed to that amendment, but that needs to be qualified because it was not the preferred choice of the Public Service unions; it was something which they were willing to trade off, for want of a better expression, in return for some of the other amendments in last year's Bills which they were positively in favour of.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response of the Minister for Finance to my question about the deletion of sub-section (5) of section 30 of the original Act does not in my opinion answer the point. However, we will not be taking the matter to a division.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, left for Geneva, the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada on 6 June. He will return on 23 June. In his absence, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hurford, is Acting Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Special Minister of State, Mr Young, left Australia on 8 June for Europe, Japan, China and Hong Kong and will return on 6 July. During his absence, the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, will be Acting Special Minister of State. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, left Australia on 7 June for Thailand, Cyprus, Greece, Turkey and the Philippines. He will return on 30 June. During his absence, Senator Evans will be the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer and Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to remarks by Mr Simon Crean published yesterday and again today which I quote in part:

QUESTION.PARA: I accept a reality that further discounting cannot be delivered by the trade union movement.

I ask the Minister: Now that Mr Crean has finally and firmly closed the door on any prospect of union agreement to discounting at the next national wage case, does the Minister agree that the Government's hands are tied and that it will be unable to achieve moderation of wage increases to allow for the effects of the continuing devaluation of the Australian currency? If the Minister does not agree with that--

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Apparently the Leader of the Government does not agree, as he has just said no. If the Minister does not agree, what courses of action are open to the Government to achieve the moderation of wage increases which everyone but the Australian Council of Trade Unions agrees is necessary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not know Mr Crean had said that. It is a rather pessimistic view. It is a bit premature to be saying that that is the case. The Government's policy, which has been spelt out on many occasions by me and a number of other people with some responsibility in the area, is that we have to have an appropriate mix on the outlays side, on the wages side and on the revenue side. One of the great difficulties we confront is that, when we try to do something on the outlays side, frequently the Opposition sabotages it in the Senate. The Opposition endlessly goes around the country saying that expenditure has to be cut. Apart from a handful of trivial items in the stunts of the Waste Watch Committee, the Opposition has not nominated any area where there can be significant cuts in expenditure. On the contrary, the Leader of the Opposition runs around the country irresponsibly promising an extra $2 billion in outlays and an extra $5 billion added to the deficit through forgone revenue.

ANSWER.PARA: So, if the Opposition were in government it would finish up with a deficit of about $12 billion-even bigger as a proportion of gross domestic product than the prospective deficit which Mr Howard left behind in 1983 when he was ignominiously booted out of office. Certainly if a government displayed that degree of fiscal irresponsibility, that is, bringing in a Budget deficit under present circumstances of between 5 and 6 per cent of GDP, we would have runaway inflation and runaway interest rates and it would be necessary to transfer the whole burden on to the wages side and get a level of discounting that nobody could hope to deliver.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. There is not time to debate the Minister's answer to the question. I am sorry that he did not refer to my Press release of yesterday when I pointed out some areas where the Government might cut expenditure and areas where it should not cut expenditure. I ask the Minister: Is it the policy of this Government that there needs to be further moderation of wage increases to take into account the current economic circumstances? If that is the policy of the Government, how does it intend to go about getting further moderation of wage increases in light of the statements made by Mr Crean?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The objective facts are that changes in Australia's terms of trade over the last 15 months have wiped more than $6 billion off national income. It follows axiomatically that, unless there is to be an increase in overseas borrowings of that size, average living standards or capital expenditures have to fall, the latter of which would not be wise. So, average living standards have to fall. Precisely where those standards fall is a matter, I suppose, for some debate and dispute. But I assert that it is absolutely unrealistic to expect anybody in the work force, and particularly those at the lower end of the pay scale, to accept further cuts in their real wages at the same time as the people for whom the Opposition speaks in this place continue to rip off the tax system by funding their self-indulgences in a tax deductible way. A package has to be put together which shows some equality of sacrifice and spreads the burden equitably across all sections of the community.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the reference by Senator Chaney at the start of his supplementary question to the Press statement he put out yesterday, I am afraid that I have not seen it. I will certainly scrutinise it very carefully. In particular, I will be looking to see which items of the $500m shopping list of political goodies which the National Party of Australia is running around promising the farmers Senator Chaney has repudiated, which of the items on that list he has walked away from. I suspect that I will be disappointed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs: Has his attention been drawn to a recent report that states: `Waldheim's victory sparks Israeli outrage'? The report further states that the election of Dr Waldheim, former Secretary-General of the United Nations, as President of Austria has caused a wave of indignation across Europe and that Israel has recalled its Ambassador from Austria. In light of these reports, what information is available to the Australian Government? Depending on the information available, is any action pending by the Government in light of the reaction from countries around the world to the alleged claims that Dr Waldheim was involved in criminal wartime atrocities while he was a member of the German Army during World War II?

—As honourable senators will know, the former United Nations Secretary-General, Dr Kurt Waldheim, was elected to the presidency of Austria, with which country Australia has warm and friendly relations, by an absolute majority of 53.9 per cent in the 8 June presidential election run-off. A total of 87.3 per cent of eligible voters cast a vote in what was clearly a democratically held election. The inauguration is expected to be held early in July. The Government is aware of the reports mentioned in Senator Jones's question. The allegations on which they are based have not yet, however, been tested under any legal process.
