At this point the Australian Government has no further information regarding the allegations to which the honourable senator refers. Accordingly, we have no further comment to make on the allegations in question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister would be aware of the industrial problems in Broken Hill which have already resulted in the standing down of 1,100 workers and the possibility of an entire shutdown of the whole mining industry in that city. In view of the possible consequences of this dispute to other centres, such as Port Pirie, and an estimated loss of $300m to export earnings, and in light of the representations made to the Government by the Federal member for Riverina-Darling, Mr Hicks, and the Barrier Industrial Council, what action is the Government taking to bring about a resolution of the conflict?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered a question about Broken Hill very similar to this recently. I put the view then, which I repeat now, that it is very silly of the unions concerned to endanger their livelihood and employment and the national interest to the extent that they have. I do not know what specific measures Mr Willis, who has left the country now, had in the pipeline before he left. I will try to find out.

ANSWER.PARA: May I give a bit of gratuitous advice to Senator Brownhill as well and say that anything Mr Willis might want to do with the unions at Broken Hill and any form of suasion he wants to use on the miners at Broken Hill are certainly not helped by the fact that the ratbag right leadership of the National Farmers Federation is getting around advocating breaking the law. I would like to see Senator Brownhill's Party express a view publicly on whether it is dissociating itself from the views being put forward in the advocacy of the ratbag right leadership of the National Farmers Federation and, in particular, its President.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware that the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Robin Gray, still believes that Tasmania has a right to continued special assistance from the Federal Government? Is he aware that Mr Gray came to Canberra on Friday to hand the Federal Government a specially commissioned report arguing against possible Commonwealth funding cuts in his State? Can the Minister see any conflict between Mr Gray coming to Canberra with his hand out and the Liberal Party's call for cuts in government spending?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the conflict is so self-evident that it needs no further elaboration from me, but I would like to know how the Liberal Party reconciles the conflict. I did hear Mr Gray on AM this morning going through his usual complaining routine and trying to con the Tasmanian electorate into believing that all the problems Tasmania has are made in Canberra, which is, of course, nonsense and always has been. To refute it I just want to put a few facts on the record. In 1985-86, total per capita grants to Tasmania are $2,034 compared to the six-State average of $1,374. That is $660 more per capita that Tasmania has received from the Commonwealth Government in this financial year than the six States on average. If Mr Gray cannot keep house and do his financial housekeeping in a way that enables him to live comfortably within that total, I suggest that is his fault and not the fault of the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: One does not have to look very far before one finds one of the major reasons why Mr Gray might have some trouble living within that extremely generous allowance he gets from the Commonwealth Government. As is fairly well known, wage costs comprise between 70 and 80 per cent of State government total expenditure. Wage costs are determined by the level of wages and the number of State government employees. When we look at the number of employees employed by the various State governments, we find that almost 20 per cent of the New South Wales work force is employed by the State Government and its agencies. I dare say that if that figure were quoted in isolation most of the people across the aisle in the Opposition would say that that is an extravagantly high level of State government employment. When we look at Tasmania, we find that 28.3 per cent of the work force is in State government employment, compared to the New South Wales figure of less than 20 per cent. That figure of 28.3 per cent is substantially higher than any other State. That is obviously a major reason why the Tasmanian Government consumes money at a greater per capita rate than any other State.

A further qualification is that Tasmania alone, with the limited exception of South Australia, does not have to carry its railway workers on its employment figures. Very foolishly, in my opinion-it is a piece of ancient history-in 1975 the Commonwealth Government took over the Tasmanian railways, and so the Tasmanian railway workers are now recorded as employees of a Commonwealth authority, whereas in any other State, with the limited exception of South Australia, those same people have been recorded as State government employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Anyone would know that a State with a small population must take more public servants per head of population--
—Order! There is no point of order.

—If an adjustment were made for the railway work force we would find that there would be about an extra one per cent of the total work force employed by the State Government. The fiscal burden of the Tasmanian railway system is also accepted by the Commonwealth, whereas in any other State, again with the limited exception of South Australia, it is absorbed within the State Government Budget. The Commonwealth Government funds the operating deficit of the Tasmanian railway system, which puts Tasmania at a significant fiscal advantage compared to any other State. If Mr Gray cannot live with an allocation of Commonwealth funding of $660 per capita above the national average, I suggest that there is something wrong with his fiscal housekeeping.

ANSWER.PARA: Moreover, as a matter for the States generally, the last Premiers Conference policy of increasing in real terms the general purpose payment to the States by 2 per cent has been substantially enhanced by the 2 per cent wage discount which has already happened since that period and the possibility of an additional wage discount. The States' income is tied to the consumer price index, whereas between 70 per cent and 80 per cent of their outlays-that is their wages bill-is tied to the CPI, discounted already by 2 per cent and possibly discounted by something more. Frankly, I was not at all impressed by Mr Gray's complaining this morning. I hope that the Treasurer is similarly unimpressed next Friday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Science aware that a special meeting of the consultative parties to the Antarctic Treaty was held recently in Hobart to advance the minerals regime to control exploration and exploitation of the mineral resources of Antarctica? At that meeting, it was agreed to proceed rapidly to conclude negotiations on the minerals regime. A completion date for establishing the regime was set for May next year. In view of Australia's declared commitment to ensuring that the Antarctic environment is protected from the danger of extensive damage from mining and oil exploration, what steps is Australia taking to ensure that negotiations for a conservation regime are completed before any mineral exploration or exploitation goes ahead and to ensure that widespread and enforceable monitoring and inspection provisions will be available to monitor any damage caused to the Antarctic environment by mining or oil exploration activities?

—I am aware that, as described by Senator Vigor, a conference of the consultative parties to the Antarctic Treaty in respect of mineral resources took place in Hobart recently. Insofar as the other parts of the honourable senator's question refer to a series of other matters, I am not able to provide him with an answer. I will refer it to the Minister for Science and obtain an answer as soon as possible.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen an article in the Australian Financial Review regarding the Australian Federation of Employers proposal to cut taxes and expenditure to produce a deficit outcome of less than $4 billion? Can the Minister say whether the AFE's package would produce that deficit outcome and can he indicate any other implications of the proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the measures spelt out by the Australian Federation of Employers would not produce the deficit outcome which the Federation set as a target. I notice that the spearhead for the Federation of Employers is one Andrew Hay, a former staffer to the former Treasurer, Mr Lynch, who produced the famous rubbery figures in the 1977 Budget. In Mr Hay's defence I want to put on the record that he, unlike the Leader of the Opposition, has at least had the decency and the intellectual honesty to name a number of specific areas where he believed expenditure should be cut. I suppose he is doing that in his capacity as one of the growing band of extra-parliamentary pretenders for the Liberal Party leadership. The Liberals, on the other hand, just go on telling Australia how they are going to spend money. I refer to an extra $2 billion of it, plus an extra $5 billion in revenue losses because of their tax promises. But the Federation of Employers proposal suggests that the top marginal tax rate should be reduced to 30c in the dollar. On the present tax scales that would have a revenue cost of about $8 billion in a full year. Against that the reformed tax scales the Government will introduce this year will have a revenue cost of just over $5 billion in a full year.

ANSWER.PARA: The areas that the Federation of Employers, or Mr Hay, nominated for expenditure cuts were a lower level of rebate under Medicare, tertiary education fees, changes to the family allowance system, cuts in welfare benefits and the scrapping of employment programs. Of these the only one which he costed was scrapping of employment programs, which is around $650m. On the rest of the items that he has put up, he would pick up a few hundred million dollars but not the thousands of millions he would require, adjustments on the outlay side, to produce the deficit outcome that he or his organisation says is desirable. But what Hay would be looking at, if his extra-parliamentary pretensions to the Liberal Party leadership were to become a reality, as well as his top marginal tax rate of 30 per cent would be no fringe benefits tax, no capital gains tax, and an even larger deficit than the one Mr Howard would deliver, taking his assurances and undertakings at face value.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister, representing the Treasurer. The Minister recently gave some advice on revised taxation measures applicable to the stud livestock industry. Can he further advise whether changes are to be made where this involves such artificial breeding practices as embryo transfers and/or animal leasing only, or right across the entire industry? In view of the time lapse since he gave that previous advice, has there yet developed a written explanation of the changes and, if not, can he urgently arrange for one to be produced?

—By way of clarification, let me state that the changes affect not only artificial breeding but the stud or bloodstock industry in general. The purpose is to include in trading stock values a substantial proportion of the cost of breeding the stock up to the date of birth, which obviously would have to cover the cost of insemination, whether it is done artificially or naturally. The natural cost would include at least the cost of the sire being used. The precise coverage of those costs will be subject of a statement by the Treasurer before the end of this month, following the consultations which he is either having or is about to have with the industry.

—Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware that on 23 February 1984, during an unrelated trial in the Supreme Court of South Australia, the then Mr Justice Wells referred to certain reported statements by Mr Justice Kirby about the alleged conduct of Mr Justice Murphy in relation to the possible appointment of a Mr Jegorow to a public office? Is it a fact that this alleged conduct was a subject of investigation by the first Senate committee which reported favourably on Mr Justice Murphy? Is he aware that the alleged conduct may be the subject of inquiry by the present Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry? Is he also aware that the extreme terms in which Mr Justice Wells spoke about judges expressing opinions on the suitability of proposed appointees to public office disqualify him from sitting in judgment on whether such conduct, if proved, constituted misbehaviour by a judge? Did the Hon. W. A. N. Wells inform the Government that he had made this statement before he indicated that he would be prepared to sit on the Commission, or at any time before the Government nominated him to the House of Representatives and the Senate as a member of the Commission?

—I have had drawn to my attention a few minutes ago a Press report to the effect stated by Senator Coleman that appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser on 24 February 1984, although Mr Justice Wells's comments as there reported are in general terms and, although directed against Mr Justice Kirby, do not squarely or expressly refer to Mr Justice Murphy or the Jegorow matter. I will refer Senator Coleman's question to the Attorney-General for such reply as he might care to make.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women to a question I asked in October last year with respect to the Movement for the Ordination of Women and in particular to her reply, in part, where she said:

QUESTION.PARA: We have always accepted in our system that the internal decisions taken by religious groups are for them to take and it is not the role of government to become involved in those internal decision making processes but rather to protect individuals against any sort of religious discrimination that may arise.

In light of reports in yesterday's Australian of a $5,000 grant from the Office of the Status of Women to the Movement for the Ordination of Women, has the Government now changed its view with respect to interfering in matters of various religious groups? Can the Minister answer the concerns of many Anglicans, both lay and clergy, that the grant represents an attempt to support one view of an internal dispute within the church and as such is interfering in religious matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Vanstone began her question, I tried to recall the occasion last October when she asked me about the position of women seeking ordination in the Anglican Church. As I recall, that question by Senator Vanstone referred to the sex discrimination legislation. It was in answer to her question as to whether we would seek to have the legislation cover the internal decisions of churches that I made my answer. The decision to make available a grant to a group of churchwomen to advance the status of women as they see it within their organisation is a different matter. It simply gives to those churchwomen the opportunity to develop their ideas and to attempt to persuade their fellow churchmen and women of their point of view. It does not in any way determine what the Anglican Church will decide on that issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Through grants made available by the Office of the Status of Women, a number of churchwomen from different churches have received grants, sometimes to pursue social issues, sometimes organisational issues. It seems to me that if we were to accept the implication of Senator Vanstone's question-namely, that because there may be disagreement about a particular issue within a particular church, churchwomen should not be eligible for grants-we would be unable to make any grants to churchwomen. Most churches that practise in Australia have a reasonable degree of democracy and therefore there will be a variety of views about particular matters. I would not like to adopt a position where churchwomen as opposed to women involved in any other sort of organisation in our community were not able to apply for government grants in any circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I accept the Minister's answer, or at least understand it, that a grant is different from a legislative direction, but is the Minister saying that it is acceptable for the Government to support one particular view of a dispute within, in this case, the Anglican Church over a matter pertaining to the rules of that Church as opposed to giving a grant to a section within a church for a policy development that would relate to all members of the community, as in a welfare project that a church may want to put forward of a policy nature? Does she accept that it is acceptable for the Government to support one view with respect to rules governing the running of that religious order or group?

—I have listened carefully to the supplementary question put by Senator Vanstone, and I do not think her description of the Government's intention in making that grant is one I can agree with. It was not the Government's intention to assist one group to operate in a way that was in conflict with other members of that persuasion, but rather the criterion that is used in these grants is that the group that receives the grant needs to be committed to advancing the status of women. It is the view of some women in the Anglican Church and, indeed, women in other churches that their status will be advanced if they can achieve ordination. That achievement has been made in some parts of some churches and not in others. I conclude by saying simply that I think the issue is one of the status of women. It is really not for the Government to judge how a status of women issue can be pursued in a particular church. I hope that the group which has received this grant has advanced the status of women. Even though it may not have achieved its particular aim of ordination, that group may still have raised the issue concerning the status of women in the church and, therefore, our criterion will have been satisfied.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Recently the Minister answered a question in the Senate on safety aspects relating to marathon runners using the Australian national highway system. The Minister would be aware of the tragic loss of two lives in Bass Strait recently when a rower, attempting to cross the Strait, ran into difficulties. Does the Minister agree that Australian authorities are not sufficiently aware of the danger some of these stunts are to the competitors and to the general public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation is the Minister responsible for the Federal Sea Safety and Surveillance in Canberra, I suppose it comes somewhat under his jurisdiction to have an interest in the area of sea rescues and other adventures, expeditions and incidents that take place from time to time. It is pretty clear that in the free society in which we live in Australia there is still a sense of adventure among many people and that these people do, from time to time, engage in activities which place at risk not only their own lives but also those who are called on to rescue or save them from unforeseen circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: My brief advises me that there is a bigger and bigger responsibility being placed on the Surveillance Centre in Canberra and that 2,500 incidents were reported to it during 1984-85. Some 61 searches were undertaken by the Centre in co-operation with the State and Territory police services. The cost to the taxpayer of those searches exceeded $1.5m. Of course, the difficulty is that sometimes people's sense of adventure leads them to take on tasks that are beyond them. I refer to the incident mentioned by Senator Devlin in which a young rower sought to row himself across Bass Strait. Not only did he lose his own life when he put out a mayday call but also, as a result of the involvement of other persons, one older fisherman, as I recall, lost his life in the rescue operation.

I suppose that we are confronted with the difficulty of a division of responsibility between State police forces, which accept responsibility in some areas, and the Commonwealth, which is becoming more and more involved as people's sense of adventure is expressed in the way it has been. There is in fact no clear division of authority between the Commonwealth and the States even though the Commonwealth has accepted some responsibilities in these areas. We have had the recent example of a hoax, again in Senator Devlin's State, which my brief tells me cost the Commonwealth some $62,000 in responding to the call. Therefore, I suppose that when Senator Devlin asks me about the Australian public becoming more aware of their social responsibilities in this matter I must respond positively to that suggestion because I think that when persons set out on some adventure they should have some support system organised for themselves so that in fact other innocents are not involved in the expedition or the adventure which they are undertaking. One can only hope that, on the basis of this recent Tasmanian experience, more care will be exercised. Whilst we do not want to take away the right of citizens to involve themselves in adventure, it is clear that they have some responsibility to make sure that they have some support system organised not only to save themselves but also to avoid losing the lives of other people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In 1984-85 the Labor Government set a target of 4,000 business migrants but achieved a result of only 1,417 such migrants. In 1985-86 the target was raised to 4,500. It is projected that only 1,800 such people will migrate. Why is this so?
—I do not know off-hand. I will ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and get an answer as soon as possible.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Territories to an anachronistic piece of legislation known as the Public Health (Sale of Food and Drugs) Regulations-specifically Regulation 27-which operates in the Australian Capital Territory and which prevents Canberra restaurant owners from serving food to customers seated outside their restaurants. Will the Government consider amending this regulation so that Australia's capital city can be brought into line with practices around the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt that all of us appreciate the civilised eating habits that we have seen when we have had the opportunity of travelling overseas and would like to see them extended to Australia. No doubt, eating outdoors is an attractive way to eat. The National Health and Medical Research Council has produced a model food Act for adoption in all States and Territories to achieve such an objective. However, it is not a matter that can be resolved easily. We have many pests in Australia. Personally, at the top of the list I would put the self-appointed economists who keep telling governments how to run the economy. However, I suppose that the pest which has its application here is the blowfly which has created problems, particularly in the hot climate of Australia, so far as our pure food health Acts are concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority has responsibility for public health matters in the Australian Capital Territory it currently is examining the draft model Act that has been prepared by the National Health and Medical Research Council. It is seeking the opinion of those involved in the catering industry with a view to meeting what clearly would be a very desirable objective. However, I am advised that there are difficulties because there have been a large number of complaints about blowflies being found in take-away food. We therefore have to consider the pest problem when we look at liberalising the existing practices. Desirable as that may be, we still have the responsibility of protecting those who will partake of the food. To that extent, every consideration is being given to the model Act. I hope shortly to be in a position to advise Senator Bolkus as to some final consideration of the recommendation of the model Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Walters, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of former Senator O'Byrne, a distinguished senator from Tasmania and also a former distinguished President of the Senate. I extend to Mr and Mrs O'Byrne on behalf of all honourable senators a warm and friendly welcome on their return to Canberra.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will the cost of the two different types of membership cards for next month's Australian Labor Party National Conference sent to Australia's top 500 corporations be tax deductible? As the first type of card, which costs $1,100, entitles the owner to breakfast with Senator Button and Mr Keating and as the second type of card, which is called the `extra card' and which costs $1,900, entitles the owner to breakfast with `Bob' and as both cards entitle the owners-according to Mr John Phillips who dreamed up the rort for the Labor Party-`to be briefed and serviced with a secretariat and given the opportunity for contact with people that matter', can the businessmen who fall for this ripoff claim a tax deduction for these based on the need of their businesses for these services?
—She's got it wrong. They're going to have you for breakfast.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite likely. I will obtain a detailed answer to Senator Walters's tax deductibility questions. As I understand it, an awful lot of people want to come to the breakfast, whether or not it is tax deductible. That is a tribute to the relevance of a National Labor Party Conference as distinct from a conference of the Liberal Party of Australia. I am sure that will not be a question of major concern.

ANSWER.PARA: I also understand that part of the expenses of the delegates will be financed by the Tasmanian Government. That is something we appreciate, that the Liberal Party has seen fit, through the Tasmanian Government, to contribute to the cost of delegates to the Conference. So the contribution is fairly universal. The recognition of the importance of the Conference is widely acknowledged and we appreciate the support it is getting. As to whether anyone will pay money to have breakfast with me, I can only say to some of my colleagues that they ought to appreciate that some people are prepared to pay for that even if they are not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to those sections of the leaked aviation policy document of the Liberal Party of Australia covering the privatisation of Australian airlines and the partial privatisation of Qantas Airways Ltd? If so, can he give an indication of the likely realisable value of those assets and the Government's response to the Opposition's justification for disposing of them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the relevant section of the leaked Opposition policy and the Commonwealth investments, which are share capital and reserves, recorded in the balance sheets of the two airlines: They are $372m for Trans Australia Airlines and $136m for Qantas. However, those amounts are not reliable or even indicative measures of realisable values since they are based on historical valuations, not current or market valuations of assets. If those assets or shares were to be offered for sale their value would be affected significantly by the conditions under which they were offered. For example, with the Thatcher privatisation policy, although shares have been offered for sale to the public, very restrictive conditions on the resale of those shares and other restrictions have been generally imposed upon them. I do not know whether this Opposition intends to do that if it should ever get into government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition is now claiming as a virtue-I find this supremely ironic-that it will end the two-airline agreement and deregulate aviation. Given that only in 1981, before the then Fraser Government and the then Treasurer-the current high priest of privatisation and deregulation; a high priest in opposition-lost control of the Senate in the middle of that year, they bulldozed through legislation effectively to lock up the two-airlines policy until 1990. So someone has travelled to Damascus, or would like us to believe he has travelled to Damascus, since them.

The stated reasons for the Opposition proposing to sell off assets is that it would be more efficient and would better deliver a service. That is nonsense, just as it was in the United Kingdom. What the Opposition's privatisation policy is based upon is the desperate need to get money to deliver on some of its irresponsible spending promises which, if honoured, would add $2 billion to government outlays. Its taxation promises would take $5 billion off revenue. What the Opposition's privatisation policy is all about is to flog off public assets and burn the money in current consumption. That is what it is all about, just as is the case in England where the Thatcher Government is flogging off public assets, not deregulating industry, to fund tax cuts for the next election. That is what this Opposition proposes to do here. However, it will have to go much further than TAA and Qantas because, even on market valuations, the total assets of TAA and Qantas are not nearly enough to fund the irresponsible expenditure and taxation promises which the discredited former Treasurer has been running around the country delivering, as he put it, a shopping list of political goodies. To deliver on that promise, the assets that the Opposition would have to flog off are Telecom Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister was asked a question about a specific element of policy. He is now debating the question across a much wider field and I ask you to call him to order.
—I have been listening to the Minister. He is within the terms of his answer, even though that may be a long way around the track. I ask him to come to the point.

—Certainly, Mr President. I was just making the point, and I was about to close, that the assets of Telecom and Qantas are not nearly large enough to meet the Opposition's requirements. The assets it would have to flog off are Telecom and Australia Post and the trading enterprises which have assets valued at billions of dollars not hundreds of millions of dollars.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Since many Ministers listed in the returns of Ministers' interests state that they are paid-up members of unions, could the grants they have made to unions over the past three years be considered a conflict of interest?
—I do not think so. All the interests are declared, and that is the point, I think.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Trade say whether Australia's export potential is being inhibited by the belief that we have a poor industrial relations record and virtually no manufacturing industry? If so, to what extent has this situation affected exports? Can the Minister indicate what the Government and the business community are doing to counter this misconception?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it would take a very long time to answer that question.
—Try, and try to shorten it.

—Senator Boswell is encouraging me today and I welcome that. It is true that traditionally this country has been regarded as one which has a poor industrial relations record. In the early months of this year Australia's industrial relations record was the best for 17 years. We had an enormous improvement in the level of industrial disputation.
—Not in the Melbourne trains.

—There are always exceptions. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle mentioned the Melbourne trains and earlier today a question was asked about Broken Hill. However, across the board the aggregate figures for industrial disputation are vastly improved throughout Australia and in some industries they have dramatically improved; for example, under this Government the record of industrial peace in the steel industry has been magnificent compared with that of previous years. That does not mean that one has any cause for satisfaction about industrial disputes wherever they occur and for whatever reasons they occur. Plenty of societies which have a better and more sophisticated manufacturing sector than ours, for example, have done it on the basis of having a great degree of beneficial and constructive consultation between employees and management, something that would certainly not happen here under an alternative government and certainly did not happen here under the last Government. We have taken a lot of painstaking measures to try to change attitude towards these issues and I think we are having some success. However, we are making slow progress. The extent to which one's reputation for these things as a country develops overseas and changes overseas is, again, a slow process. There is plenty of recognition that that is taking place. The reputation of this country in respect of those matters is changing for the better overseas.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked me about the belief, apparently articulated in various places, that we do not have a very sophisticated and integrated manufacturing sector. I think that is largely true. It is something which was abandoned in previous years as being unimportant. Again, I think we have a considerable way to go in changing perceptions about that; perceptions which, of course, vary from industry to industry. Some are good performers internationally and have a good reputation internationally; others do not. We have embarked on a series of policies in order to try to get a better integrated and more sophisticated manufacturing sector. I do not wish to refer to that at great length at the moment, but basically it involves trying to do some of the things which successful manufacturing economies have done in the past and providing the right environment of incentives for that.

Once again, the reputation issue will, I believe, change gradually, but it is exactly the same as the question which the Government has to address at the moment because of the adverse turn in the terms of trade. It does not represent anything particularly new; it represents something significant in terms of the impact which it has in a country which now has a largely deregulated financial system and a floating dollar. The impact is significant but it does not represent any great change to the underlying factors which have brought about that situation dramatically in Australia in the past few months.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER'S ADDRESS TO THE NATION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and refers to the Prime Minister's address to the nation tomorrow night and to the fact that the Parliament in the form of the Senate is sitting at that time. Have arrangements been made for the substance of the speech to be read simultaneously, or as nearly as possible, in this Senate as is the case with Budget Speeches? If not, will the Government ensure that this is done? Since the speech is foreshadowed as being of grave significance to the nation, would it not be contempt of the Senate not to make the speech to a sitting Senate? Would not the mere tabling of the text of the speech, as is done in minor matters, be an indication to the Senate of the true value which the Government places on the substances of the speech and on the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I might say so, that is a very clever question. Let me give the answer to that typically clever question. The answer to the first part of the question is no, it is not the intention to make the speech available in the Senate. The circumstances to which the honourable senator is referring and in which that is done, such as the Budget, are circumstances in which the Treasurer, the Prime Minister, or some other senior Minister in the House of Representatives makes a statement to that House and, as a courtesy, among other things, to the Senate, it is made in this House at the same time. The House of Representatives is not sitting. The address which the Prime Minister will give tomorrow night is an address to the nation; it is not an address to the Senate. We would make a mistake if in any way we tried to identify the two things because they are not the same. The nation and the Senate are not the same, however much people here might like to think that they are.

ANSWER.PARA: In doing this, the Prime Minister will not be departing from any precedent, as I understand it, set by previous Prime Ministers in this country. I doubt that the honourable senator can dredge up a circumstance in which an address to the nation was given when the House of Representatives was not sitting and it was recalled, as the shadow Treasurer, Mr Carlton, has asked for. It would not be normal for the Senate to be given a special copy of that address to the nation. That will not be done. It is not contempt of the Senate, as the honourable member suggests.

The last part, the particularly clever part, of the honourable senator's question is whether that reveals the true value which the Government puts on the speech. It is not a question of what value the Government puts on the speech; it is a question of what value the people of Australia put on the speech. That will be determined by the people who constitute the nation which is to be addressed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am sorry that the Leader of the Government should be so testy. The only clever part of the question was to show--
—Order! The honourable senator will ask his question.

—As I understand it, the Leader of the Government indicated that this speech will be made tomorrow night while this Senate, doing its duty, will be meeting and that, therefore, if honourable senators are doing their duty they will be here. Is it intended that the speech itself should not be available to the Senate whilst it is sitting? Why is that so?

—The answer is that the speech will be broadcast by all the media. All senators have access to radio and television and they can go and listen to it or look at it. If they happen to be on their feet in the Senate at the time it is given, undoubtedly there will be replays by popular demand and they can look at the replays. They will not miss out as a result of doing their duty in the Senate, as Senator Sir John Carrick suggests. Senator Sir John Carrick has always been a firm believer in the adage that `he also serves who only stands and waits'. Those who are in the Senate will have to wait for a little while longer.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Does the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities take into account the possibility of major weapons platforms being built by Australian manufacturers? If this is so, might it be possible, recognising necessary safeguards, that such a development would lead to a major revitalisation of a manufacturing sector with export potential?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Industry policy matters are discussed in part 6 of the Dibb report. The report is consistent with and extends the Government's defence policy for Australian industry of June 1984. It is specific in arguing for increased involvement in two industry areas, that is, the enhancement of electronics, including software capabilities, and increased involvement in through life supportive equipment, particularly for the Air Force. Sector by sector, the Department of Defence's assessment is as follows: So far as electronics and software are concerned, in this industry the Dibb recommendations will involve increased expenditure of $195m. Increased spending of $80m is expected on the Australian developed over the horizon radar in the five-year defence program period. Increased priority is assigned to the mobile tactical air defence radar and ground surveillance equipment, both of which would involve significant local content. As to shipbuilding, the Dibb report assigns high priority to a fleet of light patrol frigates. The fleet of eight smaller ships recommended by Dibb is expected to have high local content. As to aircraft, tactical utility helicopters and helicopters for the light patrol frigates are expected to achieve significant levels of local industry involvement.

ANSWER.PARA: Largely as a result of substituting higher Australian content projects which result from equipment more specifically suited to Australia's usual strategic and geographical circumstances, the projects with lower Australian content, the recommendations of the Dibb report can be expected to increase the work load for Australian industry. Aircraft, shipbuilding and electronics could, as I say, all be expected to receive additional benefits from the proposals on top of the increases in recent years which have flowed from higher overall expenditures on equipment. I have some further information and specific figures. I know it is unusual for Question Time, but I think it would be helpful to honourable senators in assessing the Dibb report for me to have this information incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave accordingly.

Since 1982-83 the last coalition Budget, this Government has increased annual spending in Australian Defence Industry by approximately $240m. We have strongly pursued Australian industry involvement in major procurement and have increased spending in Australian industry in real terms in each budget. Since 1982-83 an extra $90 million has been devoted to the purchase of new capital equipment in Australia.

The Dibb report of course recognises that Australian industry cannot and should not seek to be competitive in all sectors and for all products. Consistent with the Government's industry policy, the emphasis should be on exploiting industrial sectors where Australia has unique requirements or possesses a comparative advantage over competitors. Even if all defence equipment expenditure could be directed to Australian industry this would represent only a relatively small increment to our industrial sector.

Assuming that Australian industry seizes the opportunities presented by the Government's policies, and is competitive on world markets, there is every reason to be optimistic about its export potential. However, the Dibb report (P 108) correctly points out that international production and trade in military materiel is characterised by very high non-tariff barriers, government subsidised domestic sales and exports, dumping, international collaborative ventures and counter-trade. The Department of Defence is also currently examining the implications for the viability of Australian Defence industry of Australian controls on the export of defence material.

While the FYDP expenditure reduces, the Australian industry share will increase as low content projects are replaced by high local content projects. The electronic sector will also benefit from the higher number of items and higher local content in shipbuilding and aircraft systems and is likely to benefit substantially overall.
While there is no growth in the FYDP, the large number of smaller ships are likely to have higher local content and to increase industry involvement and competitiveness.
The aircraft industry can expect a significant increase in the large production run aircraft. There will be significant flow-on to systems and electronic work.
Although artillery work at Ordnance Factory Bendigo would reduce, high levels of fabrication, gun and other work would flow from shipbuilding.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROTECTION TO CLOTHING, TEXTILE AND FOOTWEAR INDUSTRIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to his response last week that the Government would reduce the levels of protection to the clothing, textile and footwear industries. Does the Minister have in mind implementing an Industries Assistance Commission recommendation which, in the estimate of the industries, would place at risk 50,000 jobs? Is the abolition of quotas really an equitable or fair alternative, given the wide disparity of wage rates between Australia and some Asian countries? Is the Minister aware that an Australian textile worker going on holiday annually earns more in that time than his counterpart does in China over five full years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Watson is getting agitated about this issue. I suppose that is inevitable, particularly if one comes from Tasmania. But the Government has not responded to the draft report of the Industries Assistance Commission on the future program for the textile, clothing and footwear industries. A number of alternative options are considered in that report--
—You said on Friday you would lower the level of protection. There is no question about that. You look it up in Hansard, at page 3581.

—I am grateful to Senator Lewis. He has joined Senator Boswell again in being helpful today. I did say that on Friday. Let me say that it is a matter of Government policy. I do not know whether honourable senators opposite are seriously saying that Australian industry can afford to have levels of protection of 200 per cent, because that is what some of it involves. If they are saying that, I will be very fascinated to hear their views.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government will, in its approach to the IAC report on textile, clothing and footwear, certainly be lowering levels of protection for these industries. The honourable senator asked me whether I have been softening up the textile, clothing and footwear industries. I have been telling them this for 18 months. They understand it and they are working on means of achieving that result in a sensible way which does not produce the sorts of problems which the honourable senator foreshadowed in the first part of his question. So, of course the Government will be adopting that general approach to the report but I am not in a position to comment on a detailed response to--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what you said on Friday.

—It is said that two heads are better than one. That is certainly true when one of them is the honourable senator's if I can put it in those terms. I ask Senator Boswell to put two and two together-to put together what I said on Friday and what I am saying now. There is no difference. The Government will be adopting a regime in respect of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries which will represent a lowering of the present levels of protection. This is precisely what the Fraser Government did-it is precisely what this Government will do too.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Watson has come in here and asked me about a report which the Government has received but has not yet made available. He asked me how we are going to respond to the detailed items in that report, whether 50,000 jobs will be lost and whether there will be abolition of quotas. I am not going to respond to those questions. We will respond to those questions in due course and then we can debate the answer in this chamber or anywhere else he wants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell the people of Wan- garatta and see how you get on.

—The honourable senator ought to consult with his Leader about this issue. Is he worried about the people of Wangaratta in respect of some of the policies that he is talking about? I think this is a very healthy question because it flushes out some interesting issues. The answer is, quite frankly, that yes, the Government will be lowering protection. I have been about softening up the industry, if I may use that expression, for 18 months now. I ask the honourable senator to read the speech that I gave to the industry council 18 months ago.
—I have.

—The honourable senator has not asked me questions in the last 18 months or so. The honourable senator is a bit slow-I have been saying it for 18 months. I will make a copy of that speech available to him. It is totally consistent with what I am saying now. Let me say that the industry understands that better than does the honourable senator. We will emerge with a healthy, viable--
—Competitive industry.

—More competitive industry. I am not prepared to say, even at the instigation of Senator Elstob, `competitive industry'. I will say `more competitive industry'. That would be a good solution because it would secure a long term future for it. Mr President, I have answered about 18 supplementary questions which were asked by way of interjection.
—I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister give us an assurance that that program will involve minimum job losses?
—Yes, it will involve the minimum number of jobs losses consistent with economic and industry realities in the second half of the twentieth century.

—Further to my reply in the Senate last Friday to a question asked by Senator Tate concerning the detention of the Chairman of the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace in Zimbabwe, I think it appropriate to complete the record by informing the Senate that Mr Auret was released from detention on the evening of 5 June on the instructions of Prime Minister Mugabe. I understand that release was without charges or conditions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked by Senator Sir John Carrick on 6 June a question about chemical weapons. I have a long and, I hope, informative answer which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard on that basis.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick's question raised a number of issues and I will deal with each in turn.

2. It is accepted by Western countries, including Australia, on the basis of sensitive intelligence information about which it would not be appropriate for me to comment further, that the Soviet Union possesses substantial stocks of chemical weapons. Estimates of the size of the Soviet chemical weapons stockpile vary, but all indicate that it is considerably larger than NATO's. To the Government's knowledge the Soviet Union has never formally admitted possessing chemical weapons and on one occasion recently a Soviet spokesman, Maj General Kuntsevich, actually denied it. The Government is not in a position to confirm reports that the Soviet Union has stockpiled biological weapons although Soviet activities in this area remain a cause for concern.

3. Moreover it is correct that the United States halted production of chemical weapons in 1969 and destroyed its stocks of biological weapons in the early 1970s. The United Kingdom also destroyed its stocks of chemical weapons around the same time. The Government is not aware of any matching response by the Soviet Union.

4. The Government agrees that there is a substantial imbalance in the chemical warfare capabilities of NATO and the Warsaw Pact and that this is a cause for serious concern. The Government is also concerned about chemical weapon capabilities of other countries. As indicated recently in answers to a number of questions on notice on this subject, the stockpiling and development of chemical weapons, and training in chemical warfare, are not constrained under existing international agreements.

5. This is why there is an urgent need for the conclusion of a comprehensive convention which would ban the production, stockpiling and use of all chemical weapons and which would require the destruction of all existing stocks of chemical weapons and their production facilities, together with international monitoring against hidden production or stocks of chemical weapons.

6. Senator Sir John Carrick asks the Government to make its concerns on these issues known to the Australian public and to the Soviet Government. As a matter of fact the Government has frequently expressed its views on these matters publicly and pursued them in official communications with the Soviet Union.

7. Moreover the Government has, in addition, greatly expanded Australia's involvement in efforts to resist the spread of chemical weapons, and to conclude the convention, to the point where foreign commentators have spoken of `Australia's leadership' in this area.
8. Measures taken by the Government since March 1983 include:
(i) Increased priority and diplomatic resources for work against chemical weapons

(ii) Additional man power and equipment costing nearly $400,000 for the Defence Department's Materials Research Laboratories (MRL) which provides technical support for Australian efforts in this field.
(iii) Designation of MRL as an analytical centre available to the UN Secretary General for investigation of evidence of chemical warfare.
(iv) Participation of an Australian expert in the 1984 and 1986 UN Secretary General's on site investigations which confirmed Iraq's use of chemical weapons in the Gulf war.
(v) Introduction of export controls on chemicals capable of being used for the manufacture of chemical weapons.
(vi) Convening consultations amongst 18 countries aimed at improving the effectiveness of such controls.
(vii) Increased participation in the chemical weapons negotiations in the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva, with Australia currently chairing one of three working groups.

(viii) In co-operation with an Australian chemical company, testing procedures for the inspection of the civilian chemical industry to guard against clandestine production of chemical weapons and to assist the development of such procedures for the convention.
(ix) Co-sponsorship of resolutions in the United Nations General Assembly and promotion of statements on the subject in the Security Council.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 10 June, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The imperative need for the Government to deliver its promised personal income tax cuts from September 1 to encourage the men and women of Australia to work, save and invest so that the cost of production will be reduced and national productivity increased as the only effective means to national economic recovery'.
Senator for the State of Western Australia
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The imperative need for the Government to deliver its promised personal income tax cuts from September 1 to encourage the men and women of Australia to work, save and invest so that the cost of production will be reduced and national productivity increased as the only effective means to national economic recovery'.

I think the need for this motion was made clear today during Question Time in a number of the answers that were given to us by Government Ministers. I suppose the most instructive of those answers was given by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, who boldly said that the Government sees the position as being one where average living standards in Australia have to fall. The Minister, after a glib reference to changes in the terms of trade and the effect that would have on Australia, has said to the people of Australia that their average living standards have to fall. That is a reality that the Opposition believes that the people of Australia face. We believe that they face the prospect of a reduction in their living standards. We have moved this motion because we believe that one of the contributions which can be made to maintaining the living standard of everyone in Australia is to carry out cuts to the marginal tax rates which have been promised by this Government but the delivery of which has been cast into some doubt.

We have moved this motion at a time of economic decision-making. There is a risk that the wage and salary earners of Australia will wind up carrying extra burdens because the Government wants to take the easy way out. The Government may well choose to reduce their living standards simply by continuing to take more and more of their incomes in tax rather than taking action which will enable the economy of Australia and their living standards to grow again. That would involve the Government making much harder decisions about its own expenditure and about the inefficiencies that it has allowed to develop in the Australian economy. Tackling those things will take great courage on the part of the Government. Leaving higher taxes on the people of Australia is, in that sense, the easy option.

We have had a number of signs over the last few days and the last few weeks that the Government is proposing to welsh on the very clear promises it has made to the people of Australia. It is important to note that those promises, made in September last year, were made on the basis that the Government was going to impose some new tax burdens on the Australian community, particularly on Australian business. It was going to introduce a great range of new taxes but at the same time it was promising that at some time in the future there would be relief for the people of Australia which would make up-indeed, more than make up-for the new taxes that were being imposed. The Government, through the Treasurer (Mr Keating), promised in September 1985 that cuts would take effect as the extra revenue from the tax reform measures came on stream. Of course, those tax reform measures have all been passed through the Senate. It was promised that personal income tax rate scales would be changed-that the tax free threshold would be increased from $4,595 to $5,100; the 25 per cent marginal rate would be reduced to 24 per cent; the 30 per cent rate would be reduced to 29 per cent; the 46 per cent rate would be reduced to 43 per cent; the 48 per cent rate would be reduced to 46 per cent; and the 60 per cent rate would be reduced to 55 per cent. These changes were to be just the first of two annual instalments which would ultimately see the reduction of all marginal tax rates, with the final position, to be reached in July of 1987, being that the highest rate of personal income tax imposed would be 49c in the dollar. That is still a hefty impost, but a considerable reduction on the rate of 60c in the dollar imposed on many people in Australia who go out and earn extra income, extra wealth, for their good and for the good of the community.

The Opposition believes that if we are to return to rising living standards we will have to get people to work harder and be more productive, not impose higher taxes. We believe that it is only by getting people to work, save and invest in a productive way that Australians will be given a better run than they now face under the economic policies of this Government. The signs I referred to in relation to the Government reconsidering its position are signs that have to be taken seriously, because the Government's record of keeping its promises on taxes is very poor. There has been reference over the past weeks of debate in the Senate on the Government's tax package to the fact that the Government made an absolute commitment that there would be no capital gains tax. Of course, it entered into a collusive arrangement with the Australian Democrats-who had come here apparently to keep both sides of politics honest-an arrangement which enabled the Government to break that very clear promise to the people of Australia. There was to be no new capital gains tax; there now is a new capital gains tax, brought in not only by this Government but also by the votes of the Australian Democrats, who supposedly were going to keep the Government honest.

There are now hints that the Government will reconsider the tax cuts it promised to the wage and salary earners of Australia, to the non-tax dodgers of Australia. It so likes to draw a distinction between those who have paid their taxes in the past and those who have not. It promised these cuts and now the hints are that they will not be delivered, or will not be delivered on time. Once again, can we in the Opposition look to the Australian Democrats to keep the Government honest, to keep the Government to its promises? No, of course we cannot. We all have copies of a letter from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to Senator Don Chipp, Leader of the Australian Democrats, which makes it clear that once again the Australian Democrats have given the Government room to break the promises it made to the people of Australia. The Prime Minister said to Senator Chipp in a letter of 28 May, following discussions which had been held by the Government and the Australian Democrats:

I advise that the Government has made no decision to defer the tax cuts as announced. However, the timing of the tax cuts will be given further consideration by the Government following the meeting of the Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes in June.
That meeting, of course, has since been cancelled. The Prime Minister went on:
This consideration has become necessary following the very adverse developments in Australia's terms of trade in recent months.
However, I am happy to repeat in writing the Government's unequivocal commitment that the tax cuts will be delivered no later than 1 December 1986.

So at that stage, at the end of May, the Prime Minister is saying that the Government might postpone these tax cuts for three months, but he gives an unequivocal commitment to bring them in by 1 December. We have to remember that this is the same Prime Minister who gave an unequivocal assurance to the people of Australia-not in this Parliament but in one of those great addresses to the nation that Senator Button was telling us just a few minutes ago are so important-that there would be no capital gains tax. We all know the worth of that promise. We find today that the newspapers of Australia have referred to the Government's action on these tax cuts. Michelle Grattan reports in this morning's Age:

Senior sources said it appeared `most unlikely' that Mr Hawke would be specific tomorrow on the timing for the tax cuts-which are due on 1 September but which were expected to be deferred-except to reassure that they will be given this year. Other sources rated the chances of the Prime Minister being specific on timing as `50/50'.
Michelle Grattan, the chief political correspondent for the Age, went on to say:
The Government wants to preserve flexibility on the timing of the tax cuts until closer to the budget, if it can. They are also a potential bargaining counter in talks on future wages policy . . .

It is the view of the Opposition that these are not a bargaining counter; they are a clear commitment to the people of Australia, and the only commitment consistent with economic recovery in Australia and a return to rising living standards. We do not bring forward the assertion that these tax cuts are important for the economic recovery of Australia solely on the basis of that being our view as an Opposition. The Government went to some trouble to justify the changes to the marginal tax rates that it was proposing in September of 1985. I would like to quote from what the Treasurer had to say at that time, because he adopted totally the view the Opposition is expressing here, and the view we have been expressing over many years, about the effect of income tax on the behaviour of Australian wage and salary earners. In a statement on 19 September 1985, Mr Keating said:
. . . I come back to the point that reductions in the higher marginal rates have been, and remain, a prime objective of tax reform.

After referring to the fact that high rates provide a major incentive for people to avoid and evade their tax, the Treasurer went on to make the central point of this debate. He said that it was those high marginal personal income tax rates that involve the most severe disincentive to work, to save and to invest.

That is the central truth around which this motion is based. The high tax rates we suffer in Australia are the most severe disincentive to work, save and invest. If Australia is to recover its capacity for economic growth, if we are to recover our capacity to compete in the world, it is essential that we become a country which works better and saves and invests more. It is there that our salvation lies; it is there that the maintenance of our living standards lies. We have seen in the answer the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, gave to us today that this Government has cravenly accepted that the standard of living of Australians has to fall. That is something which ought not to be accepted by the Government. The only way the Government can ensure that that does not occur is to make sure that Australians work, save and invest, and these tax cuts will play an important part in ensuring that that happens.

No one is denying that Australia is facing an economic crisis and that unless there are changes of direction we face a bleak and uncertain future. It is not a situation in which we can be dependent on some stroke of luck to get us out of trouble-the finding of some new reserves of gold or oil or something which will bail us out, as we have been happy to be bailed out of past financial difficulties. If we are to be bailed out in the future it will be by dint of investment in new and productive enterprises, and that means that these tax cuts are centrally important. Mr Keating has described us as heading for banana republic status and Mr Hawke, having panicked in the face of Mr Keating's statement, cancelled the meeting organised by Mr Keating in favour of making an address to the nation-an address that he is not game to bring into this Parliament; an address that he is prepared to make only from behind the safety of a television camera. The reality is that we must allow the people of Australia to get back to work, give them an incentive to get back to work, and these tax cuts are an important part of the overall solution to our crisis.

The nature of Australia's present economic difficulties is that we are uncompetitive and are not earning enough to sustain our standard of living. To live as we live in Australia at the moment we must borrow. Our governments have to borrow; we have to borrow as a country. We are simply not producing enough; we are not producing enough efficiently and effectively. We must therefore learn, as a nation, to earn more. What we have had again in Question Time and what we have had over and over from this Government is a pathetic attempt to blame the terms of trade for the decline in living standards which now faces us. Yet if we look at the terms of trade Australia has had, we find that they have been declining ever since the 1950s. The terms of trade reached their peak in the early 1950s when wool prices were at an all-time high and there has been a steady downward slope against Australia ever since that time. That was a fact faced by all previous governments-Liberal and Labor-but it is this Government which now blames that constant which has been with us over the last 30 years as being the reason for declining living standards.

I am sorry that one cannot incorporate charts in Hansard because the chart of our terms of trade is instructive. The chart shows how the prices of the things we sell compare with the prices of the things we buy. It went from a peak, on a measure of 100, of about 250 in early 1950s to a negative situation in the early 1970s, it recovered briefly and it returned to a negative situation during the term of the Fraser Government. In other words, the external difficulties on which this Government is currently relying are external difficulties that faced previous governments, including the Fraser Government, but the Fraser Government did not sit around bleating, wringing its hands and blaming the rest of the world.

What we have to do is not to concentrate on the things that the world imposes on us, but rather to concentrate on what we can control, and that means our own efficiency and our own productivity in the work place. We can control the incentives there are in Australia to work and produce. This Government, through its tax package that went through the Senate last week, is reducing the incentives to work and produce. It has put new taxes on business and investment, it has imposed capital gains taxes, it has imposed a fringe benefits tax, it has abolished negative gearing and it has abolished deductions for entertainment. Every new tax measure we have put through this Parliament this session, apart from the research and development deductions legislation, which are new deductions, has imposed an additional tax burden on those people who would invest in enterprise in Australia. Given those massive new tax burdens, it is absolutely essential that the personal tax burden be eased and that the easement not be delayed as the easy way out of the Government's present budgetary situation.

What we are seeing at the moment in this speculation that the tax cuts will be delayed is a threatening of the Government's supposed quid pro quo for the tax increases it has imposed. The Opposition is totally and finally opposed to any delay in those tax cuts. It needs to be remembered that the Government's own reasoning of September and the reasoning it put forward for the whole tax package was that all of the new taxes would be returned to taxpayers. The Government said that the tax cuts would be delivered in satisfaction of its commitment to continued wage restraint. It told wage and salary earners that it wanted to slow down the rate of wage increases but that it would offer tax cuts in return. We believe that that is a bargain that it made with the wage and salary earners, and it is a bargain which must be kept. In the September tax statement the Government said that average income earners would receive an income tax cut of $9 a week in September this year. It said there would be further cuts, bringing tax cuts to a total of $15.20 by July the following year. It said that none of these tax cuts would be financed by adding to the Government's deficit and that they would be achieved by the most rigorous restraint on public sector outlays.

The Government laid down that regime for the Australian people. We believe that it is essential that it retains that regime and that it maintains those tax cuts. But what we have actually had from this Government is none of the restraint it promised in its September statement. What we have had from the Government is simply a consistent attack on the people of Australia through ever-growing government expenditure and ever-growing taxation income. In the course of the life of this Government we have seen a growth in outlays in real terms of around 5 per cent. We have seen a growth of taxation of more than 5 per cent in each year that this Government has been in office. In straight dollar terms, this Government is collecting something like $20,000m more in taxes and is spending that sort of money more than was being collected and spent when it was elected to office.

When the Government talks about denying or delaying a couple of billion dollars worth of tax cuts to wage and salary earners, it needs to be remembered that those wage and salary earners are paying tens of billions of dollars of additional taxes to this Government because of its profligacy and because of its increased expenditure.

The Opposition believes that there are solutions to the problems of Australia. It believes that there are solutions which do not require what we heard today from the Minister for Finance-acceptance that all Australians are going to have their living standards reduced. We believe that if the Government gives the Australian work force the incentive to work, save and invest, the economy of Australia can continue to grow. We are concerned that in approaching this problem, the Government will do all of the wrong things-it will seek to remove those positive elements from the tax package and it will seek to further destroy the incentive to work, save and invest.

Over the recent months of sittings of this Senate, we have seen attempts by the Government to create alibis as to why the tax cuts should not be granted. Senator Walsh, in response to a question from Senator Watson, for example, referred to the fact that there was a possibility that some of the Government's new taxes would be defeated and that that would deny the people the tax cuts that had been promised. Senator Walsh said in the Senate:

Let it be known if the taxation package is sabotaged by the Opposition in the Senate to the point where it is impossible to deliver the income tax cuts which the Government has promised, the responsibility for that will rest fairly and squarely with members of the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats.

The Government now has the additional revenue that it sought to raise through its tax package. It has no alibis. It has vastly increased revenues which have been caused by the fact that, with inflation and higher incomes, people are paying more and more of their incomes in tax. We have reached the point where there is a dramatic need for personal income tax relief. We have reached the point where there is a possibility that the Government will welsh on its clear undertaking to wage and salary earners. The Opposition will not have a bar of that. We believe that the tax cuts are central to our economic recovery and we insist that the Government introduce them on time and as promised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Government to oppose this motion on taxation moved by Senator Chaney, the Leader of the Opposition in this place. The motion ignores the Government's achievements of obtaining economic recovery in Australia, of reducing production costs for Australian industry, and of taxation reform. In fact, as I will demonstrate during my remarks, this motion clearly underlines the mess the Opposition has got itself into on the whole question of taxation reform. The Opposition is in such a bad mess on tax reform that its taxation spokesman, Senator Messner, is not even participating in the debate this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have said that it may not be financially prudent to bring in the taxation reductions in September this year and that it may be desirable that there be some postponement in the delivery of the tax cuts to a later point this year because the country may not be able to afford reductions in personal income tax from September. But it has been made clear time and time again that the tax cuts will occur during 1986-this calendar year. The Government has given that commitment and it is on the record.

There has been a severe decline in Australia's terms of trade; that is, that the relationship between the prices we pay for our imports and the prices we receive for our exports has worsened enormously, reducing our real income. That is the major factor that the Government has taken into account in considering delaying these income tax cuts. It is a very substantial reduction in Australia's real income as a result of worsening commodity prices abroad, and that is the basic factor which has led the Government to consider some postponement of its decision. As I said, we will deliver the tax cuts by December this year. We will deliver tax cuts that Mr Howard, in five Budgets from 1978 to 1982, could not deliver.

This motion shows the clear hypocrisy and duplicity of the Liberal Party of Australia on taxation. By moving this motion, the Opposition is now saying that it wants income tax cuts in September; not later. It is not prepared to pay any attention to the financial circumstances Australia now faces. It just wants to have tax cuts in September. Let us look at the tax record of the Liberals to date. Let us look at the Opposition's attitude to tax reform over the past couple of years and its attitude to the tax package brought in by this Government. After all, this is a tax package-it is a comprehensive group of tax reforms in line with the nine taxation principles outlined by the Prime Minister, one of which was that there would be no overall increase in the taxation level in relation to Australia's gross domestic product. But the tax package must be financed in some way. Extra revenue must be obtained to redistribute taxes and to give tax cuts. The Prime Minister has indicated that overall there will be no increase in the tax burden on the community. Therefore, some revenue must be obtained if money is to be paid back to the community in the form of comprehensive personal income tax cuts.

What have the Liberals done about this tax package? What have they done every time this Government has brought into the Parliament legislation to gather that revenue? On every possible occasion the Liberals have voted to block that legislation. On every possible occasion they have voted to deny this Government the revenue with which to finance the personal income tax reductions for the Australian community. They have done that time and time again. They did it first on the legislation to disallow entertainment expenses, the so-called tax deductible lunch; then they did so on fringe benefits, a major form of tax avoidance in this country; and then as recently as last Thursday evening they did it again on the capital gains tax. The fact is that the legislation brought in by this Government to disallow entertainment expenses-to disallow the tax deductible lunches of a small number of people in this community-will bring in for the Government revenue of $310m next financial year, rising to some $330m in the subsequent financial year, 1987-88. That is a very substantial sum of money and it is one of the key means by which the Government will finance the personal income tax cuts for most Australians which will occur this calendar year. What did the Liberals do? They voted against the legislation to disallow the tax deductible lunch despite the fact that for years they have told the Australian people-as have the gurus that the Liberals have brought in from overseas-that there is no such thing as a free lunch and that economic sacrifices will have to be made.
