As soon as we brought this legislation before the Parliament, the Liberals voted against it-even though it is one of the key methods of financing the personal income tax cuts which will be produced this year.

The Liberals wanted to deny us the revenue, but they want the tax cuts. They acted in this way despite the fact that there is no comparable entertainment allowance in those countries with which we normally compare ourselves. There is no general allowance for lunches and entertainment in Britain or the United States. Yet despite that, the Opposition voted to reject the legislation brought in by this Government-legislation that next financial year will obtain $330m. The Opposition has exercised breath taking hypocrisy-it wants the tax cuts but it does not want to help us pay for them. That is the basic fact of the matter.

We then move to the question of fringe benefits. As I indicated, this has been a major area of tax avoidance in Australia in recent years. In some cases top executives have been receiving up to 40 per cent of their remuneration in the form of fringe benefits-not in cash but in non-cash benefits. Clearly this is an avenue designed to take remuneration out of the taxation net in Australia. When we brought in legislation to crack down on this major area of tax avoidance in the country, this escalation of remuneration outside the tax net, what did the Liberals do? They opposed it at every turn and on every possible occasion. This legislation, again was designed to finance the personal income tax cuts which will be delivered to Australians this year; was to be another major financing source for the tax cuts. For the next financial year, beginning on 1 July, the original revenue estimates were that some $320m would be collected through the tax on fringe benefits. Since that time there have been amendments in this place but the original figure was $320m a year, rising to $515m in 1987-88. Those are very substantial amounts of money and very substantial elements with which we could finance personal tax cuts for the bulk of the Australian community. Again, the Liberals wanted to deny us that revenue and they voted against that legislation.

Now the Opposition wants the tax cuts, not in December but in September. That is the incredible gall of this Opposition. It is no wonder the Liberals are in opposition and there is no doubt that they will stay there. When we look at those two tax measures together, the disallowance of business lunches and the taxation of fringe benefits, we find that we are talking about very substantial sums of money-$630m in 1986-87 on the original estimates, rising to some $845m in the subsequent financial year. Yet the Opposition blocked and opposed those measures at every turn and every possible opportunity. Now Opposition senators want tax cuts. They want to have it both ways. They do not want to help us raise the revenue but they want to have the credit for getting tax cuts to the community.

Last Thursday we had the debate on the capital gains tax-yet another tax with which we hope to finance these personal income tax reductions. We heard some very interesting propositions argued in the debate last week by Senator Messner who is, I believe, the Opposition's spokesman on taxation. Incidentally, he is not participating in this debate this afternoon even though the core of it is taxation. Senator Messner, speaking as Opposition spokesman on taxation, said last Thursday that the capital gains tax would raise very little revenue. He told us that in his speech. Then in almost the next breath he said that we were imposing the highest rate of capital gains tax in the world. How on earth can anyone reconcile those statements? As far as I am concerned, that is the sixty-four dollar question. I invite Senator Messner to enlighten the Senate on how those two statements can go together. It is no wonder that with logic like that-or lack of it-Senator Messner is not participating in this debate this afternoon. It indicates very clearly indeed the sheer mess into which the Opposition has plunged itself by its ducking and weaving on the question of taxation and taxation reform.

As I have indicated several times this afternoon, every time we have brought legislation before this Parliament to introduce tax reform in this country the Opposition has voted to block it, even though this legislation would raise the revenue to give the community personal income tax reductions. That sort of behaviour certainly will not fool the Australian public. It will not win office for the Opposition and it certainly will not get Opposition senators on to the treasury bench. The conclusion that one can reach as a result of this is that the Liberals are really saying that what they really want are Labor's taxation rates and schedules. That is the really inescapable conclusion that we can draw from this motion. They want our tax package. They are really saying that our proposed tax rates are better than those that the Liberals could introduce in government. They are saying, in effect, that they prefer Labor tax rates to their own. Basically that is what it comes down to and the reasons for it are clear. It is abundantly clear why the Liberals want our tax schedule to be introduced in September rather than later in the year. Our top marginal tax rate in our tax package will be 49c in the dollar; under the Liberals it was 60c in the dollar. As a result of our tax reform package no wage and salary earner in the community will have to pay more than half of his or her extra income in taxation. That is one of the reasons why the Liberals are desperate for us to introduce our tax package. I also instance the lowest personal income tax bracket in the Government's tax schedules. Under the Hawke Government the lowest rate that will apply in the community will be 24c in the dollar. Under the Liberals the bottom tax rate was 30c in the dollar. That is the big difference. They want us to bring in the tax rates that they could not achieve. They want our tax schedules and they want the tax cuts set in place by September. They want tax schedules that the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, could not deliver in his five years as Treasurer of this country, from 1978 to 1982. As a result of this tax package it will be abundantly clear to the Australian community that, because under Labor the bottom tax rate will be 24c in the dollar and under the Liberals it was 30c in the dollar, Labor is the low tax Party in Australia.

In calling for early tax cuts the Opposition is not looking at Australia's overall financial situation. It is not looking at the overall total revenues available to the Government. Basically, its tactics in moving this motion this afternoon imply that it really wants a larger Budget deficit. That is what it seems to boil down to. Honourable senators opposite want a larger Budget deficit financed by greater government borrowing, with increased pressure on interest rates in the community and spill-over effects on private sector activity in Australia. That is what the motion really adds up to.

I find it incredible that Senator Chaney, who was a Minister in the Fraser Government, should move in the Senate today a motion calling for measures to generate economic recovery in Australia, when the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, as Treasurer, brought the Australian economy to its knees in the early 1980s. That Government used increases in unemployment as a means of regulating the rate of inflation in Australia. That was its policy. It resulted in idle industry, rising unemployment and falling employment, and bankruptcy and receivership were the only growth industries in Australia. The previous Government left Australia with double digit unemployment, standing at 10.4 per cent. It left Australia with double digit inflation, with prices rising at the rate of 11 1/2 per cent a year. Yet, that Government's avowed policy-the corner-stone of its economic philosophy-was, it said: `Fight inflation first'.

Under Labor there has been a tremendous recovery in the Australian economy. In the first two financial years that we were in office we had 5 per cent real growth ahead of the inflation rate in the community. Some 670,000 extra jobs have been created in Australia since the National Economic Summit Conference in April 1983. In fact, the number of jobs created under the Labor Government in just three years-670,000-is more than double the number of extra jobs created in the seven years of Fraser-Howard government in Australia. There is record employment in Australia. Most of the new jobs have been created in the private sector, and most of them are full time jobs. This year's Budget provided for growth in employment of some 180,000 extra positions in Australia. In fact, the Budget figures are well out of date and so far during this financial year well over 200,000 extra jobs have been created. Unemployment stood at 10.4 per cent when Labor came to office. It is now down to 7.9 per cent. We do not have double digit inflation, as we did under Mr Fraser and Mr Howard; we have an inflation rate of 9.2 per cent.

One of the corner-stones of the economic recovery under Labor, one of the ways in which Australia has been brought back off its knees, has been the fall in production costs. Senator Chaney, in his motion this afternoon, called for measures to be implemented to reduce production costs in Australia. I simply point out that in a number of major areas costs are at their lowest level for many years. I instance the effect of industrial disputes on production and production costs. Industrial disputes in Australia are now at their lowest level for 16 or 17 years. I refer to a question that I put on notice that was answered today by the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), which shows that during 1984 the number of days lost per employee in Australia was 0.246. That is lower than the figures for Canada and New Zealand, and less than a quarter of the number of days lost due to industrial disputes in Mrs Thatcher's United Kingdom. So our record on industrial disputes and their impact on employers' costs is such that our level of disputes is less than a quarter of the level under Mrs Thatcher's conservative-ruled United Kingdom.

TALK.START.PARA: —And better than the Fraser Government's.

—Of course, our figures are infinitely better than those of the Fraser Government. I refer to tables in the 1985 Budget Papers, prepared by Treasury, which show that average real unit labour costs are at their lowest level since the early 1970s. That is a tremendous achievement by this Government. Senator Chaney's motion today called for economic recovery in Australia and measures to assist it, but, of course, he is calling for recovery from the Liberal years-recovery from that period when Australia was brought to its knees by Mr Howard and Mr Fraser. The fact is that now employment is up and unemployment is down. Inflation has come down, and recovery is occurring in Australia. I find the Opposition's position on taxation reform, as shown by this motion, to be breathtaking in its hypocrisy. It shows its double standards. Time and time again it has voted against legislation which we have introduced to raise revenue to be redistributed as personal income tax cuts during this year. There will be personal income tax cuts during 1986, and we will be delivering the tax cuts that the Liberals were unable to introduce in five Budgets.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chipp) agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp) moving an amendment to the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) has moved:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The imperative need for the Government to deliver its promised personal income tax cuts from September 1 to encourage the men and women of Australia to work, save and invest so that the cost of production will be reduced and national productivity increased as the only effective means to national economic recovery.
I move the following amendment to the Opposition motion:
Leave out ``from September 1'' in the statement of the matter of urgency, insert: ``as soon as is fiscally prudent, but no later than December 1,''.

Like Senator Maguire, I find this exercise by the Opposition-I am surprised that the urgency motion was moved by Senator Chaney, for whom I have a high personal regard-an exercise of breathtaking hypocrisy. For the last eight weeks the Liberal Party has passionately, vigorously, used every device of this Senate to oppose the means by which tax cuts can be given. It has opposed everything. With regard to every conceivable reform the Government has put forward, the Opposition has opposed all the nasties. Then it has had the breathtaking hypocrisy to say: `Although we have opposed those proposals, we still want the goodies'. Not one word in Senator Chaney's speech indicated where the revenue to pay for the goodies would come from. One can only assume that it would come from an increased blow-out of the deficit, and God knows how big it is now. An increased deficit means increased government borrowings, which means increased interest rates and all the horrific parts of well-known and documented past Liberal policy.

However, it is pleasing to see that the Opposition at last can see the other side of tax reform-the tax cuts. The Opposition is right to say there is a need for tax cuts, and we agree with that part of its motion. Reducing marginal tax rates, in particular the top rate from 60c to 49c and making that the rate for company tax also, will increase people's incentive to work and will reduce the incentive to avoid tax by forming a company in order to pay a lower tax rate. It is refreshing also to see that at last the Opposition has become interested in the pay as you earn taxpayer. For the last six to eight weeks people such as Senator Walters have been championing those who have been ripping off the taxpayer by means of rorts, lurks and perks. For the last eight weeks they have opposed every measure to stop lurks and perks, to stop rorts. The Liberal Party and the National Party have made every endeavour to do that. For the last six to eight weeks they have opposed every measure that has been designed to benefit the pay as you earn taxpayer. In fact, according to the Liberal and National parties, the only people who should bear a tax burden are the PAYE taxpayers. I think it is contemptible and despicable. I think a system under which certain taxpayers-75 to 85 per cent of the taxpayers-whose income is confined to wages or salaries have to bear an extra burden of tax to pay for the 10 to 15 per cent who are engaged in rorts, lurks and perks lacks equity and morality. It is a concept which I dismiss as little short of disgusting. That is exactly what the Liberal Party and the National Party have been on about for the last eight weeks.

It is odd that the Opposition, which has done everything to sabotage tax reform and tax cuts, is now pretending to be their great defender. The Opposition has opposed the ending of the free lunch. I do not know what sort of moral compulsion has led the Liberal Party to do that. I cannot see how the kind of Liberal Party I joined 26 years ago would come into this Parliament and say: `The 85 per cent of salary earners who do not get any lurks and perks have to pay extra tax so that businessmen and the wealthy can enjoy their free lunch, free dinners or whatever'. Does not the Liberal Party know that the practice was rampant, that businessmen used to go to expensive up-market restaurants with friends and everybody shared in the bill, but the businessmen would say: `I will put this on my Bankcard but you pay me the cash'? It was going on all over the country. The people who were paying extra tax so that businessmen could have the free lunch or the free dinner were the ordinary wage and salary earners.

What about the opposition to the fringe benefits tax? Members of the Opposition have become champions of small business or the business person. They say: `This is destroying small business'. Who started the fringe benefits practice? It was the business people. Why did they do it? It was as simple as this: The accountant or the lawyer would go to a business person and say: `You have a job here. You have to pay $40,000 to get the right person, but I have a lurk to put your way. Do not pay $40,000; offer the person $20,000 in cash and a lurk or a perk for $10,000-a free car, a low interest rate loan or whatever'. The business person would say to the applicant for the job: `This job is worth $30,000. We will pay you only $20,000 in salary but you will be able by this device to escape paying tax on $10,000'. He would say to himself: `I am pretty smart, because I am giving this person $10,000 less than I need pay him'. But who pays the extra tax for that lurk, that fringe benefit? It is the salary earner and the wage earner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like us.

—Like us, indeed. Only people such as Senator Peter Baume are capable of an act of such exquisite masochism, of saying with pride: `We are paying for the lurks and perks of the small business person'. It is a kind of logic that I find difficult to follow. Honourable senators opposite were champions of negative gearing. They thought negative gearing was terrific. Let me explain to the listeners what negative gearing means. A Qantas airline pilot on $100,000 came to my office and said: `Abolition of negative gearing is wicked. I have a block of flats. The interest I pay on that is $80,000 to $100,000 a year. I write the interest payments on that block of flats off against my salary and that allows me to engage in further investment which will allow me to provide rental accommodation for many Australian citizens'. I then said: `Captain, how much income tax have you paid in the last 10 years?'. He smiled and said: `None'. The Liberals opposed the abolition of this practice; yet they have talked in this place about morality and equity. It is a sort of philosophy that I just cannot follow.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has locked itself into delivering $6 billion worth of tax cuts by July 1987. It has imposed on itself the restraint of the trilogy, which has been scoffed at by the Liberals but which to me is a commendable effort to restrict government expenditure, government revenue and the size of the domestic deficit. I say and the Australian Democrats say that we must allow the Government of this country that bit of flexibility it needs in the delivery of such promises-one month, two months or three months if it needs them-before introducing the good side of tax reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank heavens for John Siddons. He introduced this.

—We are in the last week of this session. This is the third successive week of sitting and the only reason-a pathetic reason-the Liberals are taking up two hours of the time of the Senate this afternoon is that they are trying to drive a wedge among members of the Australian Democrats. We are very flattered that the once great Liberal Party should descend to such an exercise. We are flattered that the once great Liberal Party should pay the Australian Democrats such a glowing tribute.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian economy is in crisis; there is no doubt about that. I have seen terrifying predictions for the future. The terms of trade have turned dramatically against us. It is now a matter of Australia versus the rest of the world. That is how serious the situation is. I have heard of a report, which I cannot authenticate, that unless something drastic is done quickly the value of the Australian dollar could fall to 55c or lower. I just point out the implications of that, although I do not wish to score political points. If that happens, could there be a further run on the dollar? What will happen to Australia then? We may have a visit from those little gnomes in Zurich, the representatives of the International Monetary Fund, who will say: `We will lend you the money to get out of it, but you have to cut your social services by one-third, reduce wages by one-half and stop spending on the States. That means that you are in the situation of a banana republic. It is not rhetoric any more; you are there'. I believe and the Democrats believe that that is how serious the situation is. We believe that in such a circumstance the Government has to have the flexibility to manoeuvre. It has to be able to negotiate with the trade unions-something which, unfortunately, the Liberal Party never could do but which this Government at least has done with the wage discounting and the wages accord, probably one of the great economic achievements of the century.

The Opposition now wants the tax cuts it did its best to undermine. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has given me a written guarantee that the tax cuts will be in place on or before 1 December. The current economic crisis confronting Australia is in large part due to the private foreign borrowings undertaken when Mr Fraser was Prime Minister and Senator Sir John Carrick was Minister for Resources and Energy. I hope that when he speaks next he will tell the people of Australia how he could justify himself by talking up the resources boom that never happened. I sat in this Senate day after day when he organised dorothy dixers to talk up the mineral boom. Figures of scores of billions of dollars were mentioned by Senator Sir John Carrick in those days. We are now suffering from the borrowings that were a consequence of his talking up of that resources boom, borrowings which have increased our foreign indebtedness to crisis point.

I make an appeal to members of the Liberal Party. This country is in a devastating condition. It is almost academic to say that it is their fault or our fault or whatever. The fact is that we are in trouble, yet all the Liberal Party can do is play petty, vulgar politics at the expense of Australians. Mr Fraser won the 1980 election because he promised us a resources boom. Is Senator Sir John Carrick going to say that on the hustings then he did not talk up the resources boom? Is Senator Sir John Carrick going to say that he never ever promised that in future years there would be scores of billions of dollars of investment and sales of resources? We are now living with the consequences of the fact that that boom was a mirage.

What will the Liberal Party do to stop foreign money being used to finance takeovers? What is its policy on that? Its policy is to support foreign money coming into this country. Let me give honourable senators an example. An Australian company, worth $100m, earns $10m in profits a year. Someone borrows $100m from overseas, brings it into Australia and takes over that Australian company. He then pays interest to the overseas lender of $10m a year. The company was earning profits of $10m. So that company now pays no tax. Our overseas debt has increased by $100m, which has to be paid for by exports. This is supported by the Liberal Party. What do we see for it? We see an increase in our overseas debt, a further strain on the dollar and the country being sold out to foreign interests. Sometimes I cannot believe that this is the Party of which I was once a member. It is breathtaking hypocrisy for Liberal Party members to come into this chamber now and say: `Government, we have opposed all the means that are at your disposal to finance these tax cuts, but now we have failed in doing that, you must bring about the tax cuts immediately'. That is an attitude of utter, total irresponsibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would perhaps not think that we were doing so, but we are debating an urgency motion, put forward by the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, that there is an imperative need for the Government to deliver its promised personal income tax cuts from 1 September. One would believe that a government, having given a clear undertaking in its Budget that it would give those income tax cuts, would do so. One would think that the Australian Democrats, who keep saying that they are going to keep us honest, would support our motion because all we are saying is that the Government should keep its Budget promise. Very snidely, neither the speaker for the Australian Labor Party, Senator Maguire, nor the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, debated the subject at all. Each pretended that, because the Opposition opposed the fringe benefits tax, the entertainment tax and the capital gains tax, there would be less revenue. I make it very clear, not only to the Senate but to every member of the community, that the revenue is now enshrined in legislation. The Labor Party got its legislation because of the Democrats. So there is no decline in revenue at all due to the opposition of the Liberal and National parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Every time an employee pays higher taxes in the form of the fringe benefits tax which the Democrats have passed on, he should remember that it was seven Australian Democrats who brought it about. Every time people pay more rent for their rented properties-the poor people of Australia-they should remember that it was the seven Australian Democrats who brought about the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax.

The argument is very simple. The Government said: `On 1 September we will give you tax cuts amounting on average to $9 a week'. It said it would do this by bringing in a series of taxes. It has brought in those taxes. Let nobody believe, from the attempts to deflect the argument, that those taxes have not been brought in. They have been brought in, despite the Opposition's attempt to stop them. The Government made a promise. I put it quite emphatically: The tax cuts ought not to be negotiable. If we are to have good faith between the government of the day and the working community-the pay as you earn taxpayers-it is imperative that there should be a bargain which is kept. The arrangement was very clear. There would be tax cuts from 1 September, tax cuts that were absolutely vital because inflation had harvested far and away more taxes than should have been paid. The tax cuts were to be some kind of reparation for the effects of inflation. The only argument that has been put up by the Government in this debate has been that put up by Senator Maguire, who said: `The Government may have to defer the tax cuts because there has been a fall in the price of primary products'. I quote from the Budget:
A marked deterioration in the terms of trade is expected, reflecting primarily the relative weakness of world prices for our commodity based exports.

I remind the Senate that the figure given to the Government then by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics for the decline in agricultural prices was what the Budget and the tax cuts were based on. We were fortunate in one respect. As prices went down, the seasons were still bountiful and a larger volume of commodities was available. Let the Government not talk nonsense tomorrow night when it makes its economic statement and say that we have to defer the tax cuts because there is a deterioration in the terms of trade. The Budget and the tax cuts were based on a deterioration in the terms of trade. One thing is clear: Neither the Labor Party nor the Democrats can say that the Government cannot give the tax cuts now because of the terms of trade or because the Government does not have the revenue. The revenue is in place, thanks to the Democrats.

The ugliest aspect of the matter is this: There is a very serious recession in Australia. The Labor Party, and presumably the Democrats, are arguing that people will have to take cuts in their living standards. I cannot think of a more negative proposal for the Government to take to the people, after having said for three or four years that everything was rosy. People do not have to take cuts in their living standards if they understand what is happening, if they are given the correct incentives and if management and employees are given help to work more co-operatively. The Government must get off their backs and, fundamentally, tax relief must be given to the employee. The basis of any kind of consensus for the community must be the tax cuts on 1 September. If the Government is to say to the community, at whatever level, be it working people, be it managerial people or others, `You must practise some restraint', the first thing it has to do is to keep good faith itself.

The Government has to consider matters such as deferring the productivity case and the superannuation case. The Government is arguing that there should be some discounting of wages. The Australian Council of Trade Unions is saying that it will not put up with any discounting of wages. How can the Government possibly say that wages must be discounted and at the same time put taxes up?

What the Democrats and the Labor Party are doing is putting up taxes on 1 September. If the tax cuts are deferred, the Democrats will be taking $9 a week out of every taxpayer's pocket, a little matter of $117 over 13 weeks. But they will do more than that. The Democrats will have put people into higher tax brackets. Let no one misunderstand this. Any deferral of the tax cuts will be because the Democrats have become too expensive for the Australian public to wear any more. It is not just the Labor Party. One expects from the Labor Party a socialist grab. Senator Chaney has pointed out the enormous extra expenditure this Government has indulged in, the enormous extra amount of taxation that has been reaped by this Government. That is to be expected from socialists. What must be understood is that a bargain was made between the Democrats and the Labor Party, a fiddle which went something like this: The Democrats said to the Government: `If you give us a little dance in the sun on a minor matter such as relief for the motor trade, we are willing to punish every taxpayer in Australia'. That was the bargain. `Let us dance in the sun in a glib little way and pretend we have solved the automotive industry's problems', although the automotive industry has said it has done nothing of the kind. The price for that is a letter from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Government is willing to punish every Australian. For what reason? Not because we have not got the revenue from the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax or the entertainment tax, as indeed Senator Maguire and Senator Chipp were trying to imply, and not because the Government has not postulated this Budget on a very seriously deteriorating primary industry-indeed it had postulated it on the precise forecasts from the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

What is the reason behind this? If indeed there is a slippage of tax for three months it means that, instead of the Government having to work to cut expenditure in order to reduce the deficit, the Australian Democrats will have put up the taxes of all the Australian people to fix the deficit. The Democrats, by moving this amendment that no doubt will be carried by the Australian Labor Party today, because they are twin souls, have made a bargain to put up taxes by $9 a week, which will also put many people into higher tax brackets. That is the broad picture. That is against a situation of the Government saying through Senator Maguire: `Look at the wonderful things we have done'. The Government forgot to mention that under the Whitlam Government inflation soared to nearly 20 per cent and wages were put up in 18 months by 37 per cent. The present Prime Minister, who was then the Federal leader of the Labor Party and, indeed, the leader of the ACTU said: `I know that this will put up inflation, but I don't care, I am going to bargain for higher wages'. That is the same person who today is urging restraint from people. This is the same person that the Democrats are supporting.

At the moment Australia has a grossly adverse balance of trade, a symptom of too high costs of production. There is a pretence that this is caused solely by a fall in export earnings for primary industry and minerals. That is a nonsense pretence. On the other side of the balance, the costs of production are so high, with devaluation and everything else taken into account, that we cannot resist a flood of imports coming into this country, so we are pouring out our money to pay for imports and we cannot earn as much for exports. That is what is happening. The Government that tried to make a virtue of devaluing the dollar by 30 per cent is the Government that has put up costs in Australia everywhere because of imports being loaded by 30 per cent.

The Government is trying to say to the employers now: `Please, we want to help you by a device. We will give you some kind of incentive. We would like you to borrow. Perhaps we will subsidise interest rates'. What a nonsense when at the same time, through Senator Chipp's Australian Democrats' support for the Labor Party, the Government has put imposts onto manufacturing of an enormous kind. It has imposed a fringe benefits tax impost, a capital gains impost and an entertainment tax impost on to the manufacturing people of Australia. That will do two things: Firstly, it will increase costs, which will create unemployment and, secondly, it will drive more imports into Australia and further aggravate the balance of trade. These are the people who are getting up today and saying: `No, we won't support the promise in the Budget'. It is a promise which was perfectly clear. There is no argument about it. It was in two bits. Who knows when the second promise will ever be kept? Senator Chipp says: `I have got it in writing'. Well, I say to Senator Chipp that I have it in printed form in terms of the Budget, and that is the promise that is being broken and that is the promise that Senator Chipp is conniving in breaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —You talked up the resources boom. That is in print.

—The honourable senator can interrupt as much as he likes. The promise that is being broken is in printed form and Senator Chipp is in fact breaking it. The fact of the matter is that what we are debating today--
—Deny it. Deny you talked up the resources boom.

—I am not going to take these diversions from Senator Chipp. He is interjecting strongly because he cannot deny this. He cannot deny that, by his action, from 1 September every taxpayer in Australia will be denied $9 a week; that is $117 over 13 weeks. Many taxpayers in Australia will be moved into higher tax brackets. Through the fringe benefits tax being passed down to the workers and paid by them they will pay higher taxes. Every sacking because the employer cannot pay is directly due to the bargain made between the Democrats and the Labor Party. The Democrats are the people today who are standing up and saying: `No tax cuts on 1 September; let us have them on 1 December. Let us break our promises'. This is the party that said: `Let's keep them honest'. Goodness gracious, `let's keep them dishonest' should have been their phrase because that is what they have done. I think the saddest thing is the way the Democrats have sold any principles they have had.
—I said `Let's keep the bastards honest', and I was talking about people like you and the resources boom.

—I think the honourable senator said: `Let's keep the bastards honest'. Let's keep them honest. When referring to the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), why should he not be honest? Why should not the honourable senator be honest? The honourable senator supported the Budget Speech. If he wants honesty, I say `First of all, physician, heal thyself'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are few occasions in the Senate when we have genuine surprises and fewer occasions when there is a genuine sense of humour brought into this chamber. I must admit that the motion before us today encompasses both. The first, I guess, in terms of surprises, is that it is surprising indeed to all of us who sit in this chamber that the current Opposition should bring before us today a motion which criticises this Government, of all governments, for tardiness in bringing in tax reform. This comes from an Opposition which when it was in government, when a significant number of people on the other side of the House were Ministers of that Government, was unable to come to grips at all with the massive problem of restructuring tax reform in this country.
—They had a majority in both Houses.

—They had a majority in both Houses, and to the eternal shame of that particular government, of those members of the Liberal-National Party government of the day, they were unable to fulfil any of the promises they made about taxation reform in this country. They were the only ones who had the clear way right through the Senate and the House of Representatives, and they were unable to deliver. Yet they come into this chamber today with all the hypocrisy, and with what I imagine is a sly sense of humour, and put this motion before us, accusing this Government of being tardy because it has taken a financially and fiscally prudent approach towards the Government of this country and the handling of the economy and might delay the promised tax reforms until the end of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at those opposite during the time we have been in government. What have they opposed? They have a great record of opposition. They are very good at opposing. They have opposed everything positive that this Government has brought before the Australian public by way of tax reform. They have opposed a broad based consumption tax. Initially John Howard supported it and then they backed off it. They opposed the Australia Card. Two weeks or so before the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card brought down its findings, John Howard came out against that card. He did not have the decency or the objectivity to wait until that report had been tabled in this House. He came out and bagged it right from the start-a major component of the tax reform package being brought forward by the Government of this country. When this Government attempted to do something about bottom of the harbour tax avoidance, when this Government attempted to get into the various schemes to prevent all the entrepreneurs in the tax avoidance industry from continuing to have their way, as they have over the last decade or so in this country, what did this Opposition do? The Opposition did nothing. It opposed it on the spurious ground that retrospectivity is a poor principle to bring into any form of legislation. The Opposition has opposed fringe benefit taxes-the broadest types of fringe benefits taxes, ranging from the use of cars to the whole question of free lunches. For whom did Opposition members oppose such taxes? They did it in the interests of industries they supposedly represent. They have opposed the capital gains tax. Everywhere down the line when this Government has attempted to bring in tax reform, Opposition members have opposed it in this place.

What was the coalition Government's record when it was in office? It was forced to do something about tax reform-and I use the word `forced' quite deliberately. That happened only after a significant number of reports came before the public at large and before various State and Federal governments to say that nothing was being done about the tax rorts that were becoming endemic. I refer to the McCabe-Lafranchi tax avoidance report, the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and numerous reports from within the Auditor-General's Department and the Australian Taxation Office all telling the same story. What was the response? Slothful action on the part of those relevant Ministers; inaction and apathy. That was their record in government.

When the previous Government finally did enact some legislation federally, what did we see? We saw a backing off from the proposals that came before this Parliament. Following the Mathews Committee of Inquiry into Inflation and Taxation, what happened to trading stock and valuation adjustment? It was introduced and then dropped. The general avoidance provisions were improved somewhat, and I will give the coalition Government some credit there. The broadly based indexed tax arrangements on which the Australian-Taxation Office reported in favour was quietly dropped by Cabinet, much to John Howard's chagrin. Indexation of personal income tax was introduced and then dropped-more fumbles than St Kilda on a wet day; that is their record in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Steady on, are you talking about the football?

—I am talking about the football team. I can think of no team that would be a better example of the way the Liberal Party handled taxation reform when in government. I turn briefly to the Australian Democrats' amendment and indicate that the Government finds that amendment appropriate for this debate. We find that amendment a fair and objective re-arrangement of the motion and we shall be supporting it.

SPEECH.PARA: What are this country's problems in regard to taxation reforms? First, there is the question of straight-out, illegal tax evasion, which has been a growth industry since the 1970s. Around $3,000m is lost each year through tax evasion. There has been straight law-breaking, which does not include tax avoidance through minimisation of income in legal ways that slightly alter the spirit of the Income Tax Assessment Act. No effort was made over the years by previous governments to break that vicious circle whereby the tax avoiders increasingly put the burden on other people in the community, especially pay as you earn taxpayers. No effort has been made by previous governments to ensure that ordinary taxpayers do not move into higher levels of marginal tax rates simply because of the effluxion of time and the effort of inflation.

Currently some two million of the 5,500,000 full time workers face a tax rate of 46c in the dollar. Within two and a half years that number will have increased by more than one million, unless something is done about it at this stage. That is what this Government's tax reform package is all about.

Nothing has been done about the widespread use of the act of incorporation by individuals in business to avoid paying higher tax. I understand that Australia is now one of the most incorporated countries in the world, in that more private individuals in business seek to incorporate themselves as companies to avoid paying the higher rates of personal income tax that prevail. When the company tax is only 46c in the dollar and the top marginal rate in the personal area is about 60c in the dollar, then obviously the motivation to incorporate oneself as a businessman is always there. But the planned cuts to be brought in later this year will bring that tax rate up to 49c in the dollar for companies and bring the highest marginal tax rate for personal taxation down to 49c in the dollar, thus in a sense enduring that the motivation for people to incorporate themselves in future is lessened.

This Government has promised a number of tax reforms-major reforms and major structural reforms. I will briefly go through these because they have tended to be lost in the debate that has ensued in the community at large as people have debated particular reforms that have come through. The tax scales themselves will be altered at the end of this year in a way that will bring immediate benefit to all taxpayers in the community and will make it of no value at all, or of little value for people to incorporate themselves in the way in which they have in the past. I shall quickly read some of the changes as outlined by the Government. On 1 September 1986, towards the end of the year, the amount which people can earn tax free--

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't know that yet.

—We can assume that that will be the case. The amount which people can earn tax free will go up from $4,595 to $5,100 per year, and all the tax rates will be cut to bring in a new scale. That scale will move from nil dollars to $5,100 per annum, which will involve nil taxation, through to 55c in the dollar taxation for those on $35,000 and above. The point that many people in the community have forgotten, given the nature of the debate that has been going on, is that in July 1987 the cuts will be completed. The 43c and 46c in the dollar rates will be reduced to 40c and the 55c rate will be cut to 49c. Those are major cuts for people in the middle and higher income brackets, in addition to the cuts that have already been made for those people who have been on the lower income level over the last three years.

SPEECH.PARA: What else has the Government done? As a Government we have brought in associated fringe benefits tax, and I use that as a generic term. There has been an attack on the system by this Government whereby higher income earners have opted for fringe benefits such as golf club membership, cars, entertainment, holidays in lieu of higher salaries and other forms of benefits in lieu of higher salaries, all of which have left the ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers totally disadvantaged compared with those who have been in a privileged position. There has been a mild capital gains tax, and establishment of the principle that most people in this chamber would share, some in principle and some in practice, that both income and capital should be taxed at some stage or another. In effect that will ensure that the sort of investment that previously went away from the earning of income and in various ways into capital, to make a long term capital gain and not to pay tax on it, will end. In effect, that will ensure that the sort of investment that should go into productive industry, creating jobs and helping our export industries will occur rather than go into areas one would regard as irrelevant to our present economic position.

We have looked at the prescribed payments tax that operates in certain industries such as the building, cleaning and transport industries. Those with a responsible tax record can apply to have that rate lowered where appropriate. It can be seen as a major attack on the black or cash economy-a move which has not been made in the past in any effective way. Imputation of company tax is an attempt to overcome the difficulties people face when they have the courage and propensity for risk to invest in companies in this country. Such people will no longer be double taxed as has happened in the past. Those have all been solid taxation reform achievements, coupled with this major change in the tax scales.

What is the main aim? It is to ensure that we have a tax system that is fair and equitable, in which we all have confidence, in which a significant number of wealthy people do not absolve themselves of any responsibility in this area, and a tax system that is not a burden on the back of the average Australian taxpayer. As part of that whole process this Government has brought in a concept commonly known as the trilogy, which has not received the discussion it should have received in the community at large, but a part of which is a very important promise that there will be no increase in taxation revenue as a proportion of gross domestic product. That in itself is one of the major promises and policies that can be put into operation by any government. The Liberal and National parties have tended to forget it, for reasons of their own in the last few years.

Finally, I turn to the talking up of the economy which occurred in the period 1980-81 and the latter part of 1982. It is significant and rather ironic that Senator Sir John Carrick, who preceded me in this debate, I guess carrying out the brief of the day as the relevant Minister for the Fraser Government, was one of those people very much responsible for talking up the economy. He was very much responsible for indicating that there was to be a resources boom that would lift this country out of the slough of despair and despondency that it was in during the Fraser period. Day after day he answered questions in this House in an effort quietly to talk up the economy. He did it with slightly more aplomb than his rather unimaginative Prime Minister, but he did it nevertheless. What happened? What was the net result? In this country private enterprise went and borrowed off-shore to invest-in many cases in unproductive areas. What else happened? Public enterprise went out and borrowed. There were infrastructure borrowings for dams, roads, ports and all those sorts of areas. What was the net result? Our overseas debt increased dramatically during that period. If we are looking for a cause for the decay of this economy and the structural imbalances of this economy--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that I am hitting the nail right on the head, judging by the reaction from my colleagues opposite. If we are looking for the major cause of the problems that are facing this country now we must look to the irresponsible talking up of the economy that occurred during that period under the leadership of the very people who sit opposite us today and who had the gall to move this motion we are debating this afternoon. For that reason the Government rejects the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Aulich commenced his speech by talking about needing a sense of humour and saying that he had a sense of surprise in regard to the motion put before the Senate today by the Opposition. I must express some surprise at some of the statements made by Senator Aulich, in particular his last comment about the talking up of the economy. We would not be having any public debate on the economy at the moment if the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) had not, in the absence of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in China, brought forward the seriousness of the state of the Australian economy instead of the rhetoric we have been hearing over the past three years about the world's greatest Treasurer and what had been achieved simply by a change of government.

SPEECH.PARA: In referring to some of the remarks made by Senator Aulich, I have to express surprise at the fact that he took exception to the Opposition's having opposed a capital gains tax. My strong recollection is of the present Prime Minister solemnly assuring the Australian people that there would be no capital gains tax. That statement was made by the Prime Minister for some electoral advantage. It was a statement of electoral opportunism. It should not surprise Senator Aulich that we opposed the capital gains tax because throughout the whole of the last election campaign that opposition was one of the planks of the Opposition's policy. It rests rather oddly with Senator Aulich's understanding of the position not to recall that it was the Prime Minister also who promised that there would be no capital gains tax.

Senator Aulich also took exception to the fact that we opposed a broadly-based tax. There is a history in regard to that. When in government the present Opposition looked at that matter and did not proceed with it. Again, I find it somewhat odd that Senator Aulich should not remember that Mr Keating could not get his preferred option through either his Cabinet or his Caucus. Again, it was the Prime Minister who scuttled the Treasurer on the preferred option in regard to a broadly-based tax. That was abandoned by the Government itself, not because of the Opposition's attitude to it. It was a government decision that it was not timely to go ahead with the preferred option of the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were part of the community reaction, too.

— We are part of the community reaction. The Prime Minister read the community reaction, scuttled the Treasurer and left him standing without his broadly-based tax. The other matter of surprise in Senator Aulich's remarks to which I take exception concerns the Australia Card. Those of us who have followed the debate and the discussion on this will remember that Senator Aulich could not even get a majority of those who sat on the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card investigating this matter to agree with him that an Australia Card ought to be introduced in this country. I can understand why the Government has taken the decision to introduce it. This is not because any of the departments that advise the Government have given it positive advice on the matter. I remember that over the five years in which I was Social Security Minister and Minister for Finance I saw plenty of advice on this matter. Therefore, I can understand why the Government will seek to introduce the Australia Card. When putting together the Budget figures, the introduction of an Australia Card would allow a government to say that, of course, expenditure on social security benefits and pensions will be reduced by so many hundreds of millions of dollars and that tax revenues will be increased. With reference to talk earlier about rubbery figures in a Budget, I would challenge any figures, showing either savings in expenditure or increases in revenue, based on the introduction of an Australia Card. Those matters just cannot add positively to the Budget that will have to be brought in this year and to what needs to be done positively in the interests of Australia's economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased that there is a public debate. I await with interest, as I am sure do all Australians, the statement of the Prime Minister tomorrow night. However, the Opposition felt that it was timely to move this motion of urgency concerning the imperative need for the Government to deliver its promised personal income tax cuts by 1 September. The words `work, save and invest' used by the Opposition as part of its motion were used by the present Federal Treasurer when he introduced tax measures in September last year. The words `work, save and invest' probably are the most important words that ought to be addressed in Australia at present.

Senator Maguire claimed that Labor is the low tax party in Australia. That statement sits rather oddly, despite the rhetoric, with what the actual figures show. In real terms, tax revenue has increased at an annual rate of 5.4 per cent in the three years of the Hawke Government compared with an annual rate of 3.3 per cent during the seven years of the Fraser Government. If that is a low tax party, it certainly is not giving the results that it claims to give. Tax receipts as a percentage of gross domestic product were budgeted to increase 25 per cent in 1984-85-the highest in post-war history. They have averaged 24.5 per cent under Hawke compared with 23.4 per cent under Fraser. I think those figures speak for themselves. We need also to look at Government expenditure in real terms. Any party that claims to be a low tax party also has to be a low spending party. We have found, however, that Government expenditure has increased in real terms by 4.8 per cent per year under Hawke compared with only 2.1 per cent per year under Fraser. I hope that these figures will be addressed in any statement made by the Government in the light of the present economic crisis. When we find that Government expenditure as a percentage of gross domestic product is budgeted to increase to 29.4 per cent in this Budget year-the highest in post-war history-and we find that it has averaged 29.9 per cent in the three Hawke Government years compared with 27.7 per cent in the seven Fraser Government years, we need to ask where the Government priorities are in dealing with what is undoubtedly a very sick economy.

Senator Chipp made some statement about the fiscal effect of the tax cuts. In his amendment he is asking the Government to be fiscally responsible about the date of their introduction. It can be only semantics to believe that there are difficulties in dealing with a promise that tax cuts will be introduced on 1 September and their deferral until 1 December at the latest. It must be recalled that the tax proposal was brought forward as part of a trilogy and to shore up the prices and incomes accord. The introduction of tax cuts on 1 September was in effect to hold the accord. A tax cut of about $9 a week was promised. It was said that none of these tax cuts would be financed by adding to the deficit. The Australian worker and the pay as you earn wage and salary earner, about whom we have been hearing today, must ask why, if the Government promised solemnly as part of the accord that they would not be financed by adding to the deficit, the Government now has to back away and why we cannot have the tax cuts that were promised at the time and in the way in which the Government promised them.

I hoped today to have time to talk about some other matters, in particular the foreign debt which has been mentioned by some honourable senators who claim that by talking up an investment boom in this country somehow we added to the foreign debt. It is rather salutary to see that Australia's foreign debt-that is, the amount we owe to foreigners in other countries-has risen dramatically under the Hawke Government and is approaching alarming levels. This Government has been in office for over three years and the foreign debt totalled around $35 billion when it took office in 1983. The latest official figures for September 1985 show that it is at $70 billion; that is, our foreign debt doubled in only 2 1/2 years under the Hawke Government. To put that in figures that people might understand, to completely pay off our foreign debt would require $6,000 to be taken from every man, woman and child in this country. That is the seriousness of the foreign debt and that is the situation in which we find ourselves at present in trying to deal with an economy that has the terms of trade that it has and has the other difficulties that have been mentioned about the balances of payments and other things. I will not have time to discuss those matters now.

The general economic conditions are by far the most important to consider. Overshadowing all else are the high and rising production costs which render Australia seriously uncompetitive, whether in seeking to export or in attempting to resist the flood of imports. Many of these costs are caused or influenced by governments. Senator Sir John Carrick has done a great deal of work on these matters; possibly he did not have time to refer to them. However, one of the points that he has made is that, unless all governments are willing conscientiously to examine all costs imposed by them which are impacting on small business and other business and to reduce or eliminate all except those strictly necessary, economic recovery will be severely retarded. It is all very well for Senator Maguire or others to talk about the fall in production costs. No one argues that there may be some containment in production costs, but we are talking about what ought to be competitive costs; not a fall from an all time high, not a fall from something that is uncompetitive but something that was referred to by Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon when he made a submission on these matters and said:
. . . it is necessary to keep educating portions of the community to an understanding of the advantages of the material gains inherent in a more co-operative productive society.
I do not think anyone would argue about that. Charlie Fitzgibbon continued:

It should be understood that an Australian worker does not get greater pay than his German/Japanese or American counterpart, in most cases he gets less and total labour costs per employee are generally less, but it is in the bottom line figure at the end of the day as to productive cost that shows the difference in result per dollar.

That is the point that needs to be made: Do not just measure a fall in production costs against our own production costs but rather compare out production costs, out unit costs, with that of any other person with whom we must compete, with that of any other country with which we must compete on the world market, or indeed on the Australian market. I again quote Charlie Fitzgibbon:

Since Australian workers can compare with the workers of any country, it might surprise just how much productivity could be improved if the workforce understood that the increase in productivity was going to result in an increase in their security or award while not prejudicing their safety or principle.

Surely that is part of the matter that must be addressed as we look at production costs and productivity increases which we seek. I have mentioned that all governments have a responsibility for this. The charges that government makes for electricity, freight, water rates, land taxes, municipal and shire rates, payroll tax and the cost of the Public Service in this country surely must give us reason to be concerned about how we can become more competitive and how our production costs can be reduced. The word `investment' is in our motion of urgency today. I would like to quote the most recent media release of the National Australia Bank, which states:
AUSTRALIA MUST IMPROVE INVESTMENT
CLIMATE
National Australia Bank has warned that unless there is an improvement in Australia's investment climate, firms will take their capital expenditure plans elsewhere.
. . . Australian companies have been rapidly increasing their direct investment in offshore locations.
The Bank says that this reluctance to invest in Australia has occurred despite higher than average economic growth and near doubling of the funds available for investment over the past five years.
The problem of restoring business confidence, the Bank says, is compounded by six-monthly wage indexation which tends to perpetuate boom/bust cycles in economic activity.
It suggests that the present system of wage indexation be made more flexible so that changes in trading conditions and award wages can be more closely matched.
It is not surprising that the National Australia Bank finishes its media release by stating:
Similarly government should not restrict investment, either through ``crowding out'' as a result of deficit spending, or excessive regulation . . .

That brings me to the only other point I could make: I express the hope, as does the Opposition, that the Government will address the matters that are of grave importance in the economy and that it will look at ways in which it can give incentives for people to work, to save and to invest. This will be the only way in which, by working together, we can retrieve this country from its severe economic recession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, with supreme impudence, has moved this urgency motion, which claims there is a need for the Government to deliver its promised personal income tax cuts from 1 September, which goes on to encourage the men and women of Australia to work, save and invest and which, finally, uses those points to refer to national economic recovery. Senator Maguire has clearly established the basis of national economic recovery under this Government. He has pointed out, I think absolutely correctly, that what is needed is a national economic recovery from the Liberal years of government. I think this urgency motion is a bit impudent because it raises some of the issues, such as work, that it has been the Labor Government's prerogative to deal with after the Fraser years. No Liberal Party member can talk about work when, in that Party's final year, it put 200,000 people on to the scrap heap. The Opposition even used an expression which should be associated with the Australian Labor Party-perhaps the Liberal Party should be prevented from using it-and that is the `men and women of Australia' expression. Gough Whitlam used that expression and made it famous when, after 23 years of conservative rule, he appealed to all Australians to work together to change the system we had in 1972.

SPEECH.PARA: At every level the Liberal-National Party Opposition has no right to take the credit for the economic prosperity that exists in this country. Of course, the key to that prosperity is the accord between the trade unions and the Government, something that would be impossible for the Opposition to achieve under any circumstances. The contrast we have is between a patriotic and positive government and a patriotic and responsible trade union movement seeking to establish in the national interest the best position for all Australians. The opposition that has been expressed in the debate today came from the sleazy, backsliding Opposition, which faces several directions on a number of issues. I propose to show, as others have shown, that the Opposition faces different ways almost at the same time. Senator Chipp and Senator Aulich have already drawn attention to the contradictions that exist in what the Opposition says and does on so many topics.

For a moment I want to talk about integrity because, as I have said, the Opposition has no integrity to bring into this debate; with its record, it has no right even to raise the matters. I want to talk about the integrity of the Government and the trade union movement. I think that integrity has been established. I particularly want to refer to the integrity of the trade union movement because for a moment I almost thought that the Opposition had actually discovered wage and salary earners. It is still not absolutely clear whether it is sympathetic to them because just as Senator Chaney, I think, adverted to them Senator Sir John Carrick reminded us of the preoccupation of the Liberal Party of Australia with the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax

I refer to the sacrifices which have been made already by wage and salary earners through their organisation, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The concessions by wage and salary earners included the acceptance of the consumer price index for the March and June quarters of 1983 as the starting point of a new indexation system; the acceptance of the deferral of a 9.1 per cent catch-up claim reflecting the period of the wages freeze; the acceptance and deferral of tax reductions, in the absence of tax indexation, in the 1983-84 Budget; the acceptance of the Medicare-affected CPI figure for wage fixing purposes, involving the reduction of published CPI figures by 2.5 per cent; the acceptance of the accord's no extra claims commitment over the duration of the current centralised system; in the context of the 1983 national wage case decision, the acceptance of prohibition on the productivity claim; and, in the context of the September 1985 ACTU-Government agreement, the acceptance of wage discounting of 1.73 per cent, acceptance of moderation, deferral and phasing-in of the productivity claim, acceptance of the delay from April 1986 to September 1986 of the tax cuts offset and acceptance of six-monthly indexation hearings. These are the actual contributions of wage and salary earners through their trade union movement. That demonstrates the integrity of the trade union movement. I do not know what the results of the negotiations will be between the Government and the trade union movement, but, if there are any concessions by the trade union movement, I am sure they will be based on protecting existing jobs and promoting employment in this country, and that is of no thanks to the discredited Opposition in this chamber.

We have a situation in which, but for the co-operation of the trade union movement, the Government would not have the economic success that it has had until this point. To that extent, I acknowledge that the Democrats' amendment is far more effective in dealing with this problem. It allows for the flexibility which one would accept when we, at a national level, have a crisis. Even Senator Chaney said: `Nobody denies that we are facing an economic crisis'. He also referred to getting people back to work. Of course, we cannot help hearing the other things which have been said in the debate. Senator Peter Baume from the Opposition was the one person who agreed with Senator Chipp that the negative gearing proposals which flourished for so long under the Fraser Government were immoral. Senator Chipp was referring to a typically immoral example.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you be accurate?

—I am completely accurate because Senator Chipp was saying that he knew of an airline pilot who was using negative gearing and had not paid tax for 10 years. The Opposition fails to take into consideration the fact that people do understand that the Opposition has not put together a package. After all, everybody has talked about a package in the Labor movement. The Government and the trade unions understand that it is difficult to set priorities. This Opposition cannot set priorities. Today's motion reflects that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney had the audacity to refer to ever growing government expenditure. I want to refer to the sorts of things on which Senator Walsh has pinned down the Opposition time and again, and that is the promises of the Opposition to increase government expenditure. The Opposition has to be called to account for its dishonest attitude towards taxation issues and the resulting Budget decisions. Opposition promises, if implemented, would add a further $1.4 billion a year to government spending. When these promises are combined with Opposition taxation policies, it is clear that the overall effect of these promises of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and his colleagues would be to double the Budget. I will detail the many Opposition expenditures and taxation promises, showing their full year effects in 1985-86. These particular policies would add in excess of $1.4 billion to outlays and cost revenue approximately $3.7 billion. The net effect would be to increase the Budget deficit by more than $5 billion.

It is such a long list that it is difficult to outline in such a short time the full expenditure, but Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has spurred me on by referring to electoral opportunism. The electoral opportunism of this Opposition knows no bounds. For example, the ever-growing expenditure which Senator Chaney referred to would add $600m to the expenditure on tertiary education for unemployment benefit recipients. The additional expenditure on defence would be $234m. the additional expenditure on health would be $167m. The repeal of the assets test would cost $140m. There is the provision of an immediate $100m advance for rural reconstruction for farm carry-on loans at concessional interest rates. There is the $240 per tonne floor price for sugar, which would amount to $75m. The abolition of export inspection charges would amount to $52m. The disallowance of freedom of information charges would amount to $5m. Income splitting-that is the big one for the Opposition-would amount to $1.9 billion, a figure the Opposition is not terribly happy about because it puts its weights up. The abolition of tax on new oil would amount to $480m. The abolition of the non-cash fringe benefits tax would amount to $320m. The reinstitution of the entertainment expenses allowance, which is one we have just dealt with, would amount to $310m. Child care rebates would amount to $180m. The abolition of fuel indexation would amount to $108m. The abolition of tax on lump sum superannuation would amount to $100m; and there is the abolition of sales tax on oils and lubricants. I could go on, but I feel I should finish at that point because my throat is getting sore from listing all the things which the Liberal Party has promised, at a time when it urges restraint on wage and salary earners in a general way, at a time when it has a very bad record, especially in the last couple of weeks, and, as has been said by a number of honourable senators including Senator Chipp, at a time when we were actually dealing with the fringe benefits tax. We have this list of vote buying bribes which the Opposition cynically projects into the community at a time when it is denying this Government the opportunity to have reasonable revenue.

I must mention the fringe benefits tax because a number of people have referred to it. It is the key thing. It is the most recent example of the Opposition's failure to give the Government the money which it should have. It did not force people of privilege to pay their fair share of the finance. The editorial, headed `The case for the fringe benefit tax', in the Australian Financial Review-not a radical journal-of Tuesday, 27 May stated:

What hard data we have on fringe benefits shows two things: the first is that fringe benefits rise with income; the second is that the number and type of benefits received are closely related to occupational status and industry.

Only a small and very select section of the workforce enjoys very substantial fringe benefits. This privileged category largely consists of people who are able to exercise considerable control over their own salary packages-

In conclusion, I must support Senator Chipp, who was attacked because he said that the Opposition's lack of credibility was further evidenced by the deficits in the boom years of the early 1980s. At the 1980 Premiers Conference the Loan Council approved, on Mr Fraser's insistence, total infrastructure borrowings over the decade of $4.7 billion to fund the exaggerated resources boom. That is the answer to Senator Sir John Carrick, whose political epitaph will be the massive deficit that existed under the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion which essentially calls on the Government to honour the very clear promise that it made to wage and salary earners in the last Budget. That is not a promise that was made by the Opposition. The present Government promised the wage and salary earners of Australia-it promised them in the Budget and it promised them in the accord-that in return for some of the concessions that Senator Childs outlined, they would get tax relief. The simple proposition that the Government should keep its word on tax relief does not have the support of the Government and the Australian Democrats. It is a pathetic indication of this Government's intentions that no Minister could rise and speak on this motion because no Minister would, of course, be in a position to give any sort of undertaking as to what tax cuts are going to be delivered to the wage and salary earners of Australia. This has been a pathetic demonstration of the unholy alliance between the Australian Democrats and the Government when it comes to breaking the promises that have been made to the people of Australia on taxes, whether it is breaking promises about the capital gains tax or breaking promises about relief for the wage and salary earners, who are groaning under the heaviest weight of taxation in Australia's history.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some doubt in my mind about the worth of debating any issue in this chamber, given the lack of regard for the truth which has been shown by Government speakers in this debate. I think it has been one of the most disgraceful exhibitions of untruthfulness that I have ever struck in my time in Parliament. Let me start with Senator Maguire, who, in a lack-lustre and undistinguished contribution to this debate, claimed that the Australian Labor Party was the low tax party. If Senator Maguire believes that Labor is a low tax party, how does he explain his own Government's Budget Papers which show that the last two Budgets of the Labor Party have taken a greater share of gross domestic product than any Budget in Australia's history? It is a pathetic misrepresentation of the facts and Senator Maguire should look at the facts before he makes ridiculous assertions in this place.

I found that a number of other contributions-but most of all, I think, Senator Aulich's- showed a total disregard for the truth and for what the facts are. Senator Aulich just made a series of totally wrong allegations in the course of his speech. For example, he claimed that there was instant opposition from us to the broad-based consumption tax in the tax package when in fact we never departed, publicly or privately, from our support for a broadening of the tax base. We disputed the idea that a 12 1/2 per cent consumption tax was a feasible thing to introduce, given the present state of the Australian economy. He said that we bagged the Australia Card before the report of the parliamentary committee was brought down. That is absolutely wrong. He referred to other matters in respect of which he simply paid no regard to the truth. I really found his whole contribution totally unsavoury.

Senator Chipp devoted a great deal of his speech to misrepresenting the Opposition's position on the rest of the tax package. Senator Chipp, who I would have thought after his time in this place would have some knowledge of facts, spent most of his time abusing Senator Sir John Carrick over the so-called resources boom. I can only say that if it were not for the investment in resources in the late 1970s and the early 1980s this country would be in very much greater difficulty than it is in today. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that from 1981-82 to 1984-85 exports of alumina, coal, iron ore and petroleum increased in value from a little over $5 billion to just under $10 billion. There was nearly a doubling in the value of exports in those areas over a three-year period at a time when the terms of trade were supposedly running against us.

The simple point that the Opposition wishes to make is that the people of Australia are entitled to tax cuts which have been promised to them by the Government. After all, it was the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who said, when he promised the tax cuts, that high marginal tax rates involved the most severe disincentive to work, saving and investment. Mr Deputy President, I think the way in which honourable senators vote will show once again the unholy alliance that exists between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats when it comes to robbing the people of Australia.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Chipp's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HARKINS INQUIRY INTO ABORIGINAL LEGAL AID

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The provision of legal services for Aboriginals is one of the great mechanisms for giving a fair go to Aboriginal people. It is one of the mechanisms for ensuring a chance of representation before the courts. It provides us with one of the few opportunities to give Aboriginals a greater chance for justice, to give them a greater chance of acquittal when they come before the courts. It is well known that those not represented are more likely to be convicted, and Aboriginal legal services, by representing Aboriginals have been able to reduce conviction rates. Aboriginal legal services help to empower Aboriginals.

But there are problems with the legal services.
