First, over the years they have failed to work within the budgets they have been given and have confronted various Ministers with demands for open-ended budgets to continue their work. Secondly, there has been a misuse and an abuse of the power conferred on those who run the Aboriginal legal services-those who accrete power to themselves-and sometimes there has been an abuse of power in that certain Aboriginals have not had legal services made available to them. In my time as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs both kinds of complaints were made known to me by different groups of disaffected Aboriginals.

As a result of these kinds of problems the present Minister, Mr Holding, saw fit to commission Mr Joseph Harkins to conduct an inquiry into Aboriginal legal aid. The report of the inquiry is a comprehensive document and I congratulate Mr Harkins on this his latest piece of work carried out on behalf of the Government. He did some work previously, when I was Minister, and that was equally excellent.

In the few minutes available I wish to draw attention to several of the recommendations, because they provide guidelines for the way in which Aboriginal legal services might work in the future. Recommendation 8 provides guidelines about which cases should get priority. Since there is not enough money to represent every case for every Aboriginal, Mr Harkins suggests that the legal services should formalise in their guidelines decisions and informal understandings about cases in which legal assistance will not ordinarily be provided, such as Aboriginal versus Aboriginal cases, routine offences attracting routine penalties, or repeated offences. He also refer to the requirement for a merit or means test in special circumstances. That seems to me to be a well-founded and sensible recommendation.

Recommendation 10 asks the legal services to concentrate their work on criminal matters and not to address civil cases or, if they do address them, to farm them out. Recommendations 22 and 23 enjoin the legal services to work in close conjunction with other legal aid agencies-something which from my experience of dealing with the legal services they were loth to do. It is something which is obviously necessary in view of the resources available and the size of the task to be carried out. The other recommendation to which I wish to draw the attention of honourable senators is recommendation 26, which suggests that, because any Aboriginal can avail himself or herself of the services of an Aboriginal legal service, consideration should be given to the introduction of a means test with a provision for contributions limited to substantial or costly matters. That is to say, where a very costly matter or one which is likely to be prolonged involves a wealthy or affluent Aboriginal-I remind honourable senators that there is now an emerging Aboriginal middle class in Australia-it is not inappropriate to seek a contribution from that person.

Legal services for Aboriginals are important, they are vital, but they do need to be well run. They probably need to be run more efficiently than they have been in the past. I do not want to see a repeat of the circumstances which faced me as Minister when it was my sad task to close down the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legal Service in Queensland and to reconstitute it as a series of local legal services. That was done because of a misuse of power within the ATSILS as it then existed. I do not want to see the budget confrontation that took place in New South Wales or which, for example, caused the Victorian Aboriginal Legal Service to close its doors rather than meet its budgetary constraints. This report offers some very constructive suggestions. I hope that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs gives them his careful and sympathetic consideration.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: MECHANISMS FOR TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER INTO AUSTRALIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Science and Technology Council Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Technological Change Committee of the Australian Science and Technology Council identifies five stages of technology transfer: Awareness; evaluation; acquisition; adaptation; and adoption and acceptance. They stress two overriding points: Firstly, we must develop our research and development capacity in Australia and our ability to handle technical information, otherwise we will be sold down the river on a regular basis. Secondly, we must become export oriented and look for opportunities abroad. ASTEC recommends that technology data bases and patent information be used to identify opportunities in a systematic manner, as is done in Japan, France and a number of other countries. For small businesses in particular this is necessary as they cannot rely on the chance reading of journals and do not have time to get the industrial intelligence they need.

ASTEC recommends that industry bodies be given funding to perform the gathering, collating and disseminating of information on industrial and technological matters. In Japan quite often a specific company board member is delegated the responsibility of dealing specifically with technological matters and the Japan Information Centre for Science and Technology is responsible for spreading knowledge to the appropriate enterprises in this way. The Swedes have a technical attache system. The French have a Scientific Ambassador Service which obtains information overseas. This may be just another name for industrial espionage, but we must be prepared to grow up in the world and to use industrial intelligence effectively for our own needs. Australia has only five science and technology counsellors. This really is not sufficient to get the information we need abroad and to identify opportunities.

I would like to go through the five stages of technology transfer. First, evaluation of new technology should involve looking for export opportunities, and not just defending the existing local market situation, which most of our firms do. Just in Time Manufacturing, for example, was modified through Australian experiences, and was then sold on to Malaysia and Singapore. To do this type of thing properly, enterprises need in-house technical capabilities. Unfortunately, as a percentage of the total work force, our engineers were only 0.65 per cent in 1981, as compared with 1.5 per cent in West Germany in 1980, 1.6 per cent in France in 1982 and 1.8 per cent in the United States of America in 1982. This means that we really do not have the capacity in engineering that we need and that we should be training more engineers or attracting them back to engineering. We probably have sufficient qualified people overall, but they are not being used effectively.

Co-operation between non-competing firms may help us to reduce the costs of evaluation of technology. As an example of this, the report lists the hardening of metal surfaces through the Toyota diffusion process, where at least 50 companies were able to benefit from the new techniques at a cost of only about twice what a single company would have had to pay for an evaluation on its own behalf. Given more time, similar things could be said about each of the other stages of technology transfer.

However, time is running out, so I summarise: The two vital ingredients for successful technological transfer are, firstly, the availability of an in-house research and development capability in our industrial enterprises, and, secondly, a positive will to export, to seize opportunities and to make export niches. Unless we are willing to commercialise our own research and development opportunities and to take research and development information from overseas and commercialise it, we shall surely become the type of banana republic that our Treasurer (Mr Keating) says we are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to speak to the Australian Science and Technology Council report on mechanisms for technology transfer into Australia. Last time I spoke to an ASTEC report I expressed not dismay but some disappointment that it was a somewhat timid document, and I express the same thing again in this instance. I believe that ASTEC was put together to provide advice to government. If it is going to provide advice, it needs to be a little more daring and forthright. I regret that I again need to express my disappointment about this report.

SPEECH.PARA: There are not a lot of recommendations in the report but it seems to me that they are just about all heavily qualified by use of the following terms-`commissioning a survey', `to promote the use', `to establish a pilot scheme', `to invite proposals for the organisation of workshops', `establish an award', `continue to seek ways', and `monitor changes'. This is not really the terminology one expects from a body that was established to give advice. It has certainly established the problems, but this is not the first, second or third report that has established the problems. We have a host of reports that very clearly lay the problems out, and it is the solutions we are looking for.

In the last 10 or 12 years a number of committee of inquiry reports, White Papers, et cetera, have examined the issue of the dissemination of scientific and technological information. Two years ago the Industrial Property Advisory Committee told this Government that the findings of these reports had shown the need for a national information policy. It further recommended the co-ordination of major Australian repositories of technological information and urged the integration of Australian and foreign databases; yet two years on we have no response to the IPAC report and we have another report which has virtually, albeit half-heartedly, come up with the same recommendations.

Even in the area of plant variety rights this report says that we ought to proceed, very gently, with this-it says it in a way to avoid exacerbating government sensitivities, of course-but that it would have the likely effect of increasing the availability of overseas plant varieties to Australian primary producers. That is about the eighth report the Government has had that has said exactly that. We still do not have any legislation and we still do not have very much indication that we are going to get legislation.

The report discusses at some length the problems of purchasing, but it does not come up with the solutions that we require. It does not say what the Government ought to be doing. At present the Australian Government contracts out only two per cent of its operations, while in Japan and the United States of America 50 per cent of these activities are contracted out to private industry. The report does not say that is what we ought to do here. It leaves us with the impression that it has recognised the problem but it is leaving it for someone else to make the conclusion. It talks at some length about the restrictive practices in technology agreements. I think we all know about these sorts of practices. It talks about impositions on licensees, what they can or cannot do if they take someone else's development to produce in Australia, which I think should be avoided where possible. But until we are able to make more direct agreements with people overseas that we work more on a reciprocal basis, we will not be able to improve matters very much. We are behind the other countries that we deal with, so there is no reason they will give us things when there is no return. Until we are able to match them on a more even basis, I doubt that we will improve on that.

I found the report somewhat disappointing and I regret that it did not go further when that Council certainly has the capacity. I have admiration for the people on the Council, but I think they could have done a lot better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several people want to talk about the Australian Science and Technology Council report on Mechanisms for Technology Transfer into Australia, so in those circumstances I will confine my remarks. Paragraph 2 (1) of this report contains the following sentences:

SPEECH.PARA: New technology is a key ingredient for economic growth. Australia produces only a small fraction of the total technology developed world wide.

I think it is important to keep in mind the very central part that technology plays in the growth of industry, particularly when we tend to concentrate on monetary and fiscal policies as they affect industry in Australia. It is generally accepted now that, with commodity prices falling, industry is largely the way out for Australia. At times we tend too much to think in terms of cutting wages or, on the other side, cutting prices, rather than looking at the deeper problems that are inherent in our society as far as the economy goes, and that is the lack of research and development, the lack of technological change, and the adaptation of that in a way that will enable us to export.

It seems to me that it is a tragedy that we keep looking at matters which, although important, tend to cloak our very desperate need to develop research and development. Senator Archer pointed out that much of the development takes place overseas. That is a real problem because we are a country that imports a lot of technology. People overseas are reluctant-quite understandably so-to allow us to export goods in return that depend upon their technology. In other words, if a country or a company overseas gives us technology, limitations are usually attached to the use we can make of that, and our exports are therefore truncated because no matter what price we reduce them to, the country or company which has given us these technological means and facilities will not allow us to use them to export products. This is a problem and it is a matter we should look at very carefully.

It is very much a matter of developing our education systems and developing in Australia a cultural approach which enables research and development to take place. The development of ideas which will lead to production and the export of this production is absolutely essential. Other than that we will have a truncated development-that is, a development which continues only from what others have given us-and, as I have already pointed out, that is bad for the country as a whole. Those are the two main points that I wish to make: First, that a lot of the debate about our exports is too confined to our fiscal and monetary policies rather than encompassing the central issue of what we can properly export; and, secondly, too much of our technology comes from overseas and thus so confines us that we cannot use it to develop our exports as we should.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had the opportunity to read and study all the reports that have gone to the Government from the Australian Science and Technology Council. This report, `Mechanisms for technology transfer into Australia', is the first report which I find thoroughly and totally disappointing from beginning to end. It is a negative document which does not do anything to advance substantially the debate about technology transfer in Australia. To demonstrate that, let me quote paragraph 2.4:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's dependence on overseas technology is, of necessity, high and very little can or should be done about this situation.

I think that is an absolutely disgraceful comment to be made by a body such as ASTEC. First, a great deal can be done and, secondly, a great deal should be done. For ASTEC to advise the Government that very little can or should be done about this dependence on overseas technology is entirely reprehensible. Technology transfer into Australia is a matter of enormous significance. The other day we debated the industrial research and development grants scheme in which we and the Australian Democrats combined to ensure that expenses incurred in the process of technology transfer would fall within the financial support given under that scheme because of the importance that we attach to it.

It is true that the majority of science and research work will be done overseas and it is important to have the mechanisms to transfer the benefit of that overseas discovery, research and technology into Australia and make effective use of it. Senator Cooney was quite correct in drawing attention to the fact that a number of situations exist in which limitations and restrictions are put into licensing agreements which are signed by Australian companies with overseas firms. At paragraph 5.17 the report indicates:
The danger remains however that companies find themselves locked into a position where export is made impossible.

There are a number of areas-and my colleague Senator Archer identified the area of scientific instrumentation, for example-where Australian scientists and technologists are well placed to develop a niche in the international market which would be extremely valuable for Australia, not only in reducing costs for our own industry, particularly given the declining value of the Australian dollar and therefore the increased cost of importing scientific instruments, but also in that it would provide a very valuable export industry for this country.

It is true, as the report points out, that there is still a degree of technological cringe in Australia. The report indicates that overseas technology is more highly regarded by Australian firms and consumers than our locally developed products and processes. It is certainly true that we need to overcome this technological cringe because there is no reason to believe that Australian-produced goods in this area are any less valuable or useful than those which are brought from overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think about the horticultural cringe?

—I am more concerned about the continuing ministerial cringe in addressing these significant matters. As Senator Archer has pointed out, it is amazing that the Australia Card report can be responded to in about 10 days but the Industrial Property Advisory Committee report, which actually deals with millions of dollars of industrial research and development in this country, cannot be responded to in under two years by this Government. It is not just the companies whose cringe is deleterious for Australian industry, but this whole Government's cringe in making up its mind about significant questions of science and technology.

SPEECH.PARA: This report also draws attention to the reform which is needed in the Australian patent system, which I have mentioned on a number of occasions, and again there are outstanding recommendations. The Industrial Property Advisory Committee report on patent innovation and competition in Australia given to the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) in August 1984 has not yet been responded to. I find this report very disappointing; its recommendations are essentially meaningless, but I hope that it will serve to stimulate some degree of debate on the question of technology transfer into Australia because once again we are missing the boat. The Government is missing the boat and on this occasion ASTEC is doing absolutely nothing to help us advance our position, either in Australia or in the competitive international market-place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the first thing I must comment on is the Opposition's disappointment and the way in which Opposition senators have selectively picked from this report, `Mechanisms for technology transfer into Australia', to make rather tedious points. If Senator Puplick wishes to read more closely what is in chapter two of the report, he will see that the ASTEC Technological Change Committee makes some good sense before it concludes that little can or should be done. In other words, the report points out that, as our population is a mere 2 per cent of the total population of North America, Japan and the European Economic Community countries, one can assume that an overwhelming majority of the technology in use in Australia has its origins overseas and that this situation will continue. In other words, the Australian industry should not compete where it cannot compete favourably.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that the complaints of the Opposition must be noted. Unlike Senator Puplick, I have not had the advantage of reading every report that this Committee has put out, but I was very interested to read this one and would disagree with honourable senators opposite that its recommendations are pointless. For a start, its recommendations address the areas of major difficulty. The interesting thing is that Opposition senators have not picked up the report's comments on the failure of management in this country to acquire overseas technology. Senator Vigor started off by saying that the report was structured around five stages of technology transfer, the first of which was awareness. It is interesting to pick up the lack of awareness of Australian management in many areas. Managers are not even aware of, much less able to proceed to the evaluation or acquiring of, overseas technology. The report actually spells this out. It says:

On the contrary, ASTEC is concerned at the steady decline in private capital expenditure in the manufacturing sector and other evidence of a slow rate of innovation over the last two decades. This decline is reflected in an ageing of capital stock and obsolescence of its associated technology.

Honourable senators opposite were in government for seven years and this report points to a 20-year lag. It is well and good to tell the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, that he is not sharp off the mark. I do not agree with that assessment and I sincerely hope that Senator Button will speak up on his own behalf at some stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has had only three years.

—Indeed, he has and I think that anyone who looks at the car industry or the steel industry will know that Senator Button has not been sitting around doing nothing, which is more than can be said for the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to draw attention to the comments in the report about the importance of the link between a firm's research and development and engineering capability and its ability to transfer technology effectively from overseas. The report not only urges us to look at acquiring overseas technology, but also points out that local research and development will make better use of that, will increase awareness of it and will allow a firm or an industry to know its capacity to adapt to or accept the overseas technology. This Government must be commended on one step that it has taken-and that is its recent legislation on research and development tax concessions, a very important point which goes very much to encouraging local research and development. That is very critical, as this report points out.

I also believe that the tedious complaints of Senator Archer about selected programs and encouraging management missed the substance of the recommendations. One recommendation in particular-No. 1.17-is:

That the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in consultation . . . invite proposals . . . for the organisation of workshops for managers to provide training in the skills of negotiating technology agreements.

This report deals in large part with encouraging skills with management, and I think it has to be commended for that, but I do not really believe that it is the Government's business to tell managers how to manage. It may provoke, it may legislate and it may encourage or exhort, but essentially managing is managers' business. I can just imagine the Opposition's complaints if in fact this Government started to determine how management should do its work. Screams of `nationalisation' would be heard across the length and breadth of the Senate. I rather suspect that honourable senators opposite should read the report with more understanding of what it does suggest-that is, the most effective combination of public and private information, support, encouragement and processes by which the optimal outcome for Australian industry can be derived. I think the report is very interesting. It is very provocative indeed, and it is well worth the Senate's reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly on the report of the Australian Science and Technology Council entitled `Mechanisms for Technology Transfer into Australia'. I agree with what my colleagues have suggested, because of all the ASTEC reports that I have examined this report seems to be rather negative in its thrust. I recall that in 1979 the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, of which I was Chairman, presented a report on industry research and development in Australia. I believe that it was a constructive report. It drew attention to the need to develop an information policy. I think Senator Archer made reference to that need in his short speech. The Committee drew attention to the disparity between public expenditure on research and development and the lack of expenditure by private enterprise. It seemed that private enterprise had lost its entrepreneurial drive in developing research initiatives in Australia. We drew attention to several initiatives of which industry in Australia had failed to take advantage, which could have increased our export earning capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the idea behind the establishment of ASTEC, which was initiated by the Fraser Government to provide advice to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, was very important. It was important not for the Department of Science, for industrial development or for the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, but for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) so that he could act upon the initiatives suggested by ASTEC.

I believe that it is quite important that Australia does develop its initiatives. We have over- protected industry. We have not encouraged it to become more entrepreneurial by providing incentives. We have not provided it with sufficient capacity to work with the government research facilities that are available. I believe that that approach ought to be addressed more aggressively by this Government in the interests of industrial development in Australia and in the spirit of increasing our export earnings.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on High Court of Australia Annual Report 1984-85

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I present a report on the High Court of Australia annual report for 1984-85.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

In May of last year the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee reported on the 1983-84 annual report of the High Court of Australia. In that report the Committee noted its intention to pay particular attention to the question of costs and delays in its 1986 report on the High Court's next annual report. The annual report of the High Court of Australia was furnished in accordance with section 47 of the High Court of Australia Act. That section requires that the High Court `shall report upon matters relating to the administration of the affairs of the Court'. The High Court has chosen to interpret this requirement very narrowly. Consequently, it has provided only a minimum of information about the operations of the Court in its annual report. It is the Committee's view that section 47, if not actually requiring the provision of information about costs and delays, should be viewed as establishing the minimum requirements of the contents of the annual report, not the maximum requirements.
In February of this year, I wrote to the Clerk of the High Court on behalf of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. In my letter I pointed out to the Clerk:

. . . members of this Committee and presumably other members of Parliament have been approached at various times by persons and organisations expressing a concern about High Court litigation and the time taken to hear cases and deliver judgments etc.
I also pointed out to the Clerk that the Committee recognised:
. . . some of this information is in fact published by the High Court as for example in the biennial `State of the Judicature' by the Chief Justice.

However, the Committee is of the view that this information should be formally presented to the Parliament. The Clerk provided a detailed letter in response to the Committee's request. In his letter, which is published as an appendix to the Committee's report, he provided to the Committee much of the information which the Committee had asked that he include in the Court's annual report. But he prefaced this information with the statement:

The Court considers that it would not be appropriate to deal in its annual reports with questions of costs and delay not only because such questions are outside the ambit of matters referred to in s. 47 of the High Court of Australia Act 1979, but also because of the independent position which the Constitution secures to the Court in its exercise of judicial power.

The Committee remains firmly of the view that some information about the cost of litigating in the High Court, and the time taken for any such litigation, should be included in each annual report by the High Court of Australia. In particular, it recommends that future annual reports by the High Court of Australia should contain information about matters such as the expenses incurred by the Court in maintaining chambers in the various States, and by travelling to and hearing cases in the various States; the time taken between filing proceedings in the Court and the hearing of applications for special leave; the time taken between granting special leave for appeal and hearing cases; and the time taken between hearing cases and the handing down of judgments. I have already referred to information about matters such as the expenses incurred in maintaining chambers in the various States.

It is the Committee's view that there is a clear distinction to be drawn between judicial independence, which it in no way wishes to undermine, and the accountability of institutions, be they administrative, legislative or judicial, which are funded by the public moneys. Consequently, the Committee remains of the view that the provision of information about costs and delays would not in any way trench upon the independence of the judiciary. The Committee requests that this information should be included in the High Court's annual report, so as to dispel any misconceptions as to the efficient functioning of this distinguished Court. Mr Acting Deputy President, in the absence of any other member of the Committee wishing to speak at this time, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 248th report from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, entitled `Report of the Auditor-General-April 1985'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 248th report of the Public Accounts Committee examines the report of the Auditor-General of April 1985. Honourable senators will be aware that each year the Committee examines recently published reports of the Auditor-General. Following the tabling of the Auditor-General's report for April 1985, the Committee sought written submissions from 10 departments and five statutory authorities in respect of 22 items. Further information and clarification by way of supplementary submissions was sought from six departments and one statutory authority.

SPEECH.PARA: Report 248 is a departure from the usual practice of the Committee. Due to an increasing work load, the Committee decided that Parliament's attention should be drawn to the salient features of the Auditor-General's report. Consequently, the principal matters on which the Committee sought comment from departments and authorities were addressed but public hearings were not held on any of the matters raised. This report comments upon the responses of the departments and authorities to the criticisms raised by the Auditor-General. Conclusions drawn by the Committee reflect remedial action taken or proposed to be taken in addressing those criticisms. In particular, there are three matters that the Committee wished to bring to the notice of honourable senators: The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations' wage pause program, the Department of Territories' administration of the Commissioner for Housing loans, and the financial statements of the Australian National University. I seek leave to have the remainder of my comments incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982 provided for the expenditure of up to $200m through a wage pause program of public sector job creation. The money partly represented the expected savings from the 12 month suspension of salary increases for Commonwealth employees under the salaries and wages pause legislation.

Under the established guidelines the States were required to submit employment projects to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and, if considered suitable, details were forwarded to the Minister for Finance for approval. Projects which were to receive consideration for approval were required to be labour intensive and promote greater equality of opportunity, particularly for the long term unemployed.

The audit review of the scheme sought to establish whether procedures introduced to administer the program within the area of Commonwealth responsibilities were consistent with the aims and objectives.

The Committee was disturbed by the administrative difficulties which developed following hasty implementation of the wage pause program, and, in particular, from the inadequacy of interdepartmental co-ordination.

In view of this concern and the fact that this program ceased in mid-1984, the Committee sought supplementary submissions from both Employment and Industrial Relations and Finance with respect to another similar employment program, the community employment program. Whilst this program was not subject to audit, the committee considered it important to assess the administrative arrangements governing it.

From the respective departmental submissions it is clear that the administrative and financial arrangements for the community employment program differ quite markedly from those which applied the wage pause program. The Minister for Finance has limited executive responsibilities and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations clearly has carriage of the legislation and program administration. Clearer working guidelines and funding through annual appropriations has, to a large degree, clarified the obligations and responsibilities of agencies concerned.

Under the Housing Ordinance 1982 the Commissioner for Housing may, subject to the control of the Minister for Territories, administer schemes for providing or assisting in providing dwellings in the Australian Capital Territory.

On 10 September 1984 the Minister for Finance, pursuant to concern expressed by Cabinet about the management of funds in the scheme, requested the Auditor-General to perform an audit of the recent operations of the scheme in the light of recent over-commitment of funds.
Audit findings were that:
The Housing Trust Account was over-expended from 4 July 1984 to 18 July in breach of s.34 of the Audit Act.
There were deficiencies in the system for controlling commitments.
The estimated shortfall of $7.9m in funds was unreliable.

The Committee was informed that the department has now instituted amended procedures and practices in order to eliminate any future problems with over- commitment of funds. Further, the department has implemented a range of measures to improve the financial and administrative procedures and staffing arrangements of the Housing Branch. These amended procedures and arrangements implement many of the recommendations of the joint review of the scheme by the Public Service Board and the Department, conducted during September 1984, and of the Fisher Review, conducted during the first half of 1985. The Steering Committee for Housing Loans is continuing to meet on a regular basis to implement the longer term recommendations of the joint review report and will continue to do so until all recommendations are satisfactorily implemented.

The Committee notes Audit's comment that these amended systems and procedures should eliminate future problems. However, the Committee will continue to monitor the Department's operation of the scheme and may subject the scheme to further review.

The Auditor-General also reported on an inspection of the accounts and records of financial transactions of the Australian National University for the year ended 31 December 1983. Among other things, Audit noted serious deficiencies existed in the supporting documentation for the university's 1983 draft financial statements, both in their original form and in the revised draft submitted some months later. Audit was concerned that, in some respects, the university's accounting practices were at variance with those prescribed in the `Guidelines on the Form and Standard of Financial Statements of Commonwealth Undertakings', issued by the Minister for Finance in May 1983.

The Committee notes that the university has significantly reformed its financial administration and that this reform process is continuing. The Committee anticipates continued improvement in the university's financial administration, particularly with reference to its financial statements.

The Auditor-General now reports twice each year on audits undertaken. In addition separate reports are made throughout the year on efficiency audits performed by the Auditor-General, and annual reports on the Financial Statements and his activities.

During the currency of the examination of the Auditor-General's Report of April 1985 the Auditor-General presented an annual report for 1984-85 on his operations. This was the first time the Auditor-General had reported in this manner. The report referred to, amongst other things, a number of issues concerning the role and proper function of the Auditor-General, particularly his relationship with the executive. The Committee looks forward to discussions with the Auditor-General on these matters.
I commend this report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO COMPENSATION ARISING FROM SOCIAL SECURITY CONSPIRACY PROSECUTIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the first volume of the report of the Commission of Inquiry into Compensation arising from Social Security Conspiracy Prosecutions and seek leave to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first report of the commission of inquiry conducted by Dame Roma Mitchell into the so-called social security conspiracy case involving the Greek community in Sydney makes certain recommendations. The Government has considered the report and decided to implement these recommendations. It will offer compensation worth approximately $10m to 471 people of Greek origin who were affected by the case. This group consists of those who were charged, some of those who were not charged but whose pensions were affected and whose compensation has been assessed by a committee established in Sydney of Greek social workers and others in conjunction with the Department of Social Security, and some of the doctors involved in the case. In offering the compensation, the Government recognises the extreme and unjustified suffering of the victims of the case and their families over many years. The actions of a few people in authority in 1978 were based on very little more than prejudice and carried out with scant regard for the legal rights that Australians expect to enjoy. Justice Mitchell's terms of reference were limited to the appropriateness of payments to the victims of the social security case.
—How many people will get the compensation?

—About 471. This limitation of the terms of reference was essential to accelerate compensation where it was due. The report does not, therefore, go into the heart of the alleged conspiracy. It does not canvass the evidence on which the Commonwealth Police and the Department of Social Security acted at the time. It does not go into the manner of the arrests nor the unsavoury offer of a reward to an informer who had already been given immunity. It does not go into the knowledge or otherwise of various members of the Government at the time of the case. I hope that these matters will be given thorough attention in the future by historians. However, I hope this offer brings to a close at least one chapter in this sorry case, which has cost the taxpayers of this country more than $20m. The second volume of the report has not yet been released at the request of the Commissioner, because it lists the names and the amounts of compensation to be offered. Until the people have been notified, it would not be appropriate to release the second volume. However, as soon as that is possible, the Government will release it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report and statement.

The Opposition has had in its hands for only some hours the report of the Hon. Dame Roma Mitchell on the Commission of Inquiry into Compensation arising from Social Security Conspiracy Prosecutions. We do not wish to canvass, challenge or in any way enter into discussion about the appropriateness of the Government's decision. It is a matter which rests with executive government. We note that the Government has determined to accept the recommendations and that it will be making payments to some 470 people. In the short time we have had the report we have been able to look at the matters covered by the Commissioner, and we understand why Volume 2 is yet to be released. It will be released later when people have been approached and have entered into appropriate agreements with the Commonwealth.

Some matters within the report bear bringing to the notice of the public, as they would otherwise not be known. I turn first to page 49 of the report and the section headed `Evidence of dishonesty in dealings with the Department of Social Security not resulting in a conviction'. It is important to read this section because, while it appears clear that the bringing of conspiracy charges was the cause of the problems, and that may have been an inappropriate course to follow, and while the compensation is being paid because conspiracy charges were brought, that in no way makes it clear that there was no dishonest behaviour going on or that frauds were not in fact being conducted against the Department of Social Security by a number of people. I quote from page 49 the Commissioner's first words under the heading I have just given:

The files of the Australian Federal Police contain statements and other documentary evidence which infer that some of the claimants, who were not convicted of offences, may have been guilty of dishonesty in relation to their dealings with the Department of Social Security.

She says later that, although there are statements and there is other documentary evidence, these in themselves do not amount to a conviction. The Commissioner goes on to raise the question whether those people against whom evidence was held should share in the compensation payment. She says:
. . . it seemed inappropriate that a person who had behaved dishonestly in his--
or her--
dealings with the Department but who had fortuitously escaped conviction should receive undiminished compensation in relation to the conspiracy proceedings.

She discusses that matter and then gives her conclusions as to whether compensation should be offered to those against whom there appeared to be no evidence as well as to those against whom there appeared to be some evidence in the hands of the police. She went on to say:
I acknowledge that a consequence of this approach-
that is, her decision that everyone should get compensation-

is that, as between the claimants, those who were convicted of offences or in respect of whom offences were found proved will receive less compensation than some others who may well have been guilty of conduct as grave as or more grave than that in respect of which convictions were recorded.

Honourable senators should be aware that there may well be an element of injustice as between different people in terms of the amount of compensation they will receive because information in the hands of the police which indicated that some other people may have been guilty was not followed up. One of the canards which has been put about in relation to this whole affair is that it was all a beat-up, that there was no substance to it, that there was no guilt, that it was in some way an attack directed against a particular ethnic community, and that the people who conducted the whole exercise were, as it were, guilty of some kind of racist or ethnically based behaviour. It is instructive, in the light of those beliefs, to go further and to examine some later pages of this first volume of the report by Dame Roma Mitchell. She makes the following point at page 115:

Ten persons who were charged with conspiracy in the matter have not been included in the Terms of Reference. These comprise 7 persons against whom criminal charges have not been finalised, 2 persons, including one deceased person, who are alleged to have been involved in matters which are still before the courts, and one person who was a police informer.

So we should know that there are a number of matters incomplete. But in relation to the matters which were completed, there is a schedule at the end of the report-from page 125 on-which actually identifies different classes of people. The Minister was kind enough to tell me, in response to an interjection, that 471 people-that is, the vast majority-would share in the compensation. However, the first list in the Commissioner's schedule names people who were charged with conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth but against whom conspiracy charges were withdrawn and no substantive charges preferred. A second list names persons who were convicted of conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth. There were three such persons. So let us not say that there were no convictions. Three persons were convicted of conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth.

Another list names persons charged with conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth, against whom conspiracy charges were withdrawn and substantive charges preferred and who were convicted or had an offence found proved against them in respect of one or more substantive charge. There are 32 such persons listed. There are other categories. Category (g) comprises persons charged with conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth and conspiring to defraud divers insurance companies who were convicted of conspiring to defraud divers insurance companies. There are two people in that category.

So it is important, in setting the events in balance in one's mind, in acknowledging that a case for compensation has been made by the Commissioner and in acknowledging that the Government has determined to grant compensation, to acknowledge also that out of this exercise, however disastrous it was, there have ensued 40 or more convictions of attempting to defraud either insurance companies or the Commonwealth. To keep the matter in balance, while a number of innocent people appear to have been treated very harshly, a number of people who were found in the courts to be guilty have also been picked up and convicted. I come back to the first point I made. Dame Roma Mitchell acknowledges that the way she has constructed the compensation may result in some inequity because some people who were guilty may get compensation which they may not have received had they been among the group against whom charges were proved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to enter into a long debate on this matter. I was involved in this matter from 1978 onwards. Having tabled the report of the Commission of Inquiry into Compensation arising from Social Security Conspiracy Prosecutions, I merely repeat that the Government has accepted the recommendations of the report and will pay the compensation. Senator Peter Baume has said that he wishes to put some things into perspective. I also wish to put some things into perspective and give another side to the story. Senator Baume says that a canard has been put about that what happened was that some people in authority-public servants or members of government, perhaps-indulged in an exercise which was racially aimed and which involved actions taken against one racial group in particular with little substance.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume has pointed out that some 40 people, some of whom pleaded guilty very early in the piece, have been convicted. I wish to point out that all those people are of Greek origin. The 471 people who are to be compensated are of Greek origin. The 170-odd people who were arrested are of Greek origin. Many of them, despite denials made in this place, had their photographs taken with a placard in front of them with the word `Greece' written on it. The inspector in charge of the case at the time, Detective Inspector Thomas, said on public television and radio, having invited the Press along when the raids were conducted, that not only were 170 people arrested but also 1,200 people were to be arrested, all found guilty and all put away. It seems to me that there is a fair bit of evidence, to say the least, that this was aimed at the Greek community. The Greek community suffered great stress at the time. This Government has apologised to the Greek community on behalf of Australians for what happened to them at the time. I wish the previous Government had done the same.

A second matter which is worth raising is that, far from it being a canard, at the time large numbers of people-as has been frequently pointed out-who were charged with conspiracy to defraud the Department of Social Security, who were in the courts charged with conspiring against the Department of Social Security and against the Government, say, to receive invalid pensions were, while they were under charge in the courts, still receiving invalid pensions and were judged by the Department as being able to receive them on just grounds. That was commented on as being an extraordinary set of circumstances, and I agree that it was. I suggest that honourable senators also read the magistrate's report of the extraordinary circumstances whereby a person who had been given immunity from charges was offered a reward to give evidence in the case. Neither the magistrate nor anyone else was notified until the very end that the person concerned had been offered that reward. The Minister of the day knew about the reward and knew the circumstances of that case.

Sure, a small number of people have been convicted of substantive offences. But a very large number of people were charged with conspiracy. A whole community was pilloried in the Press and the taxpayer of this country has paid well over $20m for this dreadful affair. The only people who have benefited from this affair have been the Queen's counsel involved in the case, in particular, the QC who was chosen to prosecute the case, who has received over $1m for his conduct of this affair, which has come to nothing. All that has happened is that this Government will pay some $10m in compensation to the Greek community of this country to overcome gradually the very real difficulties which they and their doctors faced in the few sad years after this case came to light.

As I said, although giving the Greek community some compensation will close one chapter of the case, I hope that the public authorities and we in the Parliament learn some lessons from it. I hope that we learn that, just as we could not arrest in dawn raids, as I said at the time, even 20 people from Pymble, Toorak, South Yarra or Sandy Bay on some conspiracy charge of this type-say, conspiring to overcome the gaming laws-we should not be able to arrest 170 members of a community with the Press fanfare and high publicity seen at the time and think we can get away with it because it happens to be a minority ethnic group in the community. The people who have come out of this affair with greatest credit are the members of the Greek community because they were willing to stand up for their own, to stand up for justice and to use the system of justice to overcome the very real difficulties they faced. The system of justice in our courts has also come out relatively untarnished, although certainly not the system of justice before one reaches our courts.

When one considers the huge cost to the community in dollars and in the disgrace which resulted from this affair, we should all try to learn a lesson from it. It is only too easy, in the atmosphere that exists in the community now, in which people are willing to exaggerate wildly the extent of social security fraud, to look for scapegoats. In this case the scapegoat was the Greek community. The Greek community overcame the problem. One wonders whether other communities, perhaps smaller communities less used to defending themselves, would have come off as well. As Senator Peter Baume says, I hope that the people concerned feel that the compensation is adequate and accept it so that we can learn our lesson, rather than have this affair drawn out in the protracted way it has been over the last few years.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COUNCIL OF THE AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL UNIVERSITY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes)-by leave-agreed to:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Australian National University Act 1946, the Senate elects Senators Colston and Peter Baume to be members of the Council of the Australian National University from 18 July 1986 for a period of up to, and including, 17 July 1989.
Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The story is told of the vicar's wife who wanted to give the young curate a treat, so she offered him a boiled egg. It was not particularly good. She asked him whether his egg was good and, not knowing how to respond and tell her it was no good, he said to her: `Well, ma'am, it is very good in parts'. That is the tale of the curate's egg. The Health Legislation Amendment Bill is, as it were, a curate's egg. It is a Bill that is very good in parts. The Opposition will not be opposing it.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to go through some of the main sections of the Bill indicating those areas where we do and do not have some concerns. First of all, the Bill does a number of things which are only loosely related, and I will go through them. Firstly, it contains some new proposals for approved pathology providers or approved pathology authorities, a new scheme for these matters. It involves the giving of undertakings and the provision of sanctions in relation to these matters. The Opposition supports these proposals. The approved pathology provider scheme was actually recommended by the Pathology Services Advisory Committee as far back as July 1976. It was introduced in practice without a legislative base in 1977; that is, in the time of the previous Government. It was the intention of the designers that the approved pathology provider scheme was interim until the accreditation of pathology laboratories could be introduced. This Bill introduces needed provisions and controls to the scheme. The Opposition has no difficulty at all with those proposals of the Government, although I have a couple of questions for the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) in the Committee Stage.

Secondly, there is the question of the accreditation of pathology laboratories. This Bill introduces the concept of an accredited pathology laboratory and it limits payment of a Medicare benefit to pathology services performed in accredited laboratories. There are certain tests which could be performed by general practitioners and they will still be covered by Medicare outside an accredited laboratory. The Opposition supports these recommendations. The pathologists in practice in Australia have been calling for this action for some nine years. There is still some difficulty in prescribing the accreditation process; nevertheless, the idea is one which is supported. I understand that New South Wales and Victoria have enabling legislation. It is intended to accept the actions of those States as being suitable for accreditation. Where the States have no such process we hope that the Government has an adequate system in mind. We understand that the laboratories will be deemed accredited for Medicare purposes if they meet and pass the standards and inspections of the National Association of Testing Authorities in association with the appropriate learned college. The Opposition supports this recommendation by the Government.

Thirdly, there are moves by the Government to prohibit fee splitting. The Opposition supports these moves. There are a number of procedures which the Government proposes to try to make illegal-certain practices which have been going on and which have involved fee splitting and kick-backs. The Opposition supports these procedures and I understand that pathologists generally support them as well. These provisions, in conjunction with the approved provider schemes and the accreditation of laboratories, really lie at the heart of moves to try to overcome medical fraud as it affects pathology and to overcome abuse in the pathology services area. They are supported by pathologists in practice and they are certainly supported by the Opposition.

We next come to that part of the Bill to establish a new committee called the Pathology Services Advisory Committee, which will carry out certain tasks in setting fees. The Opposition will be withholding its judgment on this matter. We understand what the Government is doing. We are also aware of considerable disquiet from people whom we do not regard as fringe operators. I will be coming back later to this question of who are fringe operators and who are mainstream ethical providers. The concerns we are getting are from the mainstream ethical providers of pathology services. They believe this is not necessarily a good idea. They are prepared to give it a try; we are prepared to see how it goes, but we will withhold judgment until we know whether or not it is going to work. Currently pathology procedures and the setting of appropriate rebates to pathology services have been carried out and reviewed by the pathology sub-committee of the Medical Benefits Schedule Revision Committee; there is a committee already doing this job. The Government now proposes to split it off as a separate committee, and we remain to be convinced-although we are not going to the barricades on this-that it will necessarily help or overcome any of the problems that exist in this area.

The Australian Medical Association, other medical authorities and people we have spoken to believe that some of the technical knowledge which will be necessary to make this Committee work may be lacking and that there may be some difficulties in a committee only a portion of whose membership has expertise and expert knowledge. The Opposition withholds its judgment for the present in relation to the Pathology Services Advisory Committee. We would like to see in a year or a year and a half whether that Committee is working. I will be asking the Minister later for certain assurances about the immediate referral to that Committee of certain items which are the subject of the other main provisions of the Bill; that is, items where the rebate is proposed to be cut back by 25 per cent. I hope the Minister will be able to give me the assurances that the first task of this new Committee will be to examine those 18 items, for reasons I will set out later. The other group of provisions of this Bill is a series of minor amendments to which the Opposition does not object.

Before I go on to discuss the proposal to reduce certain fees, I want to say something about the private practice of pathology in Australia. Private pathologists, that is, non-government pathologists, people working in the private pathology industry, are the backbone of much of the pathology service for Australia. They provide a vital service. They fill a gap which would otherwise not be filled. They service many of the areas of Australia which could not be serviced if they were not there. They service many of the public hospitals where government cannot undertake that role. The private pathologists provide a flexible, responsive and rapid service.

I draw attention to the situation in some of the more centralised States, particularly the State of Western Australia where 90 per cent of the population live in the Perth conurbation. It is private pathology that has a significant role in providing services outside that area. In my own State of New South Wales, where so much of our population lives in the great conurbation between Wollongong and Newcastle, the enormous Sydney area, it is private pathology which provides much of the service to outlying practices and outlying rural areas. In the State of Queensland, though it is slightly more decentralised, private pathologists provide an absolutely essential service. I understand that there are two large practices in Queensland which, because they operate an efficient system of collection of blood specimens and other pathology material, because they have an efficient transport system-

TALK.START.PARA: —One million services a year between the two of them.

—Senator Boswell says one million services a year between the two. They are the backbone of much of the provision of services in that State. It is rapid, flexible and of very high quality. Most of the people who provide private pathology in Australia are people of high ethical standards; they are honest, well qualified and give a service to the public. Each one of us is a winner from what they do. They help us get services we need, which government is unable to provide because government services are inherently slower to react. It is the flexibility of the private services which often is very important.

SPEECH.PARA: In common with several other speakers in this debate, I am medically qualified and during my time as a consultant physician I used private pathology services every day of my life. If I phoned a private pathologist and said `I have a problem; I have a patient who may be going overseas in a couple of days, and it is necessary to turn yourselves upside down to get the results for me quickly', they would do so. The pathologists would try to accommodate themselves to the needs of the patient. The hospital with which I dealt offered first class services, but it was less rapid. Of course I used the hospital and the private practitioners. Each had a part to play. Because they were ethical, well qualified, honest and had the public interest at heart, they were giving the public a service it needed. They are dedicated, and they are very hurt and upset at the messages they have been receiving from government. They are a self-assessed and self-monitored profession and operate through a learned college. They maintain their standards; they place a high premium on continuing education; their training is rigorous. They are people whom we should be applauding and praising. As a doctor, I found most of them to be an essential component for the protection of patients.

The private pathologists are upset. First, they are hurt at the rhetoric, even if not at the substance, which has been flowing from many Labor politicians and which suggests that pathologists in private practices are profiteers, or crooks, or in some way less than honest, dedicated people. That is unfair to them, and they are hurt by this kind of language. They do not like to be told that they are fat cats. They are often operating very high cost practices. I know some of them whose incomes have been cut back regularly over the last few years. They believe that from the Labor Government they are receiving no recognition for the positive, essential service they are giving to the public. If Labor senators taking part in this debate want to criticise them, I ask them in so doing to acknowledge what the pathologists are doing to help Australians remain well, and to help them become well if they are ill.

Secondly, the pathologists in private practice are dismayed at what they see as a unilateral, arbitrary action by government in determining that for 18 procedures the rebate to be paid to the patients will be reduced by 25 per cent. The pathologists do not believe they were consulted. They believe that the Government is wrong factually in relation to some of the tests, but they are not even sure whether there was a factual base for the selection of these 18 tests. People say that it is the common tests, which have been automated, the cost of performing which tests has dropped. If that is so, let the Government produce the evidence in relation to each of the tests that that is the case, because the Government is asking a group of people who are providing a very expensive service in relation to these tests to take a 25 per cent cut in the rebate that government offers. It is incumbent on the Government to make the case for each of these tests.

I said that the private pathologists believe the Government is wrong in fact. Let me say that one of the groups of tests relates to the cross-matching of blood. Cross-matching of blood, pathologists advise me, is not automated; it is not done by machine. It is done manually. There has been no technological advance in the cross-matching of blood.

TALK.START.PARA: —Compared with when you and I were boys? Fair go!

—Senator Grimes says compared with when he and I were boys-there probably has, but there has been no automation that I have been able to discover from the pathologists which would warrant these tests being put in the category that reduces their benefits. But more than that: The cross-matching of blood is often an emergency procedure carried out after hours; in the middle of the night a woman suddenly has a miscarriage, she bleeds, she is in danger of losing her life, she needs a blood transfusion, and a pathologist or technician must come out of their bed, must come in and must cross-match blood at any hour of the day or night.
—Absolutely vital.

—Absolutely vital, as my colleague says. If it is still manual and if the pathologists believe it is no longer something they can do, and avoid losing money, perhaps what the Government would like them to do is to withdraw from the cross-matching of blood. Maybe that is what is suggested. Maybe they should withdraw because they believe that on that test alone the Government has got it wrong. But all they have asked that we put to the Government is that because there is a difference of opinion, let us get this new independent committee to examine the facts and let us see in relation to the 18 tests where the merit lies. Is there any objection to that? I understand that the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, is well disposed to this, and I would ask Senator Grimes to indicate when he replies to the debate whether these tests will be referred to the new Pathology Services Advisory Committee as one of its first tasks.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point again that our society as at present structured-with the medical services it has, with the number of people living in small communities which themselves cannot support a pathology service-cannot cope if the pathologists in private practice cease to offer the services they do now. They offer the services to many of the government public hospitals which cannot support their own pathology service. They support the private hospitals which are so vital in the system of health care.

I said that the pathologists are hurt and dismayed; but they are also fearful. They are fearful, first, for their good name. They ask that if the Government is attacking the crooks in any industry, it should not try to smear the entire industry in so doing. They are fearful as well for their own survival, as well they may be. The Government has proposed to reduce the rebates payable for 18 common tests. I make it quite clear that we in government would not have done this without having carried out an investigation first through the committee. It is being done now. We ask the Government to get the report, and if the report suggests that any one of those tests is inappropriately included in the lower schedule, the Government should look sympathetically at correcting such an error.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the Health Legislation Amendment Bill. I made the point before the dinner suspension that the Opposition is not opposing the Bill and that many of the provisions of the legislation are supported by us because we think they are things that we would have done. However, the area of concern is that certain pathology fees are to be altered. Our concern relates not just to the pathologists but also to the effect that may flow through to the public which depends on pathologists. I want to reiterate the point I was making earlier, which is that we believe that the people in private pathology practice in general provide a high quality, high-class, and dedicated service to the public, that they undertake many years of training before they can undertake that practice and that their practices are very expensive to run but that they often make available to the public an extensive network of collection and a rapid turnaround of results and offer a service which governments do not and cannot provide.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has determined that fees for 18 tests are to be reduced by 25 per cent. It is claimed by the Minister for Health that these are high volume, highly automated and highly profitable tests. The Government has estimated that this will save $47m in a year; that is to say, $47m less will flow through to private pathologists. It is worth pointing out that I know of no other professional area and no other area of medical practice in which the Government, by fiat, has determined that people will accept a 25 per cent fee reduction. By the way, the pathologists tell me that some of these tests are highly automated and that, in fact, technology has altered some of them. However, they say that that is not so for all the tests and they believe that the Government has got it wrong.

The Opposition is seeking from the Government some assurances in relation to the tests for which the fees are being reduced. The Government has established a new committee, the Pathology Services Advisory Committee, which is to look at appropriate matters concerning the fees to be paid for pathology services. We want to make sure that the fees for these 18 tests are the first things referred to that Committee. After all, if the Committee determines that for all those services the fee reduction is appropriate, that will reassure the Opposition. It will certainly help the pathologists, especially if they have a chance to put their case. They have had no chance to put their case. As the pathologists see it at this stage, this is an ex parte decision of the Government. That is not to say that it is wrong. However, it is a decision which the pathologists want to have tested. If the Government gives us this assurance, that will help us.

The other point is that we think the powers of referral of particular matters to the new Committee are fairly narrow. We want to know whether the Government is willing to consider a wider possible reference of powers. For example, it has been suggested that the Parliament may wish to have the power to refer certain fee matters to the Committee. After all, all the Committee does is make findings and recommendations to the Government; it does not actually determine fees. Some of the pathologists have put to us that they are concerned about what has happened and what this may presage for the future.

I conclude by making the point once again that this country cannot operate its medical care without the services operated and offered by pathologists in private practice. That they operate very capital intensive, high investment practices, in the end, really operates to the benefit of the public of Australia. When I was a doctor it certainly was my patients who were getting the benefit of what the pathologists had to offer. What we in the Opposition want to see is a reasonable and a reasoned provision of services. We do so against the background of a medical system that is in disarray at present: There are long hospital waiting lists and a public hospital system in my State of New South Wales which is in total disarray, where the morale of the system is shot, where hospital boards are being sacked and where hospital services are being reduced. My hospital-the Royal North Shore Hospital of Sydney-has had to close something like 100 beds because the Government has determined that those beds are not to be opened and filled. Right across the State is a hospital system that in the last three or four years has gone down hill and is in disarray. People are losing their confidence. We do not want them to lose their confidence in one sector of medical care provision. Private pathologists are at least offering a service.

In every area of human activity there are some bad apples. There certainly are in the area of pathology provision. If the Government-through its accreditation procedures, through the new approved pathology provider system and through the new sanctions which are written into this legislation-can do anything to reduce the activities of these bad apples, the pathologists, the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia, and the various academic authorities will be delighted. I know that the private pathologists to whom I talk will be delighted. They do not like having these people in their midst. However, I observe that we have no great confidence that the changes in this legislation will have that effect. We think the entrepreneurial pathology specialists are too clever. They will read the new law, they will operate within it and they will continue to abuse the system.

I make a final point: If we have things to say about the bad operators in the pathology service let us say them without broad brushing the whole practice and profession of private pathology. It does not deserve it. Having said that, we will not oppose the legislation. I have a couple of questions to ask the Minister at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. I start by commending the Government and the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, for introducing this legislation. I would also like to take the opportunity of commending those people in the Department of Health who have worked on these changes. Very often the back-up within the Department is not necessarily acknowledged and I think in this case it ought be. The Department has had to deal with the difficulties of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry and-I say this to Senator Peter Baume-it has taken a fair serve about its efficiency or otherwise. I note for the record that Senator Baume did not feel it necessary to defend those departmental officers who have been picked up in some of the criticism in this area. I would certainly like to place on record my support for those departmental people, particularly those who have had a very active role to play in producing to the Minister and the Government the documentation which has allowed this piece of legislation to emerge.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes are very far-reaching and they will ensure-I am happy to assure Senator Baume of this-the continuation of the quality pathology services this country expects and will go a long way to removing the less than adequate pathology services that are referred to in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report on `Medical Fraud and Overservicing-Pathology'. I think it is unnecessary nitpicking of Senator Baume to suggest that this Government and Australian Labor Party senators get stuck into the medical profession in an indiscriminate way. I am absolutely sure that Senator Walters will say exactly that when she speaks; she invariably does. I am a little disappointed that Senator Baume said that. Those of us on this side, and in particular those of us who come from the medical area, are at pains to acknowledge the good and to try to highlight where the problems are. It is not as though the Labor Government has picked up on the problems in the pathology area. That had been a matter of considerable deliberation well before any Labor government people got to make any comments about it. I remind honourable senators that there was a Public Accounts Committee inquiry into this whole area well before we had anything to say about it and that that Committee quite clearly highlighted the very significant problems of overservicing and fraud in the area of pathology services, as well as the other comments it had to make.

As well as the legislation addressing the continuation of good quality pathology in this country and removing some of the less than adequate services, I think it will go towards providing considerable cost savings to the Government. The Minister spelt them out very well in his second reading speech. He said:

When implemented, the new approved pathology practitioner scheme and related measures will provide savings to the Government of approximately $60,000,000 in a full year. $47,000,000 will arise directly from reduced fees for some pathology items in the Medicare Benefits Schedule; up to $10,000,000 from the more restrictive arrangements for self-determined tests; and $2,700,000 from the removal of Item 955 from the Schedule.

I will comment on that in a minute. The costs of pathology are very considerable. It is estimated that 15 per cent of the total Commonwealth spending on Medicare benefits goes on pathology. In real terms, in 1984-85 claims, that payment totalled $346m out of a total outlay of $2,280m. Between 1979 and 1985 there was a 69 per cent increase in pathology services as services rose from $13m to $22m over this period. So it is not as though we are talking about a small expense to government or a small service to the country; we are talking about a very significant matter, both in terms of the outlay and in terms of the services provided.

The rescheduling of fees for the 18 items mentioned at length by Senator Peter Baume not only addresses the possibility of overservicing-I will refer again to the Minister's figures in this matter-but also, I think, acknowledges the importance and proper place of the hospital pathology services.
