I noticed that Senator Peter Baume concentrated his comments on private pathology services and I think that is to miss the considerable contribution by pathology through our hospital system and/or our related public pathology provisions.

In regard to the fee rearrangement, it is interesting that Senator Baume kept talking about a 25 per cent cut in those fees for the 18 services mentioned. That is within the bounds of accuracy, but only just. There is to be a 25 per cent reduction in the specialist pathology fees. There is to be a 25 per cent reduction in other pathology services, but that is 25 per cent of 75 per cent of the specialist pathology service, so in real terms it is a lesser amount, and the arrangements proposed will increase the hospital pathology service to become equivalent to the other pathology service. For a number of these services as provided through the hospital system there will be an increase in the return. I think that those needed to have been spelt out. I am somewhat disappointed that Senator Baume did not care to do that. His manner of addressing this Bill was to defend the private pathology services and not go to the examination of the complete system which the Government is proposing in the area of those 18 services. I certainly hope that that significant increase and the increased return to pathology services provided by hospitals will go a small way to redressing the real imbalance that has occurred and the rundown of hospital pathology services which we have seen over the last number of years.

Not only has pathology been taken out of hospitals to a considerable degree, but also pathologists have been leaving. The reason pathologists have been leaving hospital pathology services is the inducement of very significant fees. I wonder whether fees of $100,000 or more per annum would seem to be a reasonable return to a specialist pathologist. I know of many general practitioners in my State of South Australia who would not be unhappy to be earning anything like $100,000 a year. If a service can support private pathologists at that kind of return, I suggest that there is a reason for saying they are getting a reasonable return on the pathology work they are doing.

The point I would particularly like to make is that I hope that this rearrangement will go a long way towards encouraging more pathology work to be done in hospitals. In my State I know of no disreputable pathology services provided through hospitals or through the Institute of Medical and Veterinary Science, which does the majority of the pathology work for the Royal Adelaide Hospital and for other people requiring that service. I will come to that later because I had the experience of working at the IMVS for some time and I can speak of pathology with some real experience, albeit a few years ago. Senator Peter Baume seemed to suggest that we should not be looking at a 25 per cent reduction in the specialist pathology fee. It is interesting that the Minister for Health said in his second reading speech in the other place:

The Public Accounts Committee noted that the top 25 pathology groups billed virtually all pathology at the specialist rate, the percentage varying . . . between 94.6 per cent and 99.9 per cent. In addition, during the period 1982-83 to 1984-85 the number of services billed at the specialist rate increased by 41.9 per cent while during the same period the number of services billed at the . . . other pathology and . . . hospital pathology rates fell by -18.2 per cent and -29.1 per cent respectively.

It is very interesting to take up the points that were raised by Senator Peter Baume about whether or not these costs could be contained. There is absolutely no difference in the cost to a pathologist, whether the tests are carried out by a specialist or a non-specialist-that is a technician. In fact, the tests referred to are mostly done by technicians. For example, the cross-matching of blood, the haemoglobin, the red blood cell count, the white cell count, the packages of biochemistry, particularly those tests that are highly automated, are in large part done by technicians or the scientists in this area. There is very little difference in the cost of the tests to the laboratory, whether the tests are done by technicians or a specialist pathologist, the only difference, of course, being the fee or the salary being paid to the specialist pathologist. We know from the figures I have just read that these tests have largely been transferred to specialist pathology. I think that is a matter of grave concern. I think there is really very good reason to question why suddenly those tests have become specialist services when for years they were not. I think that that drift towards specialist charges for those services is a matter which the Minister for Health very rightly and properly took into account when he came up with this rearranged schedule of fees for the 18 tests.

Senator Baume also made the point that the tests were not necessarily highly automated. The Minister never insisted that they were highly automated. What he said is that they belong with a package of descriptions, that they are high volume and mainly automated. They are highly profitable because the fees have not been adjusted downwards as a consequence of productive technology and they generally involve minimum specialist input-a point to which I have already alluded. To suggest, as the honourable senator did, that because a couple of tests are not automated, others that are should not be considered or that they are high volume and almost invariably never occur as individual tests but are part of a bracket or group of tests I think suggests that his analysis of the reasons the Government and the Minister have taken into account is insufficient. In fact, those tests are more and more automated.

I would like to make some comments about my own experience. For a couple of years I worked in haematology at the IMVS and I saw first hand what was happening to technology at that time. As a pathologist I was on call at night and I had to do at night by hand what was done by machine in a very automated way during the day. The machines tend to suck in a small volume of blood and automatically do a whole range or battery of tests on that sample of blood, whether those tests are requested or not. That is how the machines are set up. That will happen, for example, in a run involving blood being examined for haemoglobin, white blood cell count, red blood cell count and so on or for a batch of biochemistry.

If I had any disappointment in this legislation, it would be that I do not believe it has gone quite far enough in acknowledging the consequences of that automation. Unlike Senator Peter Baume, I hope that the first task of the Pathology Services Advisory Committee will be to review the current level of fees and the appropriateness of pathology items. In particular, I wonder whether we can look forward to seeing introduced very soon a fee for a group of tests. In fact, I am delighted to see pathology being given this kind of consideration because it has seemed to me for many years now unreasonable that the efficiency of tests previously carried out on single items by technicians enjoying a single fee and long since taken over by technology had not been improved. Automation and the significant improvement in the number of tests have not resulted in any cost benefit to the community but in fact have resulted in a massive increase in profits to sections of the pathology service. The Opposition's criticism about this is difficult to take. That benefit of technology, that cost efficiency, has not been passed on to the community. It has been evidenced not in a fall in prices but rather in a considerable increase in profits. I also find it curious that the Opposition is very selective in how it applies its standards of criticism of Government behaviour. The Government is introducing a piece of legislation that is likely to save $60m of taxpayers' money in a full year, and the Opposition is concerned that this might lead to some difficulty for some private pathologists. The Opposition's concern is right. We have that concern; that is exactly what the Government's concern is about. We want to continue to provide excellent pathology services, but if the Opposition was serious about Government expenditure it might at least have shed some words of praise on any provision saving $60m in a full year.

I comment, too, on the removal of item 955 from the Schedule. This refers to the taking of blood, or venepuncture. It is interesting to note that pathologists have been enjoying a nice little return for that service, which very often-I am sure Senator Baume will agree-is not done by the pathologists, not even by doctors, but often by a sister or nurse. Yet the doctor or the pathologist has been receiving a fee for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given my choice, I would rather have the nurse do it sometimes, for competence.

—We should note Senator Baume's comments. I presume we do not take his comment that he would rather have the nurse do it as indicating in any way that he is criticising the medical profession. I heard him say earlier that of course we must not criticise the medical profession, and I am glad he is not criticising it when saying he favours the nursing profession. In a single stroke this provision will save $2,700,000, and I understand there is absolutely no objection to that.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already alluded to the fee rearrangement. As of now there will be two fees, not three as we now have, for those 18 items. The rearrangement of those fees should go a long way not only towards containing costs but also towards preventing overservicing. It is also my hope that it will encourage a resurgence of the excellent hospital pathology that I know about and have taken part in.

A few other items in the Bill are important, including the separation of a new schedule for pathology fees. Senator Baume made the point that there is already a committee in existence to do that, but it is involved with the medical benefits schedule and that whole system over the years has proven to be very unwieldy and inflexible and slow to adjust. I support the proposal to move to a separate schedule for pathology fees and a separate system for examining them on the ground that anything would have to be an improvement on the existing scheme. Hopefully, by separating the two, and focusing more on the task and having a smaller number of items to look at, we will see that happening. I have little doubt that it will be the case.

Another important provision in the legislation is the reduction in number of self-determined tests; that is, extra tests ordered by the pathologists themselves. That is an important and significant matter. There has been a lot of criticism, not so much from Senator Baume but certainly from the other place, that pathologists were not happy, that they had not been consulted. That is incorrect. The Minister for Health acknowledges that the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia supports this measure to limit the number of tests the pathologists themselves can determine. The Royal College of Pathologists also commented in supporting this measure that it believes that perhaps the self-determined tests could be a source of abuse by some laboratories. That is one example of where clearly the College of Pathologists has been consulted. The approval of pathologists and the accreditation of laboratories are two points the Opposition supports, and I am pleased to note that. I would have been surprised if it had done otherwise. But both of those steps go very much to ensuring that some of the difficulties that have been highlighted by the Public Accounts Committee will be reduced or, hopefully, removed.

One point I did want to raise was the mention of conflict of interest between ownership or involvement in pathology services by some doctors. It is interesting to note that Madam Acting Deputy President, Senator Giles, as the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, would be as aware as I am, if not more aware than I am, of the conflict of interests we discovered in that area of medical practice. It is a matter of considerable disappointment to me but I suppose it is also no more than a measure of human behaviour that there are some doctors who have, from time to time, had interests in nursing homes or private hospitals, and here we have mention of interests in pathology services, that quite clearly allow for the potential for conflict of interests. In some cases that Committee found quite clear evidence that bad practices have followed on from that conflict. We would be very pleased to see the removal of anything that might allow that continuation. I am pleased with the way the legislation addresses this matter, and I hope it will remove that possibility for a conflict of interests.

The points raised by the Opposition about lack of consultation are insufficient. I have already referred to the College of Pathologists' comments about self-determined tests and its approval of that, but I can refer honourable senators to the speech by Minister Blewett in the other place, in which he quite clearly dissociated himself from that kind of estimate. In fact, at page 3993 of Hansard, he said:
When I met the College of Pathologists the other day it thanked the Government for the extensive consultations there had been on this matter.

Either the College has been consulted or it has not. I would be surprised if it was thankful for something that did not happen. I accept the Minister's word that there has been consultation. It is also interesting to note, though, that the Australian Medical Association, which has been suggesting that there was insufficient consultation, has the gall even to suggest that, in the light of its recent behaviour when it refused to come to any number of meetings with the Government or refused to look at a review of fees. I congratulate the Government for continuing to try to talk to the AMA at all. Its behaviour has been much less than admirable. Again, of course, it is not every member of the AMA; but I do not believe those people who represent the AMA in those deliberations have been representative of many doctors in this country. I also suggest that if the Opposition wants to get into Labor senators or the Labor Government for their alleged criticism of the medical profession-which, of course, is incorrect, as it ever is; we do not criticise the whole medical profession; we are at pains to draw the distinctions-I also think it is a disappointment that the Opposition does not sometimes suggest that the AMA is less than adequate in its dealings with government, too.

In the Minister's speech in the other place he also read a letter which I find very fascinating. It was an unsolicited letter from a pathologist, and I think it is of such importance that I will read it. The Minister said that he would finish his speech by reading a letter from an ethical specialist pathologist-just the sort that Senator Peter Baume praised-who ran a fairly large laboratory and who exemplified the very best in the medical profession in his response to the Government's legislative measures. The Minister said it was a courageous letter. It read:
Dear Minister,

Consequent to findings by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts on Medical Overservicing in Pathology, your government is enacting inter alia a reduction in schedule fees of pathology tests by 25% for the most commonly performed tests. There is widespread opposition to this fee reduction by pathologists in private practice. As a specialist pathologist of some thirty years standing operating my own private practice in Sydney, currently employing about 100 staff and serving upward of about 300 doctors, I feel you might like to know that there is at least one pathologist who approves the principle of the measure you propose.

Pathology is a desirable and necessary scientific adjunct to the proper practice of medicine and has until recent years been an honourable profession requiring years of specialized training on the part of both the pathologist and the technologist. But today the profession is seen by the public as an industry motivated by gain, given to unethical practices like overservicing and actual fraud. To the disgrace of the profession there is a big element of truth to this. Now that we have a National Health Service, the cost of medicine is borne by taxpayers, and you act properly as Minister to protect the taxpayer from those abusing the system for their own pecuniary gain. In addition, you are upholding the true cause of medical science and acting to restore public confidence in the medical profession and pathology in particular. Those dedicated to medicine and pathology will support you for doing what the profession has been unable to do for itself.
I look for continuing scrutiny of the effectiveness of the measures to reduce the attractiveness of pathology to the entrepreneur.

If it will be of any help to ascertain the costs of providing a service in a medium-sized, large automated laboratory, or any other purpose, then my laboratory and its books are open to you or your representatives.
The line in that letter that is most telling is the one that says:
Those dedicated to medicine and pathology will support you-
that is, the Minister and the Government-
for doing what the profession has been unable to do for itself.

That is a very telling comment from a private pathologist of the sort whom we wish to support. There is no dispute between me and Senator Peter Baume in that respect, we are entirely in agreement; but I believe that the line that I have just read out needs to be remembered. The pathology profession has not itself been able to prevent fraud and overservicing; this pathologist is grateful to the Government for doing it and doing it in a way that will involve pathologists and allow ethical pathologists to continue with their practices as they always have done. I believe that the letter should be noted and that it is representative of many pathologists.

I support Senator Baume in saying that pathology is a significant part of the medical profession, although I certainly know a number of doctors who feel that the more pathology grows the less medical skills grow. In times past doctors could ascertain a lot of what they now require clever pathology to do, but I am not suggesting that we should revert to the pre-pathology days-not at all. We need to celebrate and acknowledge the contribution of pathologists. This legislation goes all the way to doing that and has not only addressed the question to this point but also put in place structures that will guarantee honourable pathology and honourable pathology laboratories and practice. It also establishes a responsible committee to continue to oversee pathology services and to ensure that the difficulties that have occurred in this part of the medical profession hopefully will not arise again. In fact, the Minister has set up structures to help the pathology discipline to keep an eye on itself. I certainly commend the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 that is before us tonight has been introduced by this Government in an attempt to address the issues identified by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the problems of fraud and overservicing in the area of pathology. As Senator Peter Baume has already pointed out, the moves within this legislation to prohibit fee splitting and render illegal the sort of kick-backs that operate in some areas are supported by us all because these practices do nothing to advance the attitude of the general public towards a proud and generally honourable profession. Problems with the administration of a segment of the practitioners within the pathology field have been with us for some time in this country and, as Senator Baume said, steps were taken during the years of the Fraser Government to address the fee scales applicable to pathology services and to reduce incentives to overservicing by the profession. Those moves were made not through legislation but through administrative methods, and this Bill is another step in the direction of combatting the sorts of unsavoury practices that have been put into place by a minority of the profession which does no service at all to its colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the amounts of money involved from the public purse, it is crucial however that we deal with this problem expeditiously. Of course, it is also important that we do not deal with it in such a way that we disadvantage a section of the pathology profession which is, in fact, operating honourably and within all the tenets of its professional oath. The excesses which, it seems to me, at times approach racketeering and which exist within a small segment of the profession are costing this country enormous amounts of money. As one of the partners of the Queensland Medical Laboratory pointed out to me, the vast majority of ethical private pathology practices provide a comprehensive range of testing, and they are owned and operated by specialist pathologists who have been admitted to fellowship of the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia on examination and after a minimum of five years of post-graduate training. In contrast, many laboratories allegedly indulging in overservicing are owned by a variety of medical and non-medical persons without the relevant specialist qualifications. I do not think that many people in the Senate or elsewhere would argue with that. Nevertheless, it is also true to say that last year payments for pathology services amounted to something like 15 per cent of Federal expenditure on medical benefits, at a cost to the taxpayer of nearly $350m.

The incidence of pathology services has also increased dramatically, as has the proportion of pathology services which are billed at the specialist rate. Between 1979 and 1985 the overall number of pathology services increased by 69 per cent, notwithstanding the sorts of measures that were undertaken in good faith by the Fraser Government. The number of pathology services provided at the specialist rate, attracting a higher fee is reputed at least to have increased by something over 110 per cent in the same period. This tendency towards billing in the highest fee bracket is most clearly evident in the most financially successful of Australia's pathology companies. The Public Accounts Committee observed that the top 25 pathology groups billed between 94 and 99 per cent of their services at the specialist rate. However the increasing proportion of services being billed at the specialist rate is not being matched by an equally increasing proportion of this work being performed by specialist pathologists. It seems that the problem starts and finishes there.

The precise extent to which these figures reflect overservicing is not clear, and government estimates are always suspect, I guess, simply because they are government estimates. But the Government estimates that the operation of this legislation before us tonight will result in savings of some $60m a year. Senator Crowley has already mentioned that figure. It has been disputed in letters that have been sent to me and in conversations that I have had with pathologists. As I said, I suspect that, like many government figures, it is something that has been plucked out of the air. Of course, we will only know some considerable way down the track whether that $60m in savings is an accurate figure or whether it was a figment of this Government's imagination, chosen in order to persuade people that there is a considerable rort going on in the system.

However, a number of pathologists who have made representations to me, as well as suggesting that these figures are not accurate, have indicated their concern that the Bill will not put an end to fraud and overservicing-in somewhat the same manner, I guess, as the introduction of the Australia Card will not put an end to the criminal element of social security and tax fraud-because many of those sorts of people are in a position to get around the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will continue to operate legally.

—Yes, they will simply get through or around the system using loopholes because they have a fairly massive incentive to do so. So the pathologists are concerned that the sorts of people who need to be stopped will not necessarily be stopped by this legislation. However, generally, as Senator Peter Baume said, with the exception of the proposal relating to the reduction in fees, pathologists are tending to support the legislation. Indeed, they have expressed to me, as they have obviously expressed to Senator Peter Baume and also to Senator Crowley, a concern that in some ways the legislation does not go far enough. The Society of Pathologists in Private Practice, for example, does not believe that this Bill picks up all of the recommendations of the PAC report that it should pick up, or that the measures proposed are the most efficient or effective way of curbing the current abuses.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly concerned by arguments that have been put to me by that group of pathologists that the proposal will inhibit the legitimate business of the co-called ethical practitioners more than it will hinder the unethical pathologists determined to boost their profits by whatever loopholes they can find in this or any other piece of legislation. I accept those arguments to a certain extent, but I believe that the unethical so-called entrepreneurs-I suspect that description includes, at least in part, a rather notable organisation that operates in Senator Baume's State-will continue to find loopholes to exploit in any system which is introduced. That, I guess, is a fact of life. The profession itself may take some steps to remove those people who are putting the profession in a bad light, but I am not sure that we as legislators can do much more than we are currently doing.

Obviously, these proposals should have been developed with much earlier and much more thorough consultation with members of the profession, notwithstanding Senator Crowley's comments that there was more than adequate consultation with the groups concerned. If those that came to see me are any indication, most believe that their concerns have not been adequately responded to by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). That may well have been due to pressure of business on his part or simply to a certain arrogance. One is never quite sure with the current Minister. In any event, they are concerned quite seriously and quite genuinely with what they perceive as lack of consultation, and they believe that those who work in the area on an everyday basis and who have a very real knowledge of the problems and the gaps in the system as it exists should be the ones who are most consulted. They believe that not only their interests but also their concerns for the profession and its reputation should be taken into account. This sort of concern, as I said, sometimes reflects more on the particular working style of the Minister than on anything else.

The provisions of this Bill are, as Senator Baume said in his speech, something of a mixed bag. We support the majority of them, as does the Opposition. The Bill attempts to introduce a number of major changes. It revises arrangements for determining approved pathology practitioner status; it introduces accreditation of pathology laboratories and limits the payments of benefits to services performed in accredited laboratories; it requires request forms for pathology services which will be used by referring practitioners to be approved by the Health Insurance Commission; and it establishes a Pathology Services Advisory Committee allegedly to advise the Minister on services for inclusion in a pathology services table and an appropriate fee for those services. Like Senator Baume, I will wait with somewhat bated breath to see how successful that Committee is. I echo his comment that its success will rest very much on the sorts of people who are put on that Committee. While, I think, three of the seven members of the Committee are to come from lists provided by the pathologists and by the Australian Medical Association and the Chairman is to come from, of all places, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, there are still four whose appointment is to be left absolutely to the Government. That of, course, can make or break the value of any committee, particularly one which is inquiring into something as touchy, shall we say, as this matter.

The Bill also prohibits particular practices which take place between the various parties involved in ordering and providing pathology services, such as pathologists providing a variety of so-called inducements to doctors to order more services than are necessary, ranging from the provision of service order forms in a particular format to various sorts of kickbacks and to what appears, if newspaper reports are occasionally to be believed, to be outright threats and bribery. It also restructures the fee schedules applicable to pathology services and reduces some of the fees. The specialist pathology rate will be reduced to the ordinary pathology rate for the 18 most commonly asked for tests and those which are automated.

The Australian Democrats, as I said, will be supporting this legislation in principle although, again as I have said, we have some concerns about particular provisions. As Senator Peter Baume has indicated, he-and we too-will be seeking assurances and undertakings from the Minister with relation to those concerns, with regard, for example, to the level of cuts made in the 18 tests singled out by this legislation. Specifically we want a referral of those fee schedules to the soon to be established committee for review. As I have said, most pathologists who have made representations to us have supported the general thrust of this legislation. Their main objections have concerned, not surprisingly, the proposed reduction of pathology fees, which they see, again not unnaturally, as a threat to their very existence.

While we support these fee reductions in principle, as I said a moment ago, we think they could well be reviewed by the new committee. The current fee levels fail, for example, to take account of increasing automation and the increasing high frequency with which the particular 18 tests are conducted. In combination with the existing structure of the fee schedule the levels of fees for these consequently extremely profitable tests undoubtedly provide an incentive for overservicing by the minority unscrupulous element in the profession. With the contribution made to current pathology testing by medical scientists and technology, to use the words of the Minister, the current SP fee rate provides a `professional premium' which is more than can be justified by the specialist pathologist's professional input in relation to these 18 tests. However, on the other side of the coin, the argument has also been put to me that the amount of reduction of the SP rate of fees by 25 per cent is somewhat arbitrary, to say nothing of excessive. While we accept, as I said, the principle of the reduction, I certainly seek an absolute assurance from the Minister for Health or the Minister representing the Minister that the items and fees in question will be referred expeditiously to the proposed Pathology Services Advisory Committee.

In passing, I would like some indication from the Minister as to when exactly that Committee will get off the ground. There is not much point in seeking an assurance from the Minister that he will refer a question of a fee to the Committee if it is not going to be up and running fairly shortly. The Minister's statement in the second reading debate on this Bill in another place that he proposes to request a review by the Committee at what he called an early stage is simply not appropriate. It is reasonable of the Senate to demand of the Minister a more accurate time scale than merely `at an early stage'.

The other concerns that have been expressed to me about the Committee include, as I think I mentioned earlier, its composition. Some concern has been expressed to me about the selection of Chairman and the source of that selection. Some concern has been expressed to me about the powers of referral to the Committee and a suggestion has been made that new section 78cc could well be extended beyond merely reference from the Minister or on its own initiative to include, for example, references from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, from a Senate standing committee, or even a Senate select committee, or a simple resolution from either House of Parliament about something which is causing concern to senators or members.

Another concern that has been raised with me and with my Queensland colleague has been the situation which obtains in Queensland. Here the specialist pathologists do tend to do more work of specialist value as a result of the nature of the Queensland hospital system. The situation in Queensland has differed from that in other States because of the long history of the free public hospitals in that State. The public hospitals in Queensland did not allow private medicine and, as a consequence, a private hospital system grew up in Queensland to a much greater extent per capita than it did in any other State. Because of this the private pathology services were actually specialist services for service to hospitals as distinct from pseudo-specialist services for service to general practitioner medicine. So there is a particular case to be dealt with in the Queensland situation. Again, I suggest that the Government has not really paid a great deal of attention to that peculiarity in this legislation. I would be interested to know from the Minister whether or not any assessment of the effect of this legislation on the Queensland pathologists has been made and, if it has, what the Government's assessment is. Furthermore, if there is some dispute between the Queensland pathologists' assessment of the effect on them of the legislation and the Government's assessment, I ask whether the Minister is prepared to refer that question to the newly formed Pathology Services Advisory Committee when it takes up the general question of fees.

Like the Opposition, the Australian Democrats support many parts of this legislation. Our concerns lie with the arbitrary way in which some fees seem to have been cut, with the impact this could have on the Queensland situation, and with whether the Government has paid a sufficient amount of attention to that impact. Unfortunately, as I understand it, our hands are virtually tied with regard to making any changes to this legislation. If we defeat any part of this legislation, the Bill as a whole is held up for some months and the better parts of the legislation, therefore, will not be able to be put into practice. Furthermore, and probably more importantly, I understand that if the Schedule that is attached to the legislation is deleted and the subsequent regulations establishing the new lower fees for the 18 most common tests are disallowed, the fees, and hence the medical benefits payable, drop back to 1973 levels. This is not going to help anybody-not the pathologist and certainly not the patient. So it is unfortunate not just that the Senate's hands are tied but that the House's hands were also tied with regard to this piece of legislation simply because of the unfortunate effects that could have occurred had we taken up the normal opportunity of amending or deleting certain parts of the legislation or, some time down the track, taking up our option for disallowance.

In concluding, I echo again Senator Peter Baume's comments that this Bill is indeed good in parts, that we all support an extension of the Fraser Government's original moves to eliminate some of the problems in this area, problems that were bringing an honourable profession into disrepute, unfortunately and unnecessarily. We certainly support moves to prohibit things such as fee splitting and kickbacks and moves to eliminate the major part of fraud, overservicing and abuse generally in the pathology part of medical care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a special interest in the debate that is taking place on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill. I merely wish to take up the Senate's time for a few minutes to indicate the position of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on this legislation. The Public Accounts Committee is pleased that the Government has so promptly taken up many of its recommendations, but there are some residual concerns that will mean that the Committee will examine this legislation and also the response from the Department, which we have not as yet received. That will be the basis of a further, and I trust final, report on medifraud and overservicing which we expect to bring down in August.

SPEECH.PARA: Those who believe that scrutiny by the Public Accounts Committee has been brought to an end can rest assured that a further scrutiny will take place. The Committee has been patient, hoping that some of the revelations that were made in the last report would be taken up by the respective authorities and that some of the problems which have not been addressed in this legislation would have been addressed in another fashion. We are concerned that much of the information which was revealed was of such a nature that certain people should have been brought to account. The reasons for their not being brought to account is now a matter for further examination as to whether the legislation which has been enacted by Parliament is sufficient to curb some of the extravagances of certain members-I stress certain members-of the medical profession. In our report we stressed that it was a minority of doctors who were involved in unethical practices which affected the whole of the health delivery service. We asked the Australian Medical Association to take particular heed of the fact that it was not possible without the co-operation of the profession itself to contain the problem.

Most sections of the medical profession have responded constructively, but certain sections of the profession have taken the Committee to task and accused it of invasion of individual rights and other associated matters. We again express a wish that the medical profession through the AMA, its most responsible body, take the necessary step that we believe to be available to it to prevent an escalation of the problem which this legislation will not prevent. I believe that by the reduction of the fees the ethical section of the profession will suffer, but that the unethical section of the profession will adjust itself to maintain its level of return, which may lead one to anticipate an increase rather than a decrease in overservicing.

One has to be careful that in imposing these limitations on one section of the medical profession, particularly pathology-and perhaps I should also include radiology-one may deprive the community of a service that is essential in a preventive sense, and that, because of abuses of the system, limiting the whole of the system can lead to a loss rather than a gain. I assure the House that the Public Accounts Committee will present a further report on this matter-we trust, towards the end of August-and this legislation will come under scrutiny. I do not want in any way to denigrate the legislation because it has gone a considerable way to pick up the errors that were so dramatically exposed by the Public Accounts Committee, but still much more needs to be done. It may be that further legislation is required to strengthen by regulation the self-regulation of the industry itself, because it is fairly obvious that there is an inability on the part of the profession to bring some respectability, should I say economic respectability, to the profession.

Personally I find it hard to accept that the exposures of the Public Accounts Committee in the pathology area may lead to an increase in instead of a lessening of the excesses, because there seems to be a rush by a substantial section of the medical profession not to correct what has been happening but in fact to become part of what is happening. We now have a rush to join the Edelsten style of health service. There appears to be the possibility of a proliferation of the 24-hour medical services, which, in my mind, can survive economically only if they overservice. If such overservicing has been done by two or three practitioners, we can imagine the impact if it were to be done by many more. The idea seems to be developing that if you cannot beat them, you join them. It seems to me that the medical profession, under the advice of certain slick accountants and commercial advisers-

TALK.START.PARA: —You can stop that easily; stop bulk billing.

—By way of reply to the interjection, I suggest that the honourable senator might look at a fee for service system. Is she prepared to look at the fee for service system and question whether that is at the base of the problem? I think it possibly is.
—Cut out bulk billing.

—If I am forced to an ideological position, I suggest to the honourable senator that we might look at fee for service. The sooner the community wakes up to that, the better. Then we will not have any problems with bulk billing. I tried as much as possible in the examination of the problem before us, especially on the Committee, to place ideological positions to one side and to look exactly to what is needed within the system as it operates at present. Let me assure Senator Walters that, if we do not address the problem, we will be forced to change the system completely because the country cannot afford the excesses revealed by the Committee's report into pathology services. Neither can the country afford the further excesses that are likely to be imposed by a profession that seems to have lost its ethical base.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Health Legislation Amendment Bill. The stated purpose of that Bill is to look at the medical pathology profession and to seek to eliminate what have been identified and described as malpractices. Whether this Bill will do so requires careful analysis. The fact of the matter is that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has found certain irregularities. For example, there is evidence of such malpractices as fee splitting between doctors and pathologists, kickbacks in that regard, overservicing and fraud. The interesting thing is that we do not have before us any real measure of the magnitude of this. In a moment or two I will try to define the magnitude suggested from the amounts of money outlayed and alleged to be saved.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that every honourable senator who has spoken has indicated that by and large the majority of the profession are highly ethical and carry out their practices with high integrity. Indeed, Senator Georges, who has just sat down, said that the Public Accounts Committee was convinced that only a minority of doctors were creating this aberration; but he concluded with a much broader brush-and I reject his conclusion in that regard.

The fact is that one has to determine in the first place what is overservicing and what is a backyard situation. To the extent that this legislation seeks to give accreditation to proper laboratories and seeks to upgrade the system, to the extent that it will eliminate bad practices, kickbacks and fee splitting and to the extent that it will eliminate any form of fraud, no one could object to it. The real question is: What is overservicing, what is its nature and if it exists how has it come about? Pathology services are simply diagnostic tools. Everybody knows that in the last decade or two diagnostic services have increased, in their range, in their ability to assist the general practitioner or specialist and in their high technology and mechanisation. The real question is: How often should the doctor resort to them, to what range of them should he resort? What is servicing, what is good, conscientious medicine and what is bad medicine when a doctor goes too far?

Senator Crowley created her own dilemma. She was puzzled as to whether improved pathology was not having an effect upon the diagnostic skills of the doctor. That is not a generalisation but a reflection on the scheme in which the doctor works. Senator Georges is a strong socialist. I reject his ideology but I respect him for his beliefs. He said that we might have to look at fee for service and get away from bulk billing. Let me put the following situation to honourable senators: A general practitioner or a specialist is with a patient. He has two kinds of dilemma. He knows that his judgment might be right on a particular matter but it could be supported if he used a number of diagnostic aids, diagnostic procedures. Why should he not do that? If he bulk bills, that helps him a great deal. Firstly he can, with conscience, request the patient to come back. The visit would not cost the patient and therefore, in conscience, he is urged that way. There is no charge to the patient when pathology is bulk billed, so the doctor can conscientiously say to himself: Why should I not use those extra diagnostic tools? Who, indeed, is to judge in this situation? Who is to decide whether it is more right for the doctor to use his intuition, his art, as well as his science in this situation or whether he should seek aids?

If honourable senators want to see the major uses of pathology procedures they should go to any public hospital and look at what is done for patients by the intern or resident. The intern or resident, knowing that his master-the registrar-and the visiting medical officer will want to know everything, will take the procedures across the board because he will not want to make any mistakes or be neglectful. It is the narrowing of that procedure that is important. Who is to say what is done for reasons of conscience and what is overservicing?

Senator Crowley thought she was doing something very skilful indeed by reading a letter from an unnamed pathologist, who employs some 300 staff, I think, in New South Wales to the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett. The pathologist said that he supported Dr Blewett and I accept that. However, Senator Crowley did not finish the exercise. That pathologist said: `If you want, come amongst us and measure my practice, measure my costs, see what I am doing and then you can get a balance'. That would have been a very good test for Dr Blewett to have done. He had an invitation from a major pathology practice to measure it, test it, look at its costs and procedures and then to use it as a yardstick for others. If we had had the yardstick here today we would have been much better off.

I am thoroughly puzzled. We have a figure which was given to us and which, I think, Senator Haines quoted-presumably it is from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and from the Budget-that the cost of pathology is $350m a year. Senator Crowley said that there would be a saving of $60m. I want honourable senators to do a little mental exercise. First, we are told that the breaches in the pathology are small and that they are confined to a minority of people. If in fact we would save $60m, it has to be a net $60m. I want to point out that if we take from the doctors, their companies or their proprietary companies the millions of dollars, they, as companies or people, will pay less income tax-they must do so. So the $60m is a net amount. What the Government is talking about is a sum of $100m or more. What is being put to the Senate, unless my maths are wrong, is that about one-third of all these practices are going out of business. That is a nonsense. Nobody here has said that.

Senator Peter Baume, himself a consultant physician, has indicated that the pathology profession is a highly ethical profession, which is run by a learned college which sets high standards and it is admitted by everybody that the majority of its practitioners are obeying the rules. So we are dealing with a smaller number of people. That is what Senator Georges said. I would like the Minister to tell us how he works out a saving of $60m on $350m. At the very worst, if there were no loss of income tax at all by the Government, we would be dealing with a cost cutting situation of about 20 per cent. It is much more than that; it is about a third.

I think that we are getting very faulty information. For instance, we are told that some doctors have arrangements in nursing homes. I think it was Senator Crowley who told us that. It is very easy to get up in this Senate and make claims of that kind. Those who are listening to us will imagine that there are thousands of doctors outside who own shares in nursing homes and who shove their patients into them to increase their profits. I am told-I have no basic evidence myself-that the number of doctors who have shares in nursing homes and who put their patients in those homes can be counted on slightly more than one hand-about six. That is about right. If that is so, let us get the dimensions right.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is written up in the report.

—Senator Walters interjects that that is written up in the report. It is either right or wrong. If that is right, it is disgraceful for someone to get up in this Senate and communicate to the people of Australia that doctors have all got a foot in the door of nursing homes and are shoving their patients in those homes and making great profits. If they are, we should do something about it; but if almost no doctors are doing so, we need to correct the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental point is this: The national health scheme which this Government has brought in, a socialist scheme, has done the very reverse of what it set out to do. It is sold, as so many socialist schemes are, as something which takes away from the rich and will help the poor, that it will reach out to all the poor and give them a high quality service. The fact of the matter is that before this Parliament and before the coming Budget is a great dilemma. The cost of medical services is accelerating enormously and the standard of delivery of these services, particularly to the underprivileged, is decreasing very rapidly. The first thing is that if we want to stop overservicing we must look to what role wholesale bulk billing plays in creating the state of mind of the doctor. A decent doctor may say: `Yes, I can bring my patient back. No, I won't rely on my diagnostic skills; I will get some more information and it won't cost the patient anything'. The other doctor, who is less ethical, may say: `Let me overservice-the Government pays, not the patient'. One has to look at the very heart of the socialist scheme to see that in the end the more one encourages this sort of thinking, the more one hurts the ordinary people.

The Premiers are going to be told that they are going to suffer massive cutbacks. The hospital systems around Australia at the moment are in an extraordinary state of disrepair. The public hospital systems, which have provided excellent high quality and high skilled services to the underprivileged of Australia-and let us not have any doubt about that; that is where the underprivileged come into contact with the best qualified specialists that this country could provide-are shedding their beds, shedding their qualified staff and degenerating in their capacity to deliver.

TALK.START.PARA: —They cannot hold nurses.

—Senator Peter Baume says that they cannot get nurses. But it goes further than that. I think that the honourable senator referred to Royal North Shore Hospital, where he used to practise. I think about 150 beds have now gone from that hospital. The position is similar wherever one may go. Westmead Hospital probably has 200 beds not open. The position is much the same at Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in my State of New South Wales. Hundreds of beds are lying idle and yet patients are lining up for the treatment of quite serious health problems. Who are those patients? They are not the rich. The rich can go to the specialist in his rooms or to the private hospitals and get treatment. The people who are being penalised at the moment by this socialist system are the underprivileged people who cannot afford to pay for private hospital treatment and who, incidentally, have been told by this Government that they need not privately insure. This is the Government that in fact abolished gap insurance. It is the Government which set out to discourage providence and thrift.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have a situation in which two terrible trends have emerged throughout Australia. In the first place queues and queues-tens of thousands of people-are waiting for treatment. It is fair to say that in most public hospitals in my State no elective surgery is being carried out at all. A person who is not in absolutely acute need or does not require emergency treatment cannot have, say, a hernia patched, a hysterectomy done or a hip replacement carried out in a public hospital. The queues are more than a year long. We are now outrivalling the British system of nationalised medicine. This is the Government that said that it was setting up a system that would help the poor.

It is more tragic than that. The great teaching hospitals themselves have given of their skills in a number of ways. The best of the visiting medical specialists were attracted to those hospitals to do two things-to teach the interns, the residents and the registrars, and to pass their skill on to build a system which would pass on skills. They are the people who have, over the generations, given of their skills to the public who use the public hospitals-the underprivileged and, by and large, the poor. By and large over the years these people have had the skills of the best of the visiting medical officers who could be attracted to the hospitals. Equally, the young interns and residents being trained have had the great advantage of working among the top people. Tragically, many of the top visiting medical officers are going from the public hospital system. This is primarily because they cannot work within the system and because this Government created a series of regulations which made the situation intolerable for them. Indeed, Dr Penington in his report on the rights of private practice in public hospitals recommended quite a number of reforms. In my State alone the disappearance of first class specialists from the public hospitals is creating a great crisis in the hospital system; not only, as I said, in regard to waiting lists, although that is one terrible thing, but also because we now do not have the structure to train the young doctors as they come on. It would be reasonable for us to turn to a widening of the private hospital system so that if the top specialists go to private hospitals, the public could go to them there. Incredibly, the New South Wales Labor Government has said that it will restrict the growth of private hospitals. So it will stop people going to private hospitals and force them more and more into the queues for the public hospitals.

What a nonsense it is when socialism applies itself to these things. We had a system in which something like 90 per cent of the public were, one way or another, in some kind of medical, health or hospital scheme. People joined the schemes and elected to have their own specialists and private or intermediate beds, and they could get service immediately. This Government said it would not have any of that at all. It set out, basically, to cut down the voluntary health schemes. It pooh-poohed the idea of gap insurance and, as it wanted to do, it has made everybody reliant on the Government. In doing so it has recreated the system that has existed for something like 20 to 30 years or more in England. Indeed, if we did not learn from England we should have watched the Canadian experience. Whenever socialists are in power they wait for an accident to happen overseas so they can copy it. The socialists are attracted hypnotically towards socialist experiments overseas, particularly those that go bad.

Tomorrow the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will tell the world what he has failed to tell us for something like three years. For these years he has said that this country is burgeoning, it is wonderful, it is prosperous, everything is going right. Suddenly we are told that we are in recession. Suddenly we are told by Labor Ministers opposite at Question Time that we will have to cut people's living standards. It is quite remarkable that the Government could on one day say one thing and then on another day say, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did, that we are on our way to becoming a Third World country or a banana republic. The truth is that we have had two quarters of recession.

What will happen? The Government is setting to, cutting away at all sorts of things, because it has a problem of overexpenditure. The fact is that in its Medicare system it has created an absolute monster. The burgeoning of Medicare costs will force the pruning of a whole host of very important government functions. When the Treasurer or the Prime Minister mentions the pruning shears in all sorts of places, we should bear in mind that much of that pruning would not be necessary if the socialists had not decided that they wanted to impose on the people their blueprint of organised, institutionalised medicine. The great danger is that with the hospital system in a terrible way-not only with the shortage of nurses but with everything else I have mentioned-the process of moving towards good and necessary reforms in pathology and other procedures could be at risk. I think Senator Georges even hinted that the Government is doing exactly the wrong thing. It is having the ethical people obey and the unethical ones jumping through the fence, so we will have higher costs than we had before.

We will not oppose this legislation. There are a number of amendments that are self-indicating but I understand that it is necessary that the legislation goes through. The fact is, though, that this has been brought before us with totally insufficient information. It is not good enough for us not to know, first of all, whether Senator Peter Baume is right in saying that of those 18 procedures the fees for which are to be cut, blood-matching is not an automated procedure. Another medical colleague on my right indicates that he agrees with that. If it is not a mechanised procedure and, indeed, if it goes in with 17 other procedures on the basis that it is, we are being told wrongly altogether.

In any case, I come back to this: What kind of humbug is it when the Minister can incorporate a letter from what he says is the ideal-and well it might be-pathology practice, a big group practice employing 300 employees, which says' `Yes, chase the villains; yes, you are right in doing what you are. Come and have a look and you can examine our books' but the Minister did not go and examine its books? Why is it that we have information before us that is lacking in detail? Why do we not know the costs of running ordinary procedures in a proper ethical practice so that we can therefore say `That one is wrong', or `The other one is wrong'?

When one applies a socialist mind to this, one comes back to the dilemma I want to finish on. Over the years until specific medicine-I interpolate by saying that specific medicine is 45 years old; it is only 45 years ago that the fungi, the penicillins, the antibiotics and the sulphur drugs emerged-medicine was primarily palliative, with few other aids. It was then recognised as more of an art than a science. It certainly balances art and science. Suddenly in the last 40 years there has been a burgeoning of technology in medical aids to the general practitioner and specialist which enable much more accurate diagnosis. My goodness, do we not want that?

I do not know whether what I now say is accurate or not, but I am told that the patients in public hospitals who are there due to wrong drug therapy and the adverse effects of drug therapy can be as many as 20 per cent of patients. I believe that has been reported on in learned journals throughout the world. If this is so, how much more important it is that we should not force doctors away from proper diagnostic skills and diagnostic aids and just simply leave them in that comfort that Senator Crowley prayed for. Would we not be better off if we did not allow pathology to advance and we just went back to the diagnostic skills of the doctor?.

We must never be frightened of modern science. The CAT scans-computerised axial tomography-and all the other great advances are all proper aids to be used correctly. We may not have yet learned the restraints that are necessary in using them-when and when not to use them-but I put to honourable senators what I started with: If a general practitioner or specialist has a patient about whom he has in his mind the question, `Should I or should I not get some tests just to confirm my reading of the patient's situation', if that medical practitioner is operating under a socialist medical system which says, `I can do this and have the patient get those procedures without overt cost to the patient; I can do this having the patient returning for a second visit without extra cost to the patient and without the patient looking at the bill, why should I not do that?' is that not ethical? Where do ethics start and where do they finish? I do not believe that the Public Accounts Committee has given us sufficient evidence of the whole condition.

I repeat that, if there is any kind of villainy at all, any kind of malpractice in the pathology profession, it should be chased, found, and hounded out. If there is fee splitting, if there are kickbacks, if there is overservicing and fraud, yes, we should get rid of them. There are a number of measures in this Bill which may well do good, such as the provision accrediting laboratories. We do not want backyard laboratories. There are matters, such as the establishment of the Pathology Services Advisory Committee, which we can put on challenge and see how they work. But when it is all finished, when we look at it all, when we take it as part of the whole health system and remember what is happening to the hospital system in Australia today and to the general costs of medicine, we must bear this in mind: Today we are paying much, much more for medicine and the underprivileged and the poor in this country are getting much, much less. If this goes on, the situation will get worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly appreciated that contribution from Senator Sir John Carrick. He outlined very precisely and distinctly the problems that Australia is suffering as a result of Medicare. Tonight I wish to address the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 as it impacts on my State of Queensland. The arbitrary decision of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) to reduce the cost of the 18 most common pathology tests by 25 per cent will mean that the two major pathology laboratories in Queensland will make a loss. The net effect will be a reduction in fees by 12 per cent after the reduction in the rebate of 25 per cent is brought in under this legislation. These laboratories at present are working on a small profit margin and they estimate that they will make a loss if they maintain their fees at the present level and accept the bulk billing charges. They maintain that the losses they will sustain will be around the $3m mark. That is a lot to carry. No business can carry those sorts of losses.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is unfair to the pathology laboratories, which are offering an excellent service in Queensland. The fees that they are currently charging were set by an independent tribunal after taking evidence from all parties. Those fees were set 18 months ago and have not increased. There are few businesses in Australia that could maintain their fees over an 18-month period and very few which could sustain a 25 per cent profit drop. By arbitrarily making a decision and overriding the previous committee that established these fees, the Minister has, by the stroke of a pen, reduced these fees by 25 per cent. This legislation establishes a new Pathology Services Advisory Committee, so surely the right way to go about this would have been to ask that new Committee to investigate the level of fees and come up with suggestions which were reasonable and which offered the pathology laboratories a modest profit but certainly did not force them to make a loss. But the Minister has gone about this the wrong way. He has appointed the Committee but has not allowed that Committee to make any ruling on the fees. I certainly cannot understand what the Minister is about.

The Minister told us in his second reading speech that a number of unethical practices are being carried out by some pathology laboratories and that the reduction in fees would weed them out. Senator Georges and Senator Puplick have spoken in this chamber on unethical practices. No one wishes unethical practices to continue, but the across the board action of the Minister in arbitrarily setting a fee will only affect the honest, reliable and respectable pathologist who offers good service. It will not hit at the unethical pathologists, as both Senator Georges and Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned in their speeches. If the Minister and the Health Department know the shonks, they should weed out those people by not offering them accreditation. I believe that is the way the problem should be handled. We should get rid of the unethical people by not licensing their laboratories and we should leave the ethical people to do the good job that they are presently doing.

The Minister for Health is on record as saying in Queensland that there is no place for private pathology in Australia. His actions in bringing this legislation forward show that he is trying to achieve that aim. I believe that the Minister is trying to get rid of private pathology in Australia. I stand to be corrected, but I think the Minister made that statement at an Australian Medical Association convention on the Gold Coast. I ask the other medical disciplines: Who will be the next to be socialised? Will it be the radiographers or the neurologists? Who will be next in the queue to go down the socialist line?

Even the Minister must now have grave doubts about Medicare, which was the first step to get doctors to work for the Government with the introduction of bulk billing. As Senator Sir John Carrick said, a great many doctors-they may be ethical doctors-have a conflict of interest. They do not know whether they should get patients to come back to see them again. With bulk billing it does not cost the patient anything to do so. Many patients are now calling on their doctors because, with bulk billing, it is not costing them anything to do so. This is running up costs in this country. It is running up the medical service debt to a point where we cannot sustain it.

It is interesting to note that the trade unions in the United Kingdom are demanding private medicine and the right to the doctor of their choice as part of their employment package because they realise now that private health care provides a better service for them and their families. They realise that the national health service-that is the United Kingdom equivalent of Medicare-is letting them down badly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The unions have helped destroy it in the UK.

—They have helped to destroy the system and now they want to opt out of it. They have found that it just cannot offer them the medical care that they want for their families and for themselves. The Government should also realise what is happening to Medicare in relation to hospitals in Victoria and New South Wales. There are long waiting lists-long queues of people who want urgent surgery. Even in Queensland, the Queensland Government is putting in 80c in every dollar to maintain its hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister in his second reading speech made a comparison between pathology charges in New Zealand and in Australia and he came to the conclusion that they were much lower in New Zealand. I ask whether he has made a comparison with pathology charges in the United Kingdom and the United States of America. If he had done that comparison he would have found that charges in those two countries are certainly higher than those in Australia. In Queensland most of the pathology is done in two laboratories-the Queensland Medical Laboratory and the laboratory of Doctors Sullivan, Nicolaides and Partners. These two laboratories employ 900 people each and offer Queensland an excellent pathology service. They offer a 24-hour service, seven days a week, 365 days of the year and put through over one million-I think 1,300,000-pathology tests a year between them. They pick up and deliver in country towns and the results of the tests are phoned back two or three hours after the tests are done. The tests are carried out in the laboratories but there are pick-up and delivery points throughout Queensland and the northern parts of New South Wales.

These two laboratories are now facing the prospect of cutting services in the country towns. They have reduced services in Cunnamulla and one or two other country areas and I am told that they will have to make further reductions in staff and further cuts in their pick-up operations in the country areas. The two laboratories are run by doctors in partnership and all the partners are specialists in various fields of pathology. The laboratories in Queensland have specialists administering the tests, so the Minister cannot say with any credibility that they are charging specialist rates without having specialist supervision.

TALK.START.PARA: —But are the people doing the tests qualified?

—Yes, they are doing the tests. Not only are pathologists standing there doing the tests but also many of them are phoning the doctors back and offering doctors in the country areas of Queensland and the northern areas of New South Wales specialist services over the phone. They are advising them and consulting them over the phone. They are offering absolutely specialist services not only in testing but also in consulting, for which they are not charging any special fee. That is part of the service.
—You would agree that the technicians are qualified technicians working under qualified pathologists?

—Certainly. There are 900 people working for each of these laboratories and, of course, those 900 people are not specialists. I want to make that point clear. But the specialists are supervising the tests and phoning back the results and consulting with the doctors. The specialists are not doing just that but are performing other public duties, such as tutoring in the hospitals at $19 an hour. They are on various public health committees and are playing their part in maintaining the overall health of the Queensland people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's decision on the reduction of rebates has already caused many retrenchments. I believe that one of the laboratories has put off 50 people and that the other is letting people go by natural wastage. I point out to the Senate that in Queensland a number of public hospitals do not have a pathology department and very few private hospitals have a pathology department. They are totally dependent on these two pathology laboratories for their tests. Also, the Queensland Government, to sustain its hospitals, is putting in 80c for every dollar, and it is a well known fact that the Medicare rebate to the Queensland hospitals is much lower than that to any other State. If these two pathology laboratories have to reduce their services, the Queensland Government will have to provide pathology services. Already the health bill in Queensland is massive and the pathology services being offered by the Queensland Medical Laboratory and Nicolaides have to be used by both public and private hospitals.

The Government states that many of these tests are now done on sophisticated machines, and that is correct. These machines have been in operation for a number of years and the current fees take account of automation. What the Minister failed to take into account when he arbitrarily reduced the Medicare rebate is the high cost of running a business. It is not only the pathology laboratories that are facing the high cost of running a business, but every other business in Australia. Pathology laboratories are no exception. They use very sophisticated gear. They pay high interest rates and high lease rates for cars, computers and the machines that they use. The proposed 3 per cent productivity case, redundancy payments and the devaluation of the dollar are all forcing up their costs. They have to put up their prices to maintain their services. This Government has reduced their payments by 12 per cent. Only in the last two or three days have they had to put up their fees and make the decision that they will not be able to bulk bill people other than low income earners and pensioners. So their fees have gone up by over 3 per cent in the last few days and they will no longer bulk bill.

Everyone supports the Minister's desire to rid the medical profession of unscrupulous practitioners. I do not believe that one person in Australia would not go along with that decision. But the decision of the Minister to reduce the rebate by 25 per cent will hit the ethical practices that are providing a very good service in Queensland, a service that cannot be done without in my State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are once again debating health legislation. The public out there listening to this debate might be forgiven for thinking that at last something is being done about the dreadful situation caused by Medicare. However, that is not so. The Health Legislation Amendment Bill certainly does not address any of the problems such as the public hospital waiting lists in Victoria, New South Wales and my State, Tasmania. Nor does it do anything about the cost of Medicare. The cost of Medicare has increased to such an extent that Government expenditure now on the health care system is larger than that of any other government department except the Department of Social Security. It would not be so bad if all the taxpayers' money being spent on health care resulted in the best health care system in the world. Far from that, the Government has created a two-tiered system. We have one system for those who can afford to pay private insurance for private hospitals. We have another system for people who pay only the levy.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me explain. The Government introduced-we all remember this-a 1 per cent levy on our income. That 1 per cent levy was meant to cover 85 per cent of the medical fee and provide a free bed in a public hospital. It still covers 85 per cent of the medical fee, although there is talk that in the next Budget it will cover only 75 per cent of the cost of the medical fee and the patient will be expected to cover the rest. That is the rumour going around at the moment. The levy covers a free hospital bed in a public hospital-if one can get into a public hospital.

Let us consider the latest figures for the large States and for my State of Tasmania regarding hospital waiting lists. In Victoria, 27,900 people are on the public hospitals waiting lists. There are 6,299 patients waiting for orthopaedic surgery alone and about 1,500 children waiting for a bed at the Royal Children's Hospital. What a shemozzle. What a dreadful situation. Let us look at New South Wales. Even though the New South Wales Government does not supply figures-one must ask why-the estimates are that the situation is very similar. There are about 30,000 people on the waiting lists in New South Wales. Those requiring orthopaedic surgery have to wait 24 months for their hip replacements. Children requiring admittance to hospital have to wait up to nine months. In my State 3,000 people are waiting for private hospital beds-2,000 on the waiting list at the Royal Hobart Hospital and 1,000 at the Launceston General Hospital. Those are the sorts of waiting lists for people who are paying their levy and who were promised a free hospital bed in a public hospital. We have this pitiful situation where those who really need public hospital treatment-the pensioners, the unemployed and the low income earners-have to join those waiting lists.

Let us look at what has occurred. Before Mr Hawke introduced Medicare the Liberal Opposition warned that there would be overcrowding in public hospitals. We told the Government that if people were forced to pay a health tax they would drop their private hospital cover and the public hospitals would not be able to cope with the numbers. That is exactly what has occurred. Professor Penington, a man not given to extravagant statements, has said just recently that the cost of Medicare is out of control and the Government has to take steps to alter it. Professor Penington is an expert in health matters who was appointed by the present Government to chair the Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. The Government should take note of a person it considers to be an expert and should heed the advice given to it. We have people paying a levy for services they find are unavailable. If a person wants to be assured of a bed, he is forced to pay twice. Firstly, he is forced to pay the levy and, secondly, he is forced to pay for private hospital cover.

Let us look at what has happened to the levy, and I have figures here from the statistician. Do honourable senators remember the one per cent levy? The average paid in 1983-84 was $191 from the one per cent levy. In 1985-86 the average is estimated to be $229 for 85 per cent medical cover and a bed in a public hospital if it can be obtained; if not, join the waiting list. If a person was a member of a fund at the time of the introduction of that levy the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, promised that it would be shown separately on the tax form. One wonders why he broke that promise. It is very obvious why he broke that promise. He did not want the people to see, as they made out their tax forms, how often that payment from the one per cent was going up. As I said, the average has already gone up since it was introduced from $191 to $229. Many people cannot afford to pay twice. They find that they are at the end of the waiting list. The poorer in our community are competing for a bed in a public hospital with those who previously could afford to insure for private hospital cover.

The Government is trying to cut costs by all sorts of means. We know that it will have great trouble with its Budget. We know that at present the economy is in such a dreadful mess that the Government is hard-pressed to try to find where it can cut costs. We have been told that a children's hospital could be closed. Friday's newspapers contained headlines that the children's heart surgery unit at the Prince of Wales Children's Hospital is to be closed by 1 July. Those surgical patients will be transferred to the Children's Hospital at Camperdown.
