However, the Children's Hospital has cardiac surgery waiting lists of 160, whereas the Prince of Wales Children's Hospital's cardiac surgery waiting list is 27. The article said:
It is a bit hard to see how you can solve the waiting list problem by closing down one unit.

There are fears of a total closure of that hospital. In light of the disastrous waiting list that already exists in the public hospitals, there are rumours that the Government is to take away $135m from the private hospitals. We all know that at present a subsidy is paid to patients who enter private hospitals-a very small subsidy, but it amounts to $135m to those patients. Because of its mismanagement of the economy, the Government is considering saving costs in that area. If that is what the Government has decided to do, the situation in public hospitals will be 100 times worse than it already is and the waiting lists so much greater. Insurance rates would rise, there would be fewer to insure, more pressure on public hospitals and more pressure on the poor, because they would not be the ones who would be able to get the beds. We know that there are fewer beds now, and indeed last year, than there were when we left government. In 1982-83 in New South Wales there were 27,000 beds in public hospitals; they now have gone to 26,000, a loss of 1,000 beds. With the population going up and the number of hospital beds going down, is it any wonder that the Government has made such a dreadful mess of the availability of hospital beds in New South Wales?

The Government has tried to cover up all these errors with talk of doctor fraud and overservicing. This time, again, the Government is talking about overservicing and fraud, but it is instancing the area of pathology services. We are told that this legislation will greatly reduce the capacity for fraud and overservicing in pathology services. We have the usual types of comments from Labor members in this place. Indeed, Senator Crowley talked of pathologists being offered jobs in entrepreneurial practices at $100,000 a year. We can fix that in one fell swoop, because they would not be able to offer that sort of income to pathologists if they were not bulk billing. It is because of bulk billing that there is a problem in some of the less reputable entrepreneurial types of pathology services.

How much fraud and overservicing is there? We are told by the Government that there is a lot. However, in the first half of 1985-86 the Health Insurance Commission employed 217 people at a cost of $4m to stop this so-called abuse. During that time the Commission stopped payments of $325,000 and recovered $48,000 from fraud. In regard to overservicing the Commission recovered absolutely nothing at all. This was a really cost effective exercise! It cost $4m to get back amounts of $325,000 and $48,000.

If the Government were serious, if it really wanted to save money, and if it were keen enough to give up its ideology, it could stop that overservicing, as I have already said. The Government only has to withdraw bulk billing for all patients. Let me make it perfectly clear that the Opposition believes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The whole of Australia is listening to Senator Walters's plaintive bleatings about the medical profession without knowing that she has a direct family interest in that her husband is a doctor. I think that, if she were to be honest about this, she should make that very clear.
—There is no point of order.
—My husband is not a pathologist.
—I said that there was no point of order.
—I am quite well aware of that. As usual, Senator Bolkus is behaving in an extraordinary fashion.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask for that statement to be withdrawn. I do not ordinarily behave in an extraordinary fashion. I object to that.
—Senator Bolkus, I think that you are out of order.

—If the Government were serious about stopping overservicing, if it were serious about stopping any fraud or about trying to save money and if its ideology did not get in the way, it would stop bulk billing for all patients. The Opposition believes in bulk billing for some patients. It believes in bulk billing for pensioners and for disadvantaged groups. It does not believe that all patients should be bulk billed. Of course, this is what the Government is trying to encourage. If the Government were only serious, it would not encourage doctors to bulk bill all their patients. Of course, what the Government is attempting to do is to socialise medicine. We have to make it perfectly clear that once all doctors bulk bill, when all the doctors are fully paid by the Government, we will have the socialisation of the medical profession.

SPEECH.PARA: Overservicing is a very tricky area. Indeed, patients themselves can ask for overservicing without realising what they are doing. Again, this is caused by bulk billing. We can instance the case of a young mother taking her family along to the doctor. Perhaps she has a four-year-old daughter with an ear infection. She is able quite legitimately to say to the doctor: `Look, while I have Jimmy here would you look at him too because he has been a bit grizzly and he could easily be coming down with the same infection'. Because it will not cost her a penny she will have the doctor look at both her children. Of course, this is overservicing, but overservicing by the patient. While we have bulk billing, such overservicing is easily done. I think people have to be well aware that the Government, because of its ideology, is encouraging bulk billing. Bulk billing is encouraging overservicing and, until we get rid of the bulk billing, the Government will have to put up with continued overservicing by some of the medical profession and many of the patients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 was described earlier tonight as being rather like the curate's egg, which was good in spots and rotten in others. On that basis the speaker was prepared to accept the curate's egg that was rotten in some spots but good in others. I think there was something a little wrong with the analogy because the only thing to do with a rotten egg is to throw out the whole egg. It is more a case of the Sunday school teacher who put a bucket of ice-cream in front of a class, gave everyone a spoon and said: `Sit around that bucket of ice-cream and you have got to show self-restraint. You are not to eat any of that ice-cream'. Of course, after a little while a couple of the children dug into the ice-cream. The teacher said: `You children are behaving unethically. There is only one way to stop you from getting into this ice-cream and that is to put you all into a strait-jacket'. That is exactly what this legislation is trying to do to pathologists in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation represents the normal socialist and bureaucratic response to this part of the health mess that successive governments have got themselves into since 1974 with the advent of Medibank. The basic fault-this has been mentioned by many speakers tonight-has been the promise of health care free at the point of delivery. The engine that governments have used to fulfil that promise has been bulk billing. Bulk billing is at the very basis of the whole promise. I have said time and time again in the Senate that this promise of health care free at the point of delivery is impossible to fulfil. The Government must restrict the service, it must cut the cost. An open ended promise that has to be satisfied from a limited budget just cannot be fulfilled, so the service must be restricted.

The Government never blames itself for the legislation it is trying to implement. It blames doctors, patients, hospitals, administrators, chemists and pharmaceutical companies-anybody it can think of except itself. Usually, it gets its programs underway by denigrating doctors. It says that they are grasping, greedy, bloody-minded-I have heard that said-and unethical. It then subjects them to computer analysis, analysing their prescribing patterns, their visiting patterns and their practising patterns, and compares them with their area averages. If they differ in some minor way with their area average they are counselled. If they do not do what the Government wants they are hauled before medical services committees of inquiry which virtually have Star Chamber powers and discipline them, usually by using a financial mechanism.

The Government started off by telling doctors what pills they could give for what diseases, how many of them and how many repeats. It told doctors the conditions for which they could put patients in hospitals or nursing homes, how long they could keep them there for and how long they would attract benefits. The Government started controlling all the different aspects of medicine and now controls are extending to the pathology area. Once the Government gets its fiery fingers on the financial throat of the health industry it will start to squeeze the life out of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not unsympathetic to what you are saying, but has the AMA ethics committee done its job?

—I will answer that question shortly. I am pointing out that this has been the experience of all national health services around the world, everywhere they have been tried. The one thing they all have in common is that they are all failures. Why we should follow them down the gurgler I do not know. The Government says that it has been removing the financial barrier between the doctors and the patients, but the contrary is the correct view. The Government has erected a financial barrier between the patients and the doctors. People place a far higher value on their health care than does any government. People are willing to donate more, to bequeath more and to spend more on their health than is any government. It is no small wonder that the promise of a health care free at the point of delivery attracts an enormous vote, but it reaps a withered harvest. As this Government's stranglehold tightens, there are more restrictions and controls. There are now more controls on patients, doctors, nurses, hospitals and pharmacists. The constituents of the health area are becoming more disillusioned, disappointed and dissatisfied. That is the position with the pathologists today.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of realising the error of its ways and reducing its role in the health care industry, the Government continues on its rampage. It does not recognise the long waiting lists, particularly for elective surgery, or the shortages of hospital beds, the shortages of nurses and the inequities of nurses' wages and education, the misallocation of funds to areas such as the esoteric, artificial resuscitation programs which are going on in Australia today, such as the acquired immune deficiency syndrome program and the drug offensive to which hundreds of millions of dollars have been misallocated, the cutbacks in research funds, and the dislocation in essential services, especially in private practice and in private hospitals. The Government simply introduces more cost cutting measures, and that is what this is. It is hoping to save $60m with the introduction of this legislation. It does not improve or expand the health services; all it does is restrict them and this Bill is a restrictive Bill.

The Government introduces things such as the fraud and overservicing detection system with an army of investigators, bovver boys, and counsellors. It introduces committees of inquiry to restrict doctors in their practising patterns. It introduces quality assurance, peer review and all sorts of accreditation schemes, not just for doctors and pathologists but for hospitals, nursing homes and pharmacies. It now wants to introduce preferred provider organisations and health maintenance organisations. All these schemes have been tried overseas. They are all measures to cut costs, not to give better services to patients. They restrict services to patients and they all have been proven failures. Not one of them is a success overseas. Far from assuring quality or reducing costs, they increase costs and reduce quality. There is plenty of evidence of that from the schemes being tried overseas, so why is Australia going down that track?

The Government says things such as: `The patients are too dumb to know whether their doctor is any good'. The Government says that doctors are so unscrupulous that they will exploit people when they are at their most vulnerable. The Government also says that health costs are so high that many people cannot afford them, that medical insurance costs are out of reach, that health is too important to leave it in the hands of the doctors, that people must be protected from receiving charity and that health care is their right. All these statements are untrue and, by placing itself between the patients and the doctor, the Government is denying itself the best possible curb on health costs and that is that patients themselves. Each patient when checking the account can see whether he has had the visit, whether it was out of hours, how long it took, and whether he had an X-ray or a test. It is the patients who are the best check on health costs. But, in order to fulfil this impossible promise, the Government is trying to enslave the people who provide the health care. In this case it is the pathologists.

Once again, the Government is going to use its bulk billing as the engine to try, in effect, to convert private doctors into government doctors. When the Government is the doctor's paymaster, the doctor is working for the Government. He is not working for the patient. The doctor will be protecting his position with the Government rather than satisfying the patient. The private doctors will, in effect, become public servants without having any of the benefits enjoyed by public servants. Bulk billing will make government doctors, not private doctors. Government doctors can only do their best with the resources they have available to them. Heaven knows, they try to give good service, but nobody here could say that they are giving a proper service to people when one just looks at the conditions in Australia at the moment. All sorts of administrative restrictions are placed on doctors. Admission and discharge restrictions are being placed on the patients. Treatment routines and treatment restrictions exist in the government hospital service today. Hospital out-patient administrations subject patients to certain requirements. In other words, the administration of the system becomes more important than the poor little patients who walk through the front door of the hospitals.

We have seen doctors and nurses withdraw their services. There is a shortage of nurses in Australia today. Although advertisements have been placed overseas in order to attract nurses to Australia, we have not had very many inquiries about jobs. As a matter of fact, there was a minuscule response to the advertisements. The hospital system has a shortage of thousands of beds. Also, there is a waiting list for elective surgery that one cannot jump over.
Before Australia was subjected to this Australian Labor Party onslaught, we had health services that were the envy of the whole world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dear, oh dear!

—The Minister can laugh but that is the truth. No other country in the world had better health services than Australia. Now we have a costly crumbling shambles. The present package is designed to put pathologists into a tighter straitjacket and to reduce their incomes. The pathologists are really just the next tank off the rank as this socialist juggernaut grinds on, following the assault on our general practitioners, surgeons, nursing homes and private hospitals and hostels. The Government is gradually closing the noose.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government never thinks right through what the effects of the implementation of its policies will be. It has been mentioned here tonight that there are going to be vast restrictions on the provision of pathology services to country areas. But, of course, that does not worry this Government because it has always had it in for the people in the bush. The Government does not like their rugged individuality and the fact that they are implacable opponents of its socialist policies.

As time is running out, I will move on to outline what the Bill is going to do. The Bill seeks to introduce a new approved pathology practitioners scheme. I want honourable senators to note the word `approved'. Today, Australia possibly has the best pathology services in the world. But now the Government is going to approve pathologists who are already qualified, certified and registered and operate laboratories that have been extolled during this debate. Now the Government is going to approve them, not on the basis of their qualifications but on their ability to attract a Medicare rebate. This, in fact, is going to be the criterion. The legislation provides for Medicare participation review committees-another type of review committee-to determine whether a pathologist will be allowed to participate in the scheme, not whether he is a good pathologist. This is just another form of bureaucracy. It provides for the accreditation of pathology laboratories, when we already have some of the best laboratories in the world. Now the Government wants to accredit them. The pathologists are putting their own heads into the accreditation noose by agreeing to such a scheme. Surely the doctors on their own can work out which laboratories are good and which are bad. Laboratories which are abusing the system ought to jump out of the computers. We do not need another bureaucracy; all it will mean is more controls and more restrictions.

We will have a Pathology Services Advisory Committee to advise on fees and services. So we will have more bureaucracy; a whole new section will be set up to handle that. The legislation will create also a pathology services table-this will need another bureaucracy-which will set out prescribed pathology services. The Government might have spelt that word incorrectly; I would say it means proscribed services. We will have pathologist-determinable services. Only a bureaucrat could think up a term like that. We will have another bureaucracy there. Even pathology request forms will have to be approved by the Health Insurance Commission. No longer will a letter from a doctor be acceptable; the request form will have to be approved by the Commission.

On top of all this, the whole Bill is to conform with the Sex Discrimination Act, which was brought in in 1984, at a time when I was not a member of the Parliament. If I had been, I would have opposed that, too. It sounds to me very much as though this will be another bureaucrats' Valhalla. It is typically par for the course for the Government. It is just taking control of another section of the medical profession. It has been said, and I suppose it is true, that the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia is still negotiating with the Government. I do not know why the pathologists should be doing that. They are disillusioned and discouraged at the moment, but they are going ahead with all this accreditation and they probably think they are doing the right thing. I think they are being politically naive and ingenuous. The pathologists are really just fighting a rearguard action against the Government, and I think they have had their Camelot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-One feature of this debate tonight has been that some of the speakers, for example, Senator, Sir John Carrick, Senator Walters and especially Senator Sheil, hardly referred to the Health Legislation Amendment Bill at all. I thank honourable senators for contributing to the debate. I thank the Opposition for not opposing the legislation, which is good legislation, despite the fact that it was described as a curate's egg by two speakers and despite the fact that some reference to ice cream was made by Senator Sheil-a reference I did not quite understand. Very briefly, I point out that Senator Sheil made one of his usual speeches against all controls, all government intervention, all government involvement in medicine. He said tonight that he particularly did not like the way the Australian Labor Party had done terrible things to the medical profession, by introducing computers to look at the patterns of practice of medical practitioners, by introducing counselling for medical practitioners who do not follow the pattern, by cutting back on research, and by introducing peer review and accreditation. The use of computers, the determination of patterns of practice, and counselling of medical practitioners by Government officers, looking at their practices, were introduced even before 1972 by the Liberal-Country Party Government.
—I did not blame the ALP.

—The honourable senator did blame the ALP. Peer review was introduced by a Liberal-Country Party coalition with the agreement of the Australian medical profession, as was accreditation. There has been no cut in medical research; in fact, there has been a real increase in medical research funds in the last three years. That sort of nonsense was typical of the whole of the speech he made.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Withers, as they always do, blamed all the evils of the medical profession, all the evils of the health scheme, as they see them, on bulk billing. That is the politics of simplicity carried to its extreme. Neither of them produced one skerrick of evidence or one figure. They proceeded to denigrate those doctors who bulk bill in the way they complain others denigrate the medical profession. I will not go on listing the sort of nonsense they went on with. But the simple fact of the matter is that if people get up in this place and say that all that is wrong with the medical profession or the health scheme in this country is bulk billing, they are wrong. They should know they are wrong, and I wish my colleague on the other side, Senator Peter Baume, would inform them of that.

Similarly, Senator Sir John Carrick talked about what a terrible thing this Government had done by abolishing gap insurance. I can remember the days when the Australian Medical Association opposed gap insurance, as did the Liberal Party of Australia and the Country Party of Australia. However, things change; it depends whether one is in government or in opposition as to whether one believes in gap insurance.

To get to the specific points that were raised about the legislation, Senator Peter Baume and Senator Haines both asked for assurances that the 18 tests for which rebates are to be reduced would be referred to the proposed Pathology Services Advisory Committee. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) proposes to refer these 18 tests to the Pathology Services Advisory Committee for immediate review. They are the first things that that Committee will look at as part of a detailed review of the entire medical services table. Senator Haines asked when this review would occur. It is envisaged that the Committee will commence its operations as soon as the legislation is through and as soon as the Committee can be established. I cannot give her an exact date but when I can I will get an exact date from the Minister.

Senators Haines and Peter Baume also queried whether the powers to refer matters to the Pathology Services Advisory Committee were too narrow and raised the question that the Parliament might wish to refer matters to the Committee. The Minister, in his second reading speech on this Bill, indicated that the power to refer matters does not limit the capacity of appropriate bodies to raise matters with the Committee. It would then be up to the Committee to decide whether or not it was appropriate to consider the matter, so not only the Minister and the Government can refer matters to the Committee in that way.

Senators Sir John Carrick and Boswell very loudly asked why the Government did not ask for the books of the pathology practitioners to establish costs before making decisions. The Government wanted to and the Government would still like to do that. It is true that some pathologists, particularly the very reputable Queensland pathology company referred to, wish the Government to do so. But in the past the pathologists have always opposed this. The Australian Medical Association has refused to co-operate with the Government in its efforts to establish costs in medical practices. In fact, at its recent national congress the AMA passed motions to advise members not to co-operate with surveys of practice costs-surveys that were being conducted not by the Government but by independent consultants on behalf of the Department of Health. What more can one do when the pathologists and the medical profession refuse to co-operate; but when things happen, they say, `We will now co-operate' and they expect governments to drop everything and to co-operate with them. If they are willing to co-operate, the Government will look at it and the Advisory Committee that is being established, if it so wishes, will look at it.

I believe this is sensible legislation, and I think that everybody on the other side really agrees that it is sensible legislation. I thank honourable senators for their co-operation, and I urge that the Senate give the legislation rapid passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) for his advice about the immediate reference of the 18 most common pathology services to the proposed Pathology Services Advisory Committee. I have one other question which relates to the Medicare Participation Review Committee, which is mentioned in the legislation. The Australian Medical Association has advised me that it has some concerns about the role which this Committee might play in the oversight of pathologists. It observes that some of the matters are highly technical matters, and while it recognises that appropriate disciplinary action has to be taken, it is concerned that the technical matters should be dealt with by people with appropriate technical expertise. I ask the Minister what assurances he can give that might meet the concerns of the Australian Medical Association in this matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that written into the guidelines will be that to establish the fact of overservicing, the medical sub-committee of the Medicare Participation Review Committee, which is made up of doctors, will be the group which decides that fact, but the Committee as a whole will decide as to penalty and whether action should be taken. That technical problem will be decided by the medical sub-committee, which is made up of medical practitioners.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Traffic Intersection: Giralang, Australian Capital Territory

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the question of the future of the intersection of the Barton Highway and William Slim Drive. It is with considerable sorrow that I report to the Senate that during the past three years there have been five deaths at this intersection on a major road going out of Canberra. I do not know why this occurs; it is certainly a wide intersection. There are a number of signs there-perhaps too many, and perhaps this causes confusion. As a result of five deaths having occurred there, there is concern in the community about what should be done. In today's Canberra Times there is a photograph which indicates some of the complexities of the intersection. With that photograph there is a letter which refers to some of the people who have lost members of their family as a result of one of the accidents. There is also a comment from another person who uses the intersection daily. I also have a letter from the Giralang Community Association. Giralang is a suburb quite near the intersection and many of its residents use that intersection frequently. Naturally they are worried about what might occur in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of suggestions have been made as to what should be done. It would appear that the National Capital Development Commission is certainly aware that changes need to be made and it is suggested in the Canberra Times that plans to change some of the lead-in lanes would be implemented soon at a cost of about $30,000. There is another suggestion that perhaps a fly-over should be installed and that this might cost between $2m and $3m. Whatever the sum needed to correct the intersection, it is not easy to come by that sort of money. One suggestion is that there should be a `stop' sign placed against the traffic from William Slim Drive and perhaps there should also be a sign a few hundred metres back saying: `Slow down, stop sign ahead'. That might help.

I ask those responsible for maintaining our road system and that intersection in particular to do something immediately and perhaps work out the more expensive solutions later. Something should be done before anything worse than has already happened occurs. It is suggested that perhaps the speed limit should be reduced but reducing the speed in the Barton Highway over a short period may cause some problems. I am not an expert in traffic, but I know that this corner is causing a great deal of worry to those who use it and especially to those who have suffered loss as a result of it. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter which I have not shown to the Minister and which was written to me by the Giralang Community Association expressing its concern and asking me to refer the matter to the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) for urgent attention.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
GIRALANG COMMUNITY ASSOCIATION
1 Hirst Place, Giralang, ACT 2617
3 June 1986
Senator Margaret Reid,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Reid,

I am sure you are aware of the recent road death at the intersection of the Barton Highway and William Slim Drive. The fifth casualty at this intersection. We are deeply concerned that many people may be killed or severely injured before action is taken. Remember, you personally, and your family and friends are also at risk every time they use this intersection.
As President of the Giralang Community Association I implore you to act immediately and use your influence to improve the safety at this intersection.
The Giralang Community Association would like to see 3 immediate changes.
1. Reduction of Barton Highway speed limit near this intersection of 80 kph, reduction of William Slim Drive speed limit to 60 kph.
2. Replacement of the give way sign on the William Slim Drive entrance to a stop sign.
3. Erection of large warning signs on all entrances to the intersection, warning traffic of an extremely dangerous intersection.

As the above 3 measures will only have limited success Giralang Community Association requests the intersection be completely redesigned. We would like to know the practicality of commencing work on such a design by advancing the plans for the duplication of William Slim Drive at the intersection.
Yours faithfully,
Bill Burmester,
President
Giralang Community Association

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do as Senator Reid asks.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1985 (Hansard, page 318), Senator Chaney asked me a question without notice regarding the agreement reached between management and workers at the Mudginberri abattoir. Senator Chaney asked whether the agreement resulted in higher wages, increased productivity and lower costs which enabled the meatworks to achieve a more competitive position and whether Australia's competitive position can be improved by other enterprises entering into the same sorts of employer-employee relationships. In my reply I undertook to pass Senator Chaney's question to the Ministers responsible.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Prior to the making of the Northern Territory Meat Processing Award 1984 by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the meat processing industry in the Northern Territory was award free and was predominantly regulated by contract.

The new Award, which is based primarily on the provisions of Part I of the Federal Meat Industry Award 1981, includes a provision (Clause 33) enabling the use, on certain conditions, of systems of payment by results. The Commission's decision was made in accordance with Principle 10 of the current National Wage Principles, First Awards and Extensions of Existing Awards, which embodies the long established practice that any new award would reflect existing rates and conditions in an industry.

In accordance with the terms of the Award the owner of the Mudginberri abattoir entered into a private agreement with his employees concerning rates of pay. The owner claims that that agreement resulted in higher wages, increased productivity and lower costs. However, the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, which was not involved in discussions concerning that agreement, continues to have a number of serious reservations about the appropriateness of such agreements. The union was concerned about being left out of the decision making process on the form of payment which shall apply under the Award. In that context the union applied to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a variation of the payment by results clause of the Award. On 27 March 1986, a Full Bench of the Commission handed down its decision on the union's application. Specifically, the Full Bench decided to vary the Award to prescribe a consultative role for the union so that it will be aware of moves to negotiate a payment by results agreement, though not necessarily being a direct party to those negotiations unless requested by employees. The Full Bench also commented that it saw its decision as an attempt to encourage an essential improvement in industrial relations in the Northern Territory and that the success or otherwise of that attempt depends upon the willingness of the parties to contribute to such an improvement. The Government supports that intention and accordingly encourages the parties to seek to work towards that objective.

With regard to claims that the agreement which operated at Mudginberri during the 1985 season resulted in higher wages, increased productivity and lower costs, I would refer to comments made by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) concerning the tally system in its 1983 Report on the Abattoir and Meat Processing Industry. Specifically the IAC concluded that it was not clear that any alternative to the tally system of payment, which is used in the great majority of abattoirs throughout Australia, would improve industrial relations or reduce the costs of meat processing. Indeed, the IAC report identified a number of cost disabilities not stemming from the method of payment of meat- workers, which fell within the responsibility of State Governments and which distorted the efficient operation of the industry. In that context I would also indicate that a number of abattoirs in the Northern Territory currently operate under the tally system.

As to the question whether Australia's competitive position can be improved by other enterprises entering into similar sorts of agreements, I would point out that this really touches on one of the basic points made by the Opposition parties in the area of industrial relations, that being the need to deregulate the labour market.
Deregulation of the labour market has been comprehensively and unambiguously rejected by the tripartite Hancock Committee of Review of Australia's Industrial Relations System.
So far as this Government is concerned, the Hancock Committee is absolutely right.

There is little doubt that deregulation is a totally impracticable policy. It involves inevitable widespread confrontation with the trade union movement and all the industrial turmoil that would produce.

Such a policy would also mean that there would be no mechanism through which a wages policy could be effectively implemented. In all likelihood a wages explosion, such as occurred during Australia's last experiment with deregulation in 1981/82, would occur destroying the benefits of lower inflation, reduced unemployment and real labour costs which have resulted from implementation of aspects of the Prices and Incomes Accord.

Major employer organisations have made it clear that they do not want deregulation of the labour market. For instance the Director-General of the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) last year stated that not only did the CAI prefer the current system of conciliation and arbitration, but so too did the majority of employers.
